IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delineating the functionality and pharmacology of specific supraspinal pathways involved in pain modulation is of critical importance if we are to understand neural dysfunction that contributes to chronic pain. The goal of this project is to define neural mechanisms through which a common lipid signaling pathway drives antinociception by altering the excitability of specific supraspinal pathways sensitized by chronic pain. Findings of this project have promising potential for uncovering preclinical and clinical drug targets within sensory-discriminative and affective supraspinal circuits that could lead to novel approaches exploiting lipid signaling pathways for treating chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative For 38 years, Children’s Hospital Oakland Research Institute has hosted a program for underrepresented minorities to confront the disparities of representation for students of color and economic disadvantage within science employment and academic programs. In this request for continued funding, we propose an updated curriculum called STIMULUS (Science & Technology IMmersion for Underrepresented Learners in the US) in order to grow the program and be responsive to the changing needs of modern student. The curriculum has many additions, including new collaborations with the UCB Department of Bioengineering, more comprehensive training workshops, expanded recruiting from regional pipeline programs and historically black colleges, formalized program for near-peer mentoring, case-based approach for bioethics education, and enhanced alumni tracking and evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This competive renewal focuses on characterization of residual CLL cells and immune function of the microenvironment after prolonged therapy with an irreversible Bruton’s tyrosine Kinase inhibitor (BTKi), either ibrutinib and acalabrutinib. Additionally, this project seeks to target these residual cells for elimination clinically using novel immune based therapies such as VAY-736 to facilitate discontinuation strategies of BTKi with significant economic and survivorship benefit to patients with CLL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE KRAS-driven non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) remains one of the most aggressive and lethal solid tumors, therapeutic options and outcomes for NSCLC have remained virtually unchanged over the past thirty years. Using novel CRISPR/Cas9-based genome-engineering technologies we have established a unique and rapid research program to functionally characterize lung cancer mutations and identify genotype-specific metabolic vulnerabilities that can lead to novel therapeutic approaches in KRAS-driven lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This real world efficacy study (NIH stage 3) will determine the benefit of social needs (e.g., for housing, food, transportation) screening, community-based service referrals, and telephonic follow-up as a scalable, sustainable strategy for preventing COVID-19 transmission, and for addressing the secondary health effects of the social, behavioral, and economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Results of this study will provide much needed information regarding whether social needs screening and community service referrals improves health outcomes of vulnerable and socioeconomically disadvantaged populations, an NIH-designated health disparity population, and whether intensive follow-up and collaborative goal-setting helps overcome barriers to community service use by patients seen in the emergency department and seeking COVID testing at community-based and mobile clinic locations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Research narrative Neuroendocrine cells in adrenal glands secrete adrenalin in response to stress, increasing the rate of blood circulation, breathing, and carbohydrate metabolism, preparing muscles to exert. However, extracellular matrix proteins are constantly secreted from fibroblasts to embed cells within tissues and protect them from mechanical damage. Our work will elucidate basic mechanisms controlling secretion to help understand pathologies such as psychiatric disorders or cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is of high relevance to Public Health, because it aims at understanding and controlling Notch1-driven leukemogenesis and discovering potential new target to guide the personalized treatment of a disease of unmet need. The successful completion of the proposed project will elucidate a new ‘molecular rheostat’ that calibrate Notch signaling activation and open the way for targeting the endo-lysosomal pathway in T-ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposed study aims to understand the role and mechanism of gain-of-function mutant p53 in colorectal tumorigenesis. We will test the hypothesis that mutant p53 drives fatty acid synthesis as a critical gain-of-function mechanism to promote colorectal tumorigenesis, which can be targeted for therapy in colorectal cancers carrying mutant p53. We expect that the results from this study will deepen our understanding of mechanism of mutant p53 in tumorigenesis, and provide the rationale and base for the development of new therapeutic targets and strategies for cancers carrying mutant p53.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hundreds of thousands of adult patients undergo cardiac surgery every year in the United States, each of whom has a significant risk of reintubation after surgery. A better understanding of interventions that can effectively decrease the reintubation rate could help decrease short- and long-term mortality, cost, and hospital length of stay. Therefore, we propose the “Reducing ReIntubation Risk in High-Risk Cardiac Surgery Patients with High-Flow Nasal Cannula” (I-CAN) Study, to assess whether this simple, relatively non-invasive technique can help decrease postoperative reintubation rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Ewing sarcoma (ES) is the second most common bone tumor in children and adolescents. As survival for ES has not improved beyond ~60% in the last few decades, it is critical to understand its molecular underpinnings in order to improve therapy. The experiments outlined below represent a novel method for clarifying the molecular mechanisms that underlie ES, which if successful would uncover new pathways that could inform the development of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients who receive hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) to cure their cancers face elevated risks for skin cancers in the future. We are testing which program best supports better and faster diagnosis of skin cancers: 1) teaching patients to perform skin self-examination and talk to their doctors, 2) teaching patients and their doctors to perform skin examinations, or 3) teaching patients and their doctors to perform skin examinations and doctors to take digital photographs for “tele”-dermatology support. We expect our results to improve detection of skin cancer in HCT survivors, and ultimately other high-risk cancer survivor populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a systemic inflammatory disorder affecting approximately 1.5 million adults in the United States; parenchymal lung disease, which includes interstitial lung disease and emphysema, is a common lung complication of RA associated with significant morbidity and mortality. This study aims to better define clinical and molecular features of early RA-associated parenchymal lung disease, thereby leading to improved non-invasive ways to identify those at risk for progressive disease. The results of this work have the potential to lead to earlier opportunities for intervention and improved outcomes in RA patients with interstitial lung disease and emphysema.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Microbial communities in the cervicovaginal space are associated with spontaneous preterm birth. To truly advance the field and provide clinically relevant therapeutic targets, it is imperative that we more fully understand how the cervicocovaginal ecosystem leads to premature cervical remodeling and spontaneous preterm birth. Importantly, for the significant racial disparity in preterm birth, these studies are focused in black women in order to have the greatest impact on those at risk for this significant adverse health outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative African American women experience a high burden of cardiometabolic diseases, including obesity, heart disease, and type 2 diabetes. Performing regular aerobic physical activity is an established behavior to prevent and manage these conditions. The purpose of this study is to test the efficacy of a culturally tailored, theory- based smartphone-delivered physical activity intervention to increase physical activity and improve cardiometabolic disease risk factors among sedentary African American women with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Oral drug delivery has multiple advantages over intravenous or injectable routes, including higher patient compliance, reduced complication rates, and ultimately lower cost and improved patient outcomes. A class of drugs called peptide macromolecules, which includes insulin as well as monoclonal antibodies indispensable to a wide variety of inflammatory conditions, cannot be given orally despite years of intense research. Here, we bring preliminary data built through 10+ years of NIH-funded multidisciplinary collaboration and propose to advance a new paradigm where these drugs can be given by mouth by small, millimeter-scale autonomous robots that can latch to the intestinal mucosa and inject these drugs into the systemic circulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About one man in nine will be diagnosed with prostate cancer in their lifetime, about 80% of men who reach age 80 will have cancer cells in their prostate, but only one in 39 will die from it. Our ability to determine which patients will die is limited by our lack of understanding of how prostate cancer develops. The proposed studies will use new technologies to build better human models of prostate cancer to gain a better understanding of how prostate cancer develops.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe acute vascular brain injuries encompassing ischemic stroke, intracerebral hemorrhage, and cardiac arrest are common, disabling, and often deadly. While palliative care is increasingly recognized as a specialty with expertise in reducing suffering and improving patient and family centered decision making in people with serious illness, there is a paucity of research specific to applying palliative care principles to individuals with severe acute brain injury. This project will help to define the scope of advanced, complex symptoms and needs for this common yet understudied population of seriously ill individuals in order to help design future specific interventions to reduce the emotional and psychological burden on patients and families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Exosomes are microparticles released from many animal and human cells, which contain various bioactive lipids, endothelin, microRNAs or proteins such as enzymes. These exosomes may contribute to dysfunction of small heart arteries leading to ischemic heart disease (IHD) including heart attack. This grant application seeks to examine how exosome release is controlled in these arteries and how aggregation of the exosomes reduce heart blood flow, which will elucidate a novel mechanism that potentially causes IHD in addition to hardening of large heart arteries, helping develop new therapy in the future for more effective prevention or treatment of chest pain and heart attack due to IHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The overall goal of this proposal is to dissect the molecular mechanisms of metabolic regulation of ATP-citrate lyase (ACLY) and to characterize ACLY inhibitors for cancer therapy. Together, these studies will elucidate how cellular metabolites, and posttranscriptional and posttranslational modification, tune ACLY activity and will lead to the rational development of ACLY drugs to treat cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NHL is the most common hematologic malignancy, and there are many unmet clinical and public health needs of this growing patient population. The goal of this infrastructure grant is to support a cohort of over 16,000 non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) patients in order to address broad and cutting-edge research that identifies clinical, epidemiologic (including lifestyle and other exposures), host genetic, tumor, and treatment factors, and the interaction among these factors, on short and long-term outcomes. These efforts will identify new approaches to improve the survival and well-being of NHL patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRARATIVE CAR T cells have the potential to recognize and specifically kill cancer cells, making them the target of extensive anti-cancer drug development research. This proposal will use a novel technology for monitoring the activation state of a T cell, a protein-interaction-network based approach called Quantitative Multiplex co-Immunoprecipitation, or QMI. Our goal is to identify a protein interaction network state indicative of clinical performance, and to better understand the molecular mechanisms responsible for CAR T cell efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Few studies have focused on the skin microbiome from birth to a steady state in preterm infants. Early interactions between the skin and microbes are particularly important in preterm neonates, who are at increased risk for sepsis. A better understanding of the preterm infant skin microbiome, as well as microbial shifts that precede sepsis, will lead to strategies for early identification and prevention of neonatal sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Severe periodontitis affects over 50% of adults worldwide and is characterized by a pathogenic biofilm and chronic inflammation of the tooth supporting tissues11, 27, 72. P. gingivalis is considered a causative species in periodontitis that can function to reshape the oral microbial community leading to dysbiosis and tissue damage73. Development of a safe treatment and preventative for periodontitis that specifically inhibits P. gingivalis colonization without harming the healthy oral microbiome has the potential to significantly improve the health of the world’s population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rural patients have traditionally been underrepresented in cardiovascular clinical trials yet have a higher burden of cardiovascular disease than patients from metropolitan areas. Thus, there is a significant need to integrate rural patients in clinical trials conducted by the Cardiothoracic Surgical Trials Network. Dartmouth- Hitchcock Medical Center and Maine Medical Center as Linked Clinical Research Centers will expand the capacity of cardiothoracic surgery research in Northern New England and develop strategies to implement research findings to rural communities with a high cardiovascular disease burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Leptomeningeal disease (LMD) is a metastatic cancer of the brain that impacts up to 30% of all patients with a primary tumor of advanced stage, most commonly from breast, lung or skin cancer. Treatment options and prognosis for these patients are poor with survival ranging from 3-6 months depending on the location of the primary tumor. The device proposed in this project will deliver chemotherapy more effectively by controlling the flow of CSF in an effort to improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) aggressively spreads to surrounding brain tissue, often preventing surgical resection; approved therapy works in only 30% of patients. Our results with genetic and pharmacological GPR68 knockdown suggest GPR68 is critical for GBM survival and treatment resistance, and this Phase I project is focused on selecting a lead GPR68 inhibitor and establishing proof-of-concept that GPR68 is a therapeutically relevant and tractable target. Successful completion of this project will move us closer to developing a new therapy that could finally make a significant shift in GBM patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular events (heart damage, stroke, blood clots) appear to be both common and dangerous in patients who are hospitalized with COVID-19. A better understanding of which patients are at highest risk for these events is a key step to developing better approaches for prevention and treatment. We will combine multiple sources of information, including a large national COVID-19 registry from the American Heart Association, health care data from Medicare, and blood protein levels from patients treated at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, to identify the factors that are associated with a higher risk of short- and long-term cardiovascular events among patients hospitalized with COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Generalized spike-wave (SW) absence seizure is the most common seizure disorder in children and thought to be exclusively of genetic origin. While over 20 genes have been discovered and studied in SW epilepsies, it re- mains unclear how each of genetic lesions disrupts the stability of developing cortical circuits and ultimately leads to the same seizure phenotype. To this end, we take advantage of three monogenic mouse models of SW epilepsy and perform the comprehensive cortical circuit analysis and comparisons among distinct genotypes along the seizure development, aiming to identifying the stereotypical circuit deficits underlying SW seizure expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Slit is a signaling molecule that repels growing nerves. Slit can get cut into two fragments that have new and distinct activities, both for growing nerves and many other processes in the body including inhibiting HIV replication, metabolic function and blood vessel permeability. Despite this, the function of Slit fragments in nerve growth is controversial and this proposal will define the biological activities of the fragments using a molecular genetic approach in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A vast and diverse community of microbes known as the gut microbiota colonizes the human intestine. The microbiota is largely a beneficial community, but also produces some potentially toxic compounds that can accumulate to high levels in the circulation of dialysis patients. This proposal aims to define the bacterial species and genes that make these compounds and how the gut microbiota can be rationally altered to reduce the production of toxic substances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Genomic instability, a major driving force of cancer initiation and progression, generates unique “mutation signatures” that are characteristic of specific types of human cancer. To elucidate how these mutation signatures arise during tumor development, this study will focus on triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), a highly aggressive malignancy characterized by lesions in the BRCA1 tumor suppression pathway. In particular, the full spectrum of TNBC mutation signatures will be defined and the molecular mechanisms by which these signatures arise will be elucidated.

PHR: Narrative  Sepsis is a highly lethal disorder due of uncontrolled infection. It is the major cause of death in most intensive care units in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Kinase inhibitors are gaining increased FDA approvals for treatment of cancer and other diseases. Outcome of the studies will accelerate the kinase drug discovery efforts and expand the druggable target space.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Our work has identified the protein NCOA4 as a critical regulator of iron homeostasis in health and disease. NCOA4 targets ferritin, the cellular iron storage complex, for degradation in the lysosome which leads to release of iron for use in a variety of physiological pathways, e.g. DNA replication and repair, hemoglobin synthesis, and red blood cell production. This proposal focuses on identifying how NCOA4 activity is regulated in cells and the importance of NCOA4 in normal physiology and in pathophysiological conditions such as iron deficiency anemia and ferroptosis, an iron-dependent form of cell death. A further understanding of how NCOA4 works could improve treatment of iron deficiency disorders such as iron deficiency anemia and iron overload disorders such as hemochromatosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aberrant chromosome rearrangements, particularly chromosome translocations, are implicated in the development of human cancers. Chromosomal translocations arise when DNA breaks are inappropriately brought in close vicinity and mis-repaired. Thus, the generation of distinct repair domains is a critical tumor suppressor mechanism. The goals of this project are to determine how DNA double-strand breaks domains are generated to ensure genome stability and how defects in the spatial organization of DSB repair yields specific mutation and chromosome rearrangement signatures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Norovirus is the leading cause of childhood diarrhea around the world, but the development of therapeutics has been limited by a lack of understanding of the pathogenic mechanisms underlying norovirus-induced gastroenteritis. We have developed a symptomatic mouse model for murine norovirus infection that allows us to study how norovirus causes disease. The objectives of this proposal are to understand norovirus interactions with the intestinal epithelium and how these norovirus-intestinal epithelium interactions cause diarrhea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rapid assessment and response to the increasingly diverse tobacco market are essential to informing and evaluating FDA’s current and pending regulatory actions, including proposed product standards, pending marketing authorizations for e-cigarettes, and the modified risk tobacco products (MRTPs) pathway. This U01 proposal assembles a large collaborative network that triangulates multiple data sources to establish the Center for Rapid Surveillance of Tobacco (CRST), which will perform surveillance of tobacco product marketing, the tobacco product marketplace, and tobacco use behaviors, transforming tobacco surveillance to be rapid, comprehensive, and coordinated, with salient findings fed immediately into traditional data collection systems. By identifying and evaluating signals in a timely fashion, the CRST will generate critical actionable information about changes in tobacco products which can inform FDA’s regulation of tobacco products leading to a substantial public health impact.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly 25% of Veterans have diabetes, which costs the VA 1.5 billion annually. Diabetes is associated with impaired daily functioning and quality of life. Most Veterans to do not engage in recommended physical activity and other diabetes self-management behaviors. Most self-management takes place outside of medical visits; however, factors related to self-management are only assessed at the time of medical visits, likely missing large amounts of variability. The proposed study will use real-world ambulatory assessment methods to examine daily fluctuations in symptoms like mood, pain, and stress, and social context like social support and daily interactions in relation to physical activities, in real-time, in Veteran’s own environments. Results will inform more effective assessment tools and interventions that may improve daily functioning and quality of life. Technology-supported interventions can provide the right type of support at the right time by adapting to an individual’s changing internal and contextual state to maximize physical, psychological, and social functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Complex interactions among neurons, glia, immune and endothelial cells in the microenvironment drive the progression, treatment resistance, and recurrence of glioblastoma (GBM), an incurable primary brain tumor. The short-term goal of this project is to elucidate how a poorly understood microenvironmental interaction—namely, mitochondrial transfer from neural cells to GBM—drives tumorigenicity, focusing on astrocytes as predominant organelle donors. The long-term goal and future studies will (a) investigate the differential mechanistic role of mitochondrial transfer from diverse brain cell lineages, (b) interrogate how mitochondrial transfer influences spatio-temporal heterogeneity in primary and recurrent patient GBM specimens, and (c) develop therapeutics targeting molecular mediators of this protumorigenic interaction.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative  Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is associated with later development of impaired cognitive function and dementia. The mechanisms underlying this relationship remain largely unknown. TBI causes early and late impairment of cerebrovascular function, much in the same way that dementia disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease and vascular dementia were associated with early development of impaired vascular function. Our overall goal is to test the hypotheses that long-term mild TBI (mTBI)-induced cognitive dysfunction is due, at least in part, to persistent cerebrovascular dysfunction and that early onset mTBI will contribute to worse cerebrovascular and cognitive function with concomitant hypertension. We will use a validated model of diffuse mTBI in rats using fluid percussion injury. We will measure cognitive function using novel object recognition tasks. We will measure cerebrovascular function in living animals using magnetic resonance imaging and by measuring reactivity of blood vessels isolated from the brain. We will determine the relationship between cerebrovascular function and cognitive function and evaluate whether aerobic exercise training will attenuate the effects of mTBI. In rats genetically predisposed to develop hypertension, we will also compare cerebrovascular and cognitive function with mTBI versus those without. The proposal is significant in filling in our knowledge gaps about how mTBI causes impaired cognitive function as well as understanding the underlying causes on how TBI induces impaired cerebrovascular function. If successful, the study will uncover important new treatment pathways that could be used to prevent impaired cognitive and cerebrovascular function following TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research is to understand how neurons in the retina convert the image on the back of the eye into electrical signals for transmission to the brain. We will focus on understanding the neural signals related to night-vision and to the detection of motion in the visual scene. The results of the investigations will help us to understand how the neural networks function of the healthy eye, which will help to understand how pathological conditions compromise vision, and thereby ultimately point to possible novel therapies and prosthetics for the treatment of blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Our vision depends on the flexible interplay of excitatory and inhibitory circuits across the visual cortex. Understanding the connectivity and dynamics underlying visual perception would not only elucidate key processes of cortical computations but may also grant insights into understanding maladaptive changes to connectivity or network function that underlie pathophysiology of neurological disorders. This project aims to provide a mechanistic basis for a key process of visual computation and further our understanding on how the visual cortex forms a cohesive representation of the visual environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: VISITING NURSE SERVICE OF NEW YORK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gender minorities experience disparities in physical and mental health. Gender-affirming healthcare has the potential to mitigate these disparities, yet this population faces multiple barriers to accessing competent care. This mixed-method, longitudinal cohort study examines changes in psychosocial adjustment and health-related quality of life after gender-affirming surgery, informing the development of future home- and community-based healthcare interventions to promote their health and wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Cortical visual impairment (CVI) is the most common cause of pediatric visual impairment in developed countries, but there is no evidence-based treatment, in part due to the absence of a validated and comprehensive method of visual assessment that can be used as an outcome measure in clinical trials. The primary objective of this proposal is to use high resolution eye tracking and machine learning to develop and validate a CVI eye tracking severity score. The proposed studies will establish eye tracking as a quantitative, objective, and comprehensive measure of visual function in children with CVI, with widespread applicability in both clinical and research settings via the CVI eye tracking severity score, which will automate data interpretation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Human stem cell derived tissues offer new models for studying human retinal degenerative eye disease, potentially providing new insight into the biology of inherited retinal degenerations. In this application, we propose to use stem cell derived AIPL1 mutant reporter lines to explore how variations in different functional domains lead to the disease phenotypes observed in LCA and CORD. We propose to study the consequences of mutations in different functional domains in rods and cones and will develop a gene-therapy based approach to prevent retinal degenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Treatment planning for radiation therapy, where an optimal treatment strategy is designed for each individual patient and executed for the whole treatment course, plays a central role for the success of radiation therapy treatment. The current treatment planning workflow is inefficient and produces plans with sub-optimal quality, substantially deteriorating treatment outcomes. Jointing strong research and clinical expertise at UT Southwestern Medical Center with extensive commercial product development experience at Varian Medical Systems Inc, this project will develop and translate an artificial intelligence planner that is capable of efficiently generating high quality treatment plans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Food Allergy is a serious and sometimes fatal condition affecting nearly 30 million people in the US for which there is currently no cure. We developed an innovative berberine nanoparticle called NIT-X that in preclinical murine studies causes rapid, selective and lasting abrogation of IgE and completely protects from anaphylaxis. Understanding how NIT-X causes sustained reduction of food specific-IgE production advances scientific knowledge of food allergy mechanisms and facilitates the development of a curative therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Incarcerated people are a key population facing disproportionately high HIV burden in Zambia and across sub- Saharan Africa, yet almost nothing is known about their patterns of HIV risk behaviors or pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) use during and after incarceration, which are thought to be times of substantial HIV risk. In the PreVAIL study, we will assess patterns of PrEP uptake and persistence, HIV incidence, and HIV risk perception among incarcerated people in Zambia, and conduct qualitative assessments of facilitators and barriers to efficacious PrEP use in this population both during and after incarceration. Insights from this study will generate currently unavailable data to inform the development of a differentiated service delivery model to deliver effective HIV prevention services to justice-involved persons, and provide critical information to surmount last-mile barriers to HIV epidemic control in Zambia, with applicability across other low- and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a cornerstone to ending HIV in the United States (US), but gaps in PrEP uptake expose regional and racial disparities; despite accounting for the majority of new HIV infections, PrEP use remains exceedingly low among young sexual and gender minorities (YSGM) in the US South. In North Carolina, the HIV epidemic is uniquely concentrated in more rural counties, presenting unique HIV prevention challenges including provider shortages, over-burdened health departments, intersectional stigmas, and lack of PrEP knowledge among providers and rural YSGM. In this project, we will partner with state and local health department sexually transmitted infection clinics to examine a multilevel intervention targeting PrEP use barriers at the policy, clinic, provider, and PrEP user levels, with the goal of increasing PrEP uptake and persistence among YSGM via an integrated, cost-effective, and scalable strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Navigation is an important daily skill that engages many sensory, motor and cognitive systems, but which can be severely impaired by aging and degenerative brain diseases. We propose to dramatically advance our understanding of the brain mechanisms mediating navigation by using high field fMRI to measure brain activity during a naturalistic driving task, and then analyzing these data by means of an innovative voxelwise modeling framework. The results will be used to test dozens of specific hypotheses about navigation, and to recover functional areas and networks that mediate this important process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Statement of Relevance to Public Health To date, the SARS CoV-2 pandemic has resulted in over half a million deaths in the US alone. Although effective vaccines are now available, there are limited therapeutic options for patients who develop life-threatening COVID-19. The SCARLET trial is a blinded, placebo-controlled, and randomized Phase 1 dose-ranging and safety study with an adaptive design in adult COVID-19 patients with ARDS, which will confirm that administration of the liponucleotide citicoline every 12 hours by i.v. bolus is safe in this vulnerable population and will provide preliminary evidence that citicoline has clinical efficacy in COVID-19 patients with ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Peptides have extraordinary potential as therapeutics for a wide range of conditions, yet their extremely short half-lives in biological environments hamper clinical implementation prospects. Attaching peptides to polymer chains or physically encapsulating peptides within polymer particles can prolong peptide half-life and even improve biological function, however some polymer-peptide formulation designs can render peptide therapeutics less active. Towards fully leveraging the tunability of polymers to maximize clinical benefits of therapeutic peptides, this proposal describes a systematic investigation of how the molecular design of polymer-peptide formulations impacts the biophysical properties that influence biological function, including size, morphology, surface charge, stability, and binding affinity to biological targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinal degeneration (RD) affects both photoreceptors and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). This study will determine whether transplants of a human embryonic stem cell (hESC)-derived retina together with a supporting layer of RPE promote better visual improvement than transplant of hESC-retina alone by using an RD rat model with dysfunctional RPE that does not reject human cells. In addition, we will investigate the mechanism of visual improvement with hESC- retinal transplants by creating RD rats with labels that identify specific host cells and investigating host-transplant connectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The COBRE Center for Applied Immunology and Pathological Processes (CAIPP) provides a unique interactive training and research environment for investigators to receive mentorship and guidance, while increasing the competitiveness of their research programs for national funding. The proposed Center will allow the development and growth of the key infrastructure needed to support the national competitiveness of not only the members of the CAIPP Center, but of all researchers on campus, the region and the state. We propose new techniques and infrastructure not presently found on campus. We also propose to promote the interaction and synergy of multiple disciplines where appropriate and harness the collective strengths of the collaborative departments and schools within the state and region to drive research competitiveness. Together, the CAIPP will advance new insights and understanding for how when the immune system is dysregulated in either a hyperactive manner as would be seen in the case of chronic inflammatory conditions or when negatively affected such as during infection with viral or bacterial pathogens, serious and often fatal disease pathologies ensue. It is the understanding of the molecular and clinical basis for these diseases and resulting immunopathologies that we hope will lead to new and better ways to detect and treat these various diseases. These proposed studies go hand and hand with the needs of the citizens of the State of Louisiana where diseases associated with altered immune responsiveness take a significant toll on the health of the citizens of the state, as well as financially on the health care system within the state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Although HIV self-testing (HIVST) can reach men who have sex with men at high risk of HIV infection, most MSM who remain at risk are never linked to care and even fewer initiate pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) after testing, highlighting a major gap in the HIV prevention continuum. We seek to close this gap by developing and piloting a peer-led linkage to PrEP intervention after HIVST, with the goal of increasing PrEP uptake among MSM at risk of HIV. The proposed research will optimize the impact of HIVST among MSM, an evidence-based tool to expand HIV testing, while expanding the prevention continuum through linkage to PrEP to reduce new HIV infections in this key population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) are neuromodulatory G protein-coupled receptors with critical roles as drug targets for neurological and psychiatric diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Men of African ancestry have a higher incidence and mortality from prostate cancer (PCa) than men of European ancestry. There is currently an urgency to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying these race-related differences and to harness them for identifying novel therapeutic targets. The high mortality of advanced PCa is attributed to therapy resistance, thus there is also an urgent clinical need to develop innovative approaches to circumvent this resistance. The proposed study will uncover the molecular basis for specific race-related differences in PCa immunobiology, which could provide key insights into immune determinants contributing to PCa mortality disparities. The study will also establish the glycolytic enzyme Enolase as a potential therapeutic and theranostic target for advanced PCa, which could lead to innovative clinical strategies to reduce overall PCa mortality disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Multi-drug resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae infections are a major threat to human health as we move into the 21st century. One of the defining characteristics of K. pneumoniae is a robust capsule that aids in resistance to the human complement system, host antimicrobial peptides, and last resort therapeutic polymyxins. This proposal will define the physiochemical attributes that allow for antimicrobial peptide penetration through capsule and provide direction for therapeutic development of antimicrobial peptides to inhibit the fatal infections caused by K. pneumoniae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Gut colonization by Klebsiella pneumoniae greatly increases the risk of acquiring a subsequent K. pneumoniae infection, which is a leading cause of hospital-acquired and highly antibiotic-resistant infections. This study will examine K. pneumoniae gut colonization to identify, characterize and prioritize targets for focused therapeutic intervention. Thus, the proposed research is directly relevant to the mission of NIH to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness by contributing to the understanding of the first step in K. pneumoniae pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal control of movement is extensively studied not only because it underlies fundamental human behaviors but also because neurodegenerative diseases that affect the motor system represent a significant burden for human health. We have identified abnormalities in the way neurons communicated with each other by means of abnormal removal of synaptic connections, which result in pathological situations. Additionally, we will be investigating the cellular and neuronal circuit mechanisms involved in postural and locomotor deficits since this proposal describes a multidisciplinary effort aimed to determine the molecular and cellular mechanisms that may contribute to human diseases such as spinal muscular atrophy—the leading genetic cause of death in infancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitors have transformed the treatment of intraocular vascular disorders such as wet AMD, but there is an urgent need to discover longer-acting VEGF inhibitors in order to reduce the burden of intravitreal injections. We hypothesized that the ability to bind heparan-sulfate proteoglycans in the vitreous may be a strategy to promote intraocular retention and lead to a longer half-life. We designed a series of VEGF receptor 1 variants and identified some with strong heparin-binding characteristics that are more effective and durable in animal models of intraocular neovascularization than a standard of care such as aflibercept. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This study will define the potential of interventions based on the removal of CD8+ lymphocytes to disrupt virus latency and reduce the reservoir that persists under antiretroviral therapy in SIV/SHIV-infected rhesus macaques. We will build upon our previously published data and use a highly relevant, well validated animal model to provide novel, critical information on how the recently-discovered latency promoting activity of CD8+ lymphocytes can be manipulated in vivo to reduce or eliminate the persistent virus reservoir under ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) by conjugation is one of the main contributors to the worldwide spread of antibiotic resistance. The proposed work will develop a novel, synthetic-biology-based intervention strategy for targeted suppression or elimination of self-transmissible plasmids. This strategy has two major implications: (1) addressing the rising antibiotic resistance crisis, by limiting their spread; (2) providing a toolkit for precision microbiome engineering through the modulation of gene flux.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Poly(ADP)-ribose polymerase inhibitors (PARPi) exemplify a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of homology-repair deficient tumors. The proposed research is relevant to public health as elucidation of the cellular DNA repair mechanisms that respond to PARPi treatment will enable novel approaches to combat clinical issues of resistance and relapse. Successful completion of the proposed research will advance the NIH mission to improve human health by providing the framework for the development of new therapeutics for the treatment of BRCA and homology-repair deficient malignancies.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The burden of tuberculosis is disproportionately borne by low- and middle-income countries of sub-Saharan Africa, such as Uganda. The current proposal is built upon the premise that digital mobile technologies, that were not developed with health purposes in mind, may be leveraged in imaginative and novel ways to provide useful information that could guide the prevention and control of tuberculosis transmission, infection, and disease. The proposed training program will build research capacity among a community of scientists to enable them to apply new technologies and analytic methods to study an old disease like tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a major risk factor for osteoarthritis that involves both mechanical (altered joint loading) and biological (systemic inflammation) components, but the interaction between altered mechanosensation and obesity-related inflammation is unclear. The goal of this proposal is to determine if chondrocyte mechanotransduction via the Piezo ion channels is altered by obesity-associated inflammation. These findings will provide key mechanistic insights into the pathogenesis of osteoarthritis that can be more broadly developed into novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cocaine use disorder increases the risk of HIV infection and HIV infection increases cocaine use, suggesting that these conditions share important reciprocal interactions such that each can exacerbate the other; however, the molecular and cellular bases for cocaine-HIV interactions are poorly understood. Here, we will use cutting- edge single-cell sequencing, single-cell epigenetics, and spatially resolved transcriptomics technologies to characterize transcriptional responses to HIV infection and/or volitional cocaine consumption in a cell type- specific manner in addiction-relevant brain regions of mice, to determine the functional interactions between cocaine use in HIV infection and these cell type-specific transcriptomic profiles. This program of research promises to deliver maps of brain gene expression relevant to cocaine addiction and HIV infection with unprecedented cellular resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The cohesin protein complex bridges together the copies of chromosomes following DNA replication, and compacts chromosomes by forming intramolecular loops and domains. These activities ensure accurate chromosome segregation during cell division, and allow proper DNA repair, gene expression and development. Our work will address how cohesin function is integrated with DNA replication, and how changes in cohesin function within the nucleus are controlled to respond to local or cellular signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because increasing our understanding of continence-regulating neural circuits and bladder-afferent-activity sensing circuits, both of which function critically within the reflex micturition pathway, is ultimately expected to increase understanding of the neural control of bladder function and of how urinary continence is maintained. As such the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH and NIDDK missions that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that may yield improved pharmacologic approaches and interventional strategies, and thereby reduce the burdens of human disability, in not only individuals with brain or spinal cord injury-induced LUTS, but also in aging and a host of neurodegenerative disorders, including Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Palliative care is effective for improving quality of care for nursing home residents with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), but there are few sustainably-designed and tested models for nursing homes and palliative care practices to implement. The UPLIFT-AD (Utilizing Palliative Leaders In Facilities to Transform care for Alzheimer’s Disease) intervention provides both internal capacity-building strategies for nursing homes, as well as external specialty palliative care support, to impact the overall quality of care for residents with ADRD. Impact on quality of care of residents with ADRD near the end of life will be measured, as well as success of the implementation of the intervention and nursing home staff palliative care knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Over activity of the brain renin-angiotensin system (RAS) has major deleterious effects in the development and maintenance of cardiovascular diseases (CVD), particularly in hypertension, which affects 55% of individuals above age 55 in United States. Based on our previous work, ADAM17-mediated shedding is a novel and unexplored mechanism leading to a loss of compensatory ACE2 (angiotensin converting enzyme type 2) activity but also an increase in pro-inflammatory cytokines in hypertension and CVD. Targeting the maturation of ADAM17 will be investigated both in vitro and in vivo in order to determine the overall benefits for the treatment of hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Overall Component Gary S. Stein and Janet L. Stein, Program Directors Building on a record of significant contributions, this highly collaborative program, pursued by a team of scientists and physician-investigators, will explore epigenetic mechanisms that regulate and respond to parameters of genome organization. The Program Project facilitates the conceptual and experimental integration required to advance understanding of functional parameters of epigenetic control that will provide novel insights into breast cancer onset and progression, and provide potential diagnostic and/or therapeutic value.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT 1 | NARRATIVE Breast cancer is a leading cause of death for women in the United States and around the globe. An early event in development of breast cancer is the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) when mammary cells lose their normal structure and function and gain migratory and invasive properties. Project 1 studies will investigate mitotic gene bookmarking—mitotic retention of transcription factors with target genes on chromosomes for transcriptional regulation in progeny cells—as an epigenetic mechanism to maintain normal mammary epithelial cell identity. We will determine whether compromised mitotic bookmarking by the RUNX1 transcription factor results in initiation of EMT and onset of breast cancer. Findings will have far reaching impact on development of new approaches to identify and therapeutically target early events in breast cancer development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aligns with the priority objectives and goals in the HIV National Strategic Plan for the United States: A Roadmap to End the Epidemic 2021–2025, which states that “[…] to successfully achieve the goal of ending the HIV epidemic, issues such as discrimination and systemic racism that contribute to differences in health care quality and access […] and lead to ongoing disparities among racial, ethnic, and sexual and gender minority populations, must be addressed.” By targeting structural racism and discrimination at the organizational (clinic) and systems (provider/staff) levels, we will indirectly impact its downstream manifestations affecting processes and co-morbidities for Black, Indigenous, and People of Color at the individual level. Findings will support the creation of a manual for SRD reduction and racial equity promotion that may be adopted by other RWHAP-funded clinics and facilities serving marginalized groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinal progenitor sheet transplants into rodents with retinal degeneration (RD) have been shown to make nerve connections to the recipient RD retina, and to generate basic visual responses to light in the superior colliculus (SC, a primary target of retinal ganglion cells). However, we still do not know whether and to what degree complex, higher-level visual processing is restored in visual cortex. The objectives of this study are to investigate to what extent rat fetal- and hESC-derived retinal sheet transplants restore higher level visual function and connectivity in the visual cortex in rat models of severe RD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Episodic Ataxia type 2 (EA2) and Familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM1) are neurological disorders resulting from mutations in the CACNA1A gene, which encodes the pore-forming subunit of the P/Q type calcium channel (Cav2.1). Recently, CACNA1A patients presenting primarily with cognitive defects have been described, suggesting a novel cellular mechanism may lead to their symptoms. Here we propose combining a heterologous expression system and an in vivo model system (C. elegans) to delineate the effects of CACNA1A mutations that lead primarily to cognitive symptoms on channel and synaptic function and expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The goal of baroreflex activation therapy (BAT) is to activate the baroreceptor afferents without activating chemoreceptor afferents or motor nerve fibers, however, selectivity between stimulation of these populations is limited in current clinical neural interface designs. In this study, we seek to determine the functional neuroanatomy responsible for the side effects of BAT and to use these data to design and test approaches for more effective BAT neural interfaces. These optimized designs will expand the therapeutic window between baroreceptor activation and limiting off-target effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE  MANCR Mediates Epigenetic Mechanisms for Survival of Advanced Breast Cancer Cancer cells are characterized by altered rearrangements of chromosomal interactions with regulatory factors that contribute to expression of genes promoting tumor growth and metastasis to distal organs—the devastating end stage of breast cancer (BCa). Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) are epigenetic regulators that support the genomic properties of normal and BCa cells through chromatin interactions with their target genes. We have discovered a lncRNA named MANCR that is highly expressed in metastatic BCa cells and in ER+ cells that become resistant to hormone therapy. Because inhibition of MANCR in aggressive BCa cells results in cell death, this proposal is investigating the potential for MANCR to be used as a biomarker for diagnosis in breast cancer biopsies and for therapeutic intervention in preventing primary tumor growth and tumor cells advancing to the metastatic stage. This challenging goal requires a full understanding of the mechanisms by which MANCR supports the survival of aggressive BCa cells related to MANCR-mediated regulation of chromatin interactions.

PHR: Project Narrative: The primary mission of G-RISE at the University of Texas at El Paso is to increase the participation and retention of underrepresented minority (URM) students in biomedical research. The G-RISE program will involve the training of URM Ph.D. trainees from the Departments of Biological Sciences and Chemistry and Biochemistry. The overarching goal of this proposal is to significantly increase the participation of URM doctoral students in these Ph.D. programs over the next 5 years and successfully prepare them for careers in the research workforce using effective, evidence-informed approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study will combine eight data sources on lifecourse social and vascular risk factors for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) to create a large (N=304,171) and diverse (25% Black) synthetic birth cohort (age 0 to 90) for research on ADRD. We will apply rigorous methods to estimate and incorporate corrections for selection forces, including survival, enrollment, attrition, and reverse causation from incipient dementia to risk factor changes. The synthetic cohort will then be used to rigorously estimate how lifecourse social and vascular factors and hypothetical age-specific interventions on those risk factors would affect ADRD risk and ADRD disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Novel functional cell models will be established from normal prostate and different stages of prostate cancer from African American (AA) and European American (EA) men. Biological and genetic analysis of these cultures will be correlated with corresponding xenografts and annotated genomic and patient clinical information. Overall our studies will provide a new and invaluable resource for evaluating the known health disparities of prostate cancer in these patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT This multicenter study of Platelet Expression of FcγRIIa and Arterial Hemodynamics to Predict Recurrent Stroke in Intracranial Atherosclerosis advances recent data on blood flow changes in brain arteries that cause repeated injury and disability. New approaches to blood samples and imaging of mechanical forces around narrowed arteries are used to predict new strokes and silent brain damage over the course of 1 year. The research has direct implications for enhancing precision medicine of stroke, targeting the devastating consequences of the most common cause of stroke and leading cause of disability with vast disparities around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will determine the underlying mechanism(s) for increased cancer risk in individuals with the Ashkenazi-specific p53 hypomorph G334R, using human LCLs and CRISPR knock-in lines as well as a novel mouse model. It will also analyze common activities between three different p53 hypomorphs, and it will test the hypothesis that we can create a gene-signature that is prognostic for other hypomorphs: as such, this research can be used to more accurately predict cancer risk in hundreds of thousands of families in the United States with germline variants in p53.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study uses novel, advanced imaging techniques (i.e. individual-specific Precision Functional Mapping of resting state functional connectivity MRI), along with new computational tools (i.e. Functional Random Forest) to identify atypical brain physiologies related to negative valence symptoms in trans- diagnostic fashion across ADHD, Autism and typical development. This work will utilize new methods to identify brain biomarkers related to important outcomes of interest (i.e. negative valence symptoms) independent of diagnostic category. The findings from this study will advance our knowledge of the neurobiological underpinnings of negative valence symptomatology, ADHD and Autism, and assist in the improved characterization of homogeneous subtypes for future genetic, functional, and therapeutic investigations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) is the leading cause of infectious blindness in the Western world. The objective of the proposed research, which uses a unique HLA transgenic rabbit model of HSV-1 spontaneous reactivation, is to develop an innovative tissue-targeted vaccine designed to bolster the number of functional TG-resident CD8+ TRM cells to reduce virus reactivation from latently infected TG, reducing virus shedding in tears, thus preventing potentiall y blinding recurrent ocular herpetic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Neuronal axons are essential for proper brain wiring and travel long distance from the cell body, which necessitates localized protein synthesis in axons. Although dysfunctional axonal protein synthesis is linked to multiple brain disorders, our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the local protein synthesis in axons is largely limited. This proposal aims to elucidate how axonal protein synthesis is regulated at the molecular level, which will provide essential basic knowledge for developing effective treatment for the brain disorders that are caused by dysregulated axonal protein synthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research in this application is highly relevant to public health because better understanding of the molecular pathogenesis of alcohol-related liver disease is expected to provide potential novel drug targets for the prevention and treatment of this common liver disorder. Specifically, the proposed research in this application will address the underpinning for the strong association of the human PNPLA3 gene with the alcohol-related liver disease. Thus, this project is highly relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to pursuing fundamental knowledge that will help extend healthy life and reduce the burdens of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) has revolutionized cancer treatment but many patients fail to respond to even the most promising immunotherapies. Thus, there persists an urgent need to identify the host factors responsible for the limited efficacy of these otherwise potent immunotherapies in cancer patients. Our study will focus on evaluating contributions of obesity- associated IL-1b as an apex regulator of ICB outcomes in renal cancer, with the goal of obtaining knowledge that will improve treatment outcomes for RCC patients and ultimately save lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This UO1 brings together a unique team of leaders in lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) and tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) to address key unanswered questions with high clinical impact. First, how can factors secreted by LAM cells, identified through analysis of the LAM “secretome” and single cell RNA-sequencing, be used therapeutically and in the development of models of disease progression? Second, what are potential Rapamycin-insensitive pathways leading to LAM cell survival? Third, are there genetic factors associated with the risk of disease progression, including both novel disease modifiers and somatic genetic mosaicism for TSC gene mutations?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: HIV Associated Neurocognitive Disorder (HAND) is one of the most common and clinically important complications of patients living with HIV infection. Unfortunately, the progression of HAND is known to be worsened by drugs such as cocaine. We will explore the role of a novel metabolic intermediate, itaconate, in modulating the immune response to neuroinflammation in the presence of HAND and cocaine.Brain- penetrant itaconate esters with translational therapeutic potential will be employed to resolve neuroinflammation.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative This D43 International Research Training Grant award will: a) Build a training program at the Aga Khan University (AKU), Pakistan; 2) Develop research capacity in infectious and gastrointestinal disease; 3) Emphasize three areas of critical importance to child survival in Pakistan; undernutrition as an enteric infectious disease (i.e., Environmental Enteric Dysfunction – EED), vaccine efficacy, and understanding and reversing the vicious association of the cycle between maternal-child undernutrition and infectious diseases. This work will be executed in collaboration with colleagues from the University of Virginia (UVa). Through this proposal, we aim to produce a cadre of high quality, independent local scientists and build sustainable capacity in pediatric infectious disease and gastroenterology and nutrition research, specifically related to EED and its complications such as vaccine failure, undernutrition and subsequent growth failure in children residing in Pakistan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA), the most common joint disease, leads to severe pain and disability primarily due to altered chondrocyte mechanotransduction and increased joint inflammation. Exome-sequencing studies have identified a mutation that increases risk of developing early on-set OA in COL6A3, a critical component of the chondrocyte’s pericellular matrix (PCM). While it is likely that the effects of this mutation are due to changes in the properties of the PCM, the etiopathogenesis remains unknown. This project will determine the mechanistic link between COL6A3 mutation and OA by investigating how this mutation affects the PCM’s susceptibility to inflammation-induced degradation and chondrocyte catabolism, along with determining alterations in chondrocyte mechanotransduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative In the US, there are ~795,000 cases of stroke annually with 140,000 deaths making stroke the 3rd leading cause of death. While there are therapies for certain types of stroke, for example recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) for acute ischemic stroke, <7% of patients actually receive therapy in part due to the lack of an in vitro diagnostic that can supply information on patient management within the short (<4.5 h) therapeutic time window. In this R01 application, an innovative set of tools will be developed along with the associated biomarkers to realize delivery of an in vitro diagnostic test for stroke. In its final rendition, the test will diagnose stroke in ~31 min and use blood plasma as a source of markers (i.e., RNAs secured from extracellular vesicles, EVs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Cognitive impairment results in decreased ability to complete daily activities such as managing medications, finances, and appointments resulting in care needs. However, one out of four individuals with cognitive impairment lives alone and requires distance caregiving, which is associated with unique challenges compared to in-person caregiving. This study involves developing an integrative stakeholder (care receivers with cognitive impairment and their remote caregivers) co-designed intervention focused on improving use of innovative remote caregiver technology, everyday functioning and independence of care receivers, remote caregiver involvement, and the emotional bond between the dyad.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parental high-fat diets that are rich in omega-6 fatty acids have been shown to increase osteoarthritis severity in adult mouse offspring. I hypothesize that maternal obesity programs offspring osteoarthritis risk by epigenetically programming the cells of the developing knee joint. Here we propose that re-balancing the fatty acid ratio in the presence of maternal obesity will improve pregnancy health and protect the offspring from susceptibility to injury-induced osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will provide a fundamental mechanistic understanding of the photoreceptor cilium and the way disk membranes form to create the outer segment. Numerous retinal degenerations are related to the photoreceptor cilium, so that the studies will also provide a scientific framework for understanding the pathogenesis of these degenerations. Indeed, defects in the photoreceptor cilium are often related to defects in other cilia, in tissues elsewhere in the body, so that the studies may have a wide-ranging benefit to understanding human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This project focused on the mechanisms of development and progression of kidney disease in tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC), an autosomal dominant disease in which renal disease (including cystic disease, which can resemble autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease [ADPKD]) is the second leading cause of death. We hypothesize that CD206-positive macrophages and expression of B7-H3 on TSC2-deficient cells cooperate to promote cell survival and growth in TSC. Targeting these pathways could lead to completely novel therapeutic strategies for children and adults with TSC.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Vision Science Training Program in Oklahoma will recruit and train students pursuing a PhD or MD degree (pre-doctoral trainees) or individuals who already have the PhD or MD degree (postdoctoral trainees) to perform clinical and basic science research in vision science. An outstanding group of investigators spanning several departments and two institutions has interfaced to create a collaborative and highly competitive, yet nurturing environment for our trainees to excel. Training in research laboratories of well-funded, highly productive, and nationally and internationally recognized scientists, along with a strong program in vision science course work, retreats/workshops, clinical experiences, and national/international meetings will provide training critical for future vision scientists in the United States.

PHR: Narrative Our Multidisciplinary Training Program in Digital Mental Health is the first in the nation to co-train postdoctoral fellows with backgrounds in behavioral and psychological sciences and human-computer interaction. The program admits roughly equivalent numbers of fellows from each domain. The program uses a co-training model, in which fellows from both domains work together in research and have mentors from both behavioral and psychological sciences and human computer interaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The visual cycle regenerates key light-sensitive opsin pigments that are essential for vision- these opsins are chemically changed by light exposure, and needs to be rapidly converted back to their initial “dark” state for vision to be sustained in the retina. Impairments of this visual cycle lead to the buildup of toxic molecular intermediates, which kill cells of the retina and potentiate vision loss. In this proposal, I will test if artificially consolidating key visual cycle enzymes into photoreceptor cells can reduce the buildup of these toxic intermediates, exploring their potential in prolonging retinal health and vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Traditional clinical research studies that require travel to a research site for in-person assessments place undue burden on participants with Parkinson’s disease, particularly as the disease advances, and fail to capture the range and complexity of Parkinson’s disease. This project will extend the remote follow-up of two clinical trial cohorts using video visits, remote patient reporting, smartphones, and wrist-worn sensors. By addressing some of the limitations of traditional assessments and evaluating new methods for predicting events like falls and cognitive impairment, we will help to accelerate the development of new treatments for people with Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep disturbances are increasingly recognized as a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and a marker for AD pathology. The sleep-wake cycle affects the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) concentrations of proteins critical to AD pathogenesis, such as Aβ and tau, although other processes (e.g., immune response, synaptic function) are also involved. Dual orexin receptor antagonists (DORAs), such as suvorexant, block the interaction of wake-promoting neuropeptides called orexins and induce sleep. DORAs have been found to decrease the ratio of phosphorylated tau to unphosphorylated tau in humans as well as AD pathology in animal models. In this project, we will test the hypothesis that chronic treatment with suvorexant will decrease CSF and plasma AD biomarkers. Optimal trial design is essential prior to launching a full primary or secondary prevention trial with a maximum chance of success. This study will provide critical information for designing AD secondary prevention trials using suvorexant obtaining data on pharmacokinetics, safety, and chronic effects of suvorexant on multiple soluble AD biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The limited success of clinical interventions in attention- deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can be attributed to poor understanding of the neurobiological mechanisms that contribute to the heterogeneous set of behavioral dysfunctions associated with attention control. The proposed research will investigate how different stages of attention control– selection of sensory input, decision and motor responses are generated in the nervous system. These findings will advance basic understanding of specialized circuit elements of distinct components of top- down attention control leading to better defined diagnosis and more tailored therapeutic interventions of attention disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Surgical performance directly impacts patient outcomes. Prostate cancer, the most common cancer in men, is treated with surgery (robot-assisted radical prostatectomy (RARP)) that can lead to impotence, incontinence, and even death. Reliable means of objectively assessing robotic surgical skills are required. The proposed work will automate technical skills assessment, empowering surgeons with valuable knowledge to minimize prostatectomy surgical risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Downstream processing has remained a major bottleneck for the high-yield production of Lentiviral vectors owing to the intrinsic fragility of the virus that makes it highly susceptible to degradation and/or inactivation by the often harsh elution conditions that are required to desorb the lentivirus from the purification matrix. In this project, Mabswitch will develop LentiSAFE Ligands which are Switchable Affinity Mild-Elution immuno-affinity ligands based on a commercially available anti-lentivirus antibody, with the aim to assess the feasibility to purify functional lentiviral vectors from production supernatants under mild non-destructive conditions. Importantly owing to the universal character of the approach it will serve as a template for purification of many other fragile biotherapeutic reagents where immunoaffinity purification is currently not feasible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal provides a timely response to an environmental accident and chemical exposure in East Palestine, Ohio by initiating community engagement participatory research, providing context with qualitative research approaches, and establishing a baseline biospecimen repository. The utility of novel biomarkers for chemical-wide exposures establishes a new paradox for environmental exposure assessment and health changes. The community engagement establishes a cornerstone for continued and future research determining long-term health impacts, as well as establishing a two-way relationship between community members and health researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  According to the World Health Organization, in 2019 three of the top ten causes of death were respiratory diseases, contributing to over 8 million deaths every year. The proposed research will investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying cell identity in the alveolar epithelium, which will provide crucial insights into how lung tissue properly repairs itself during regeneration, and how this process contributes to fibrosis when it goes awry. The results of these studies will provide key insights into the basic biology of molecular determinants of cellular identity, and open avenues for the development of therapeutics that can improve the lives of the millions of patients living with respiratory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The East Palestine, OH train derailment resulted in a significant spill of volatile organic compounds including the hepatotoxicant vinyl chloride (VC), impacting a community of 5000 people and multiple environmental media. Given the volatile nature of the contaminants and the high level of stress in the community, it is critical to collect and bank time-sensitive environmental media- and biospecimen data, as well as actively characterize and address the growing psychosocial stressors. We propose to use a citizen science approach, engaging the community from design through dissemination.
