IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) is the most common elective surgical procedure in the US with up to 40% of patients reporting some degree of chronic post-surgical pain and 13% of opioid naïve patients continuing use of opioids 1-year after surgery. Insomnia impacts 50% of TKA patients and is increasingly identified as a perioperative risk factor for chronic post-surgical pain and opioid misuse, but it is not known whether treating insomnia perioperatively reduces chronic post-surgical pain and opioid consumption. This randomized controlled trial in patients undergoing TKA, tests the effects of perioperative cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTi) and CBTi + morning bright light treatment on chronic post-surgical pain and opioid consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  On February 3rd, 2023, a train derailment caused a fast-moving contamination event that spread chemicals and their combustion by-products through the surrounding region, impacting multiple communities including the immediate evacuation areas in a one-mile by two-mile area surrounding East Palestine, OH, as well as other communities in Columbiana and Beaver Counties. This project aims to determine the post- accident exposome profiles in the impacted communities by collecting soil, water, and sediment samples and conducting both targeted and non-targeted analyses on the persistent combustion byproducts, as well as performing a model-based comprehensive evaluation of long-term environmental fate, human exposure levels, and corresponding health risks of all the quantified contaminants in the exposome profile. The project is time- sensitive due to its urgent need for sample collections, and the results will provide critically needed data on a broad suite of contaminants that can currently impact human health in the affected regions, empowering key stakeholders to make informed decisions about exposure interventions and remediation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Treating inflammation in deep lung targeting distal airways represents an important avenue for managing pain in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), however, current forms of anti- inflammation inhalation therapies are ineffective due to multiple challenges, including significant side effects, low pulmonary delivery efficiencies, hard-to-use hand-breath coordination user interfaces and the lack of dose monitoring/control systems. This proposal seeks to develop a novel aerosolization platform with the inhalation device prototype combined with the condensation aerosolization atomizer and optimized formulations for the effective, efficient, and dose-controlled pulmonary delivery of anti- inflammatory agents, corticosteroids and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), to the deep lung. This innovative technology platform has the potential to shift the paradigm from traditional inhaler and nebulizer strategies for inflammation and pain management in COPD and other inflammatory respiratory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the clinical benefits of AAV ocular gene therapy vectors, inflammation and toxicity have been reported in some patients, at times resulting in visual deterioration. Prior literature and unpublished data suggest a role for dsRNA-mediated ocular toxicity of AAV vectors, which we will test directly in this proposal. Our data suggest that there are other pathways as well that contribute to toxicity, so we will leverage an unbiased spatial transcriptomics approach (Light-Seq) paired with functional readouts to identify and validate pathways mediating toxicity, expanding our understanding of antiviral responses to AAV in the eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Tooth decay (or dental caries) is a health condition which affects 3.5 billion people annually and which primarily arises from bacterial infection from the biofilms that cover the teeth. VerAvanti intends to develop a clinically safe Optical pH device which introduces an acid-measurement technique that relies on pH-sensitive fluorescence dye as a means to detect, and even predict, locations of future demineralization and caries. This will allow dentists to determine where there is the highest risk of tooth decay, providing feedback to both the dentist and the patient as to the level of enamel health, and guide the dentist in therapeutic actions to prevent future cavities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: We aim to understand the biophysical mechanisms that enable the distinct intrinsic dynamics of dopamine (DA) neuron subpopulations that project to distinct targets by a combination of modeling and in vivo/in vitro experimental strategies. We focus on how intrinsic dynamics differ between defined DA subpopulations, and how those differences shape the integration of synaptic input within the circuit, including newly identified modes of burst generation in DA neurons in vivo: plateau bursting and rebound bursting. A better understanding of the intrinsic properties of distinct subpopulations of dopamine neurons will be invaluable in targeting therapies for disorders with abnormal dopamine signaling, such as substance abuse disorders, Parkinson’s disease and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE The environmental disaster in East Palestine, Ohio following the train derailment and controlled burn in February 2023 caused immediate concerns for air quality and respiratory hazards. Preliminary mobile air sampling data support continued spatial and temporal characterization of volatile organic compound mixtures to identify hot spots and apprise known and unknown chemicals of concern that may volatilize from remediation processes. Continued air sampling coupled with AI-based tools enabling community health assessment and environmental exposure and sensitivity analysis directly inform hyperlocal air quality issues and residential health concerns following an environmental disaster that may exert long-term impacts on community health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE. Several cancer treatment modalities involve the DNA damage response, and furthermore mutations and chromosomal rearrangements are hallmarks of cancer. The 2024 Gordon Research Conference on DNA Damage, Mutation and Cancer will focus on cutting-edge research on defining basic mechanisms of the DNA damage response and leveraging this information for translational research on cancer biomarkers and therapeutics. Thus, this conference will support the mission of the NIH to improve cancer treatments and patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hundreds of thousands of children were confirmed victims of maltreatment in the United States in 2017. In that same year, of the 442,733 children in foster care, approximately one out of 10 were placed in a group home or institution. Out-of-home placement decisions have extremely high stakes for the present and future well-being of these vulnerable children because some placements, and multiple placements, are associated with poor outcomes. The likelihood of success recommendations provided by the proposed “Placement Success Predictor” tool will help placement staff and administrators identify the best placement setting for each child using machine-learning statistics to predict the child’s chances of success in each potential treatment setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis (MS) is one of the most prevalent (~1 million MS patients in the US) and debilitating neurological diseases that affects patients in early adulthood and is the second leading cause of non-traumatic paralysis. In the brain, in MS, hallmark signatures derived from susceptibility weighted MRI (SWI) have provided insight into the biogenesis, evolution, and improved diagnostic specificity of the disease but SWI has even shown utility beyond MS for detecting and quantifying iron accumulation, vascular leakage, microbleeds, and traumatic injury. SWI of the spinal cord is understudied, but if optimized, deployed, and validated in MS, identifying similar hallmarks as seen in the brain would 1) provide insight into MS disease, 2) provide a tool that can be utilized in the spinal cord for other conditions and 3) address a knowledge gap of quality, vetted, SWI for the human spinal cord in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Our lab has published that an agonistic TLR4/MD2 antibody (TLR4-Ab) successfully reverses acute T1D in diabetic mice, activates myeloid derived suppressor cells, and has prolonged endosomal sequestration. However, the mechanism by which TLR4-Ab can reverse T1D is still unclear. Our proposed study will determine the role of TLR4-Ab structure, which downstream TLR4 signaling is important for MDSC differentiation, and begin the translation of this therapy from mice to humans by studying novel human anti- TLR antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Critical maturation steps of mammalian heart development include critical changes in cell structure, metabolism and gene expression of cardiomyocytes take place during the first few weeks after birth all of which are essential for the proper function of the heart. Recently, our lab found Growth differentiation factor 10 (GDF10), also known as Bmp3b, to be an upregulated ligand in postnatal cardiac fibroblasts compared to mature quiescent fibroblasts which suggests GDF10 to have a role in the crosstalk between cardiomyocytes and fibroblasts during neonatal development. This proposal seeks to determine if GDF10 is a key crosstalk ligand between fibroblasts and cardiomyocytes in mammalian in vivo and in vitro postnatal cardiac development and if the loss of this communication impairs maturation of cardiomyocytes by decreasing cardiomyocyte hypertrophy and mitochondrial maturation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Relapse to cocaine use remains a pervasive and difficult-to-treat problem for addressing cocaine use disorder. In particular, the specific neural pathways and network activity underlying the extinction and inhibition of cocaine seeking remain unclear. By elucidating the circuits and network function underlying relapse-like behaviors, this proposal will provide fundamental knowledge regarding cocaine use disorder and lay the groundwork for future studies that can use such knowledge to develop better treatments to prevent relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project focuses on the recovery of solvents from low-concentration waste streams that typically come from Superfund sites. These waste streams contain various solvents such as chlorinated and aromatic solvents, DNAPL, MTBE, tetrahydro furan, and others. Our proposed technology, Microwave Induced Membrane Distillation with Carbon Nanotube Immobilized Membrane or MIMD-CNIM, aims to concentrate the solvent form the waste streams, which then can be used to generate pure solvents for resale or used for other applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE The proposed project will continue the development of prostate cancer cell-targeted ultrasound contrast agents, called nanobubbles, which will be used to guide prostate biopsies under transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) imaging. Successfully developed nanobubbles will depict the pattern of primary tumor within or outside the prostate gland and inform planning for biopsy and surgical approaches. In turn, improved biopsies will lead to increased detection of high grade tumors and tumor staging, and lower morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a severe type of stroke with high case fatality and long-term neurological deficits in surviving patients. This proposal will study the role of cerebral venous circulation in SAH by developing and characterizing a new mouse model of SAH with ipsilateral jugular venous occlusion and explore potential therapeutic strategies to alleviate increased intracranial pressure after SAH with venous occlusion. This study will provide a new perspective on contribution of venous system in SAH pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lack of access to educational and instructional materials is hugely detrimental to the educational attainment of blind and visually impaired (BVI) learners and it negatively affects their quality of life and socio-economic status. This STTR project proposes a novel AI system, Midlinatm, that will provide an end-to-end accessibility pipeline solution for creation of accessible STEM materials and flexibly delivering the accessible content across multiple hardware and software platforms. Successful completion of this project will lead to increased participation of BVI individuals in STEM programs, promote independence for BVI learners and will make educational institutions more inclusive and equitable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The advantage of a multiplexed BioAssay approach is that it permits a rapid, low-cost ‘yes/no’ alert to the presence of any chemicals at concentrations in water sufficient to alter a protein’s physiologic function. The hypothesis is that most water samples will test negative and that a positive test will inform the water agency of any previously unknown or known contaminants. Such a low-cost BioAssay ‘first-pass’ survey can have far- reaching ENVORNMENTAL IMPACT as a comprehensive and affordable identifier of ‘dirty’ water to be prioritized for characterizing the responsible chemical entity and its entry routes into the water supply.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As the number of elderly individuals suffering from dementia in the U.S. continues to significantly increase, solutions are needed to assist these individuals in maintaining functional independence for as long as possible while still safe, and provide caregivers and clinicians ongoing assessment of Activities of Daily Living, in order to improve outcomes from continuous evaluation of patients’ disease progression over time. Leading clinical research on practical interventions shows strong benefits from patients’ use of compensatory memory techniques to report ADL and other healthy behaviors performed, and these interventions, along with appropriate responses and adjustments to caregiving, have helped prevent or delay dementia onset and preserve functional abilities. The proposed research addresses an important unmet need to continuously monitor, and accurately and automatically validate whether expected ADL were performed as expected, without the need for direct caregiver observation, which will provide remotely-located caregivers, physicians, and cognitive rehabilitation therapists with verified and reliable information on whether these important activities were achieved or had lapsed, and promoting informed decisions on diagnosis, interventions, and level of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Costs of care and concerns about affordability are among the most prominent barriers to mental health services, even among Americans with commercial health insurance. The state of New Mexico passed a law (SB 317) to eliminate cost-sharing for mental health and substance use disorder services in commercial insurance, in order to improve access to services. The proposed study will use qualitative and quantitative methods to assess how this law is affecting the delivery of mental health services from patient and provider perspectives, and how it is affecting patterns of mental health services use and quality of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endocarditis is a life-threatening disease and a significant economic burden due to prolonged intensive treatment. Early identification of the microbial infection is crucial to improving outcomes, but current standards relying on blood cultures are slow and often yield false-negative results. This prevents the administration of evidence-based antimicrobials precisely when they are maximally beneficial. The efforts described in this Phase IIB program will build upon the success demonstrated in our Phase I and Phase II and will advance the maturity of a novel, fully automated test capable of identifying and characterizing these infections directly from patient blood in only a few hours. Success in this effort will result in a critically needed diagnostic, ready for manufacturing scale up as required for FDA trials and market launch.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Family caregivers to patients with severe acute brain injury (SABI) are at risk for chronic emotional distress, yet no tailored, efficacious interventions exist to promote their mental and physical wellbeing. The proposed study aims to lay the foundation for the development of a mind-body peer support intervention for SABI caregivers through conducting preliminary quantitative and qualitative work, and adapting existing interventions with stakeholder-engaged methods. Future work can evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of the proposed intervention, and if successful, the proposed mind- body peer support intervention has wide-reaching potential to be implemented in diverse critical care settings and improve the long-term wellbeing of SABI caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The enzymes that add, remove, and bind ADP-ribose (ADPr) on histones are emerging as high value drug targets, given the strong connection between this class of post-translational modifications and multiple pathologies. However, the ability to perform the robust biochemical and genomic mapping studies of histone ADPr required to bolster basic and drug development research has been undermined by a lack of defined, physiological substrates and assays. Here, EpiCypher will develop a first-in-kind molecular toolbox to advance the study of ADPr signaling for drug discovery research and inhibitor development.

PHR: Project Narrative Chagas disease is a parasitic infection primarily in Latin America caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. Existing drugs for Chagas disease are inadequate because of severe side effects, lengthy treatment regimens, and poor efficacy. The proposed research aims to bring forward new drug treatments that meet modern-day standards for the millions of infected people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Two FDA approved treatments for large vessel occlusion acute ischemic stroke (AIS) to dissolve the clot by recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA thrombolysis) or extract the clot (endovascular arterial thrombectomy-EAT) require a ratio (1.8) of ischemic penumbra (tissue near death) /core (dead tissue) volumes plus two measures of stroke severity to qualify for intervention. Only 25% of the annual 800,000 first ever AIS in the US and 16.9M globally would qualify for treatment; Lamiflo™ uniquely enhances flow by altering the physical dynamics of blood and red blood cell (RBC) flow, not pharmacologically. By reducing the ischemic penumbra and core after onset of AIS, Lamiflo™ will increase the number of patients qualifying for tPA thrombolysis and EAT intervention and improved neurologic recovery without increasing hemorrhagic transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: There is a considerable body of evidence that protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) activity is reduced in Alzheimer’s Disease and other neurodegenerative conditions and this underlies multiple factors contributing to pathology. This SBIR Phase 2 proposal is directed at initial pre-clinical steps in development of a lead compound, ATUX-5800, as a novel, disease modifying, Alzheimer’s Disease therapeutic. The lead compounds and back-ups are compact, drug-like, structures that directly target PP2A holoenzymes in the brain, thus simultaneously addressing multiple drivers of AD pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement)  In the proposed project, we will use a novel nano formulation of curcuminoids to mitigate neuroinflammation and attenuate neurological diseases with emphasis on Alzheimer’s disease (AD). In our approach, curcuminoids, known for their potent anti-inflammatory activity and activities inhibiting early brain markers of AD including neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaque formation, will be sequestered in exosomes (natural nanoparticles), isolated from standardized bovine colostrum powder, to increase bioavailability. The exosomes will be decorated with folic acid whose receptors are expressed in high levels in the brain, to target the brain sub tissues such as cortex and hippocampus, and the formulation is delivered by a novel trans-spinal (t.s.) topical route for efficient brain delivery and the efficacy assessed using transgenic mouse model of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Because the vast majority of people (93%) who experience alcohol use disorder do not attend in-person, abstinence-based treatment, mobile harm reduction treatment for alcohol use disorder (mHaRT-A) – which does not require abstinence or in-person treatment attendance – is well-positioned to vastly improve intervention access. This project’s aims are to develop and initially test an accessible, low-barrier mHealth application to reduce alcohol-related harm and improve quality of life for individuals in this high-morbidity and high-cost population. In the longer term, mHaRT-A has the potential to make a public health impact through its broader dissemination, both directly to consumers as a standalone product and to larger healthcare systems for use as an adjunct to clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RBC propensity to sickle under hypoxia is a critical feature of SCD; however, there are no easy-to-use methods available to clinicians or pharmacology researchers to assess it. Functional Fluidics is providing the first rapid and convenient assay, to be translated into a small footprint, stand-alone system, to assess hypoxia induced RBC sickling. Our long-term goal is a diagnostic device for assessing sickle patient conditions and predicting treatment efficacy at point-of-care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The need for moral injury interventions is increasingly being recognized as a domain in Veteran care that must be addressed. Consequences of exposure to morally injurious events include risk for suicide, substance abuse, and refractory symptoms of PTSD and depression.1-5 Exposure to morally injurious events is also highly prevalent among Veterans.8-9 Thus, interventions addressing moral injury are crucial to helping Veterans build meaningful lives. Psychotherapies explicitly targeting moral injury and functional recovery associated with this construct are limited in VHA. The proposed study serves as a first step in addressing this gap in the literature through the development of a recovery-oriented, evidence-based treatment approach for moral injury among warzone Veterans who report functional impairments related to moral emotions. The proposed pilot study will evaluate the acceptability of this intervention and the feasibility of the design for a future study to test the treatment's capacity to improve patients' functioning.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Insomnia is a common condition in Veterans, with prevalence rates as high as 53% among treatment-seeking Veterans. Chronic untreated insomnia is associated with increased risk for functional impairment, psychiatric illness, suicidal ideation, unhealthy lifestyles, and decreased quality of life. Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is recognized as the first-line treatment for insomnia. Despite its proven efficacy, CBT-I is not always readily provided and/or accessible to Veterans. To address these limitations, behavioral sleep medicine specialists have endeavored to streamline CBT-I through development of time-shortened variations of CBT-I. Although these modifications show promise for advancing care and access, studies comparing brief treatments to standard CBT-I have yet to be performed. This investigation will therefore compare a 4-session brief CBT-I to VA standard 6-session CBT-I to evaluate whether a brief intervention can provide comparable benefits to sleep, functional, and psychiatric outcomes in Veterans with insomnia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Over 500,000 head and neck cancer patients receive therapeutic radiation each year, resulting in irreversible damage to the salivary glands, salivary hypofunction, and subsequent xerostomia (dry mouth syndrome). As current strategies to mitigate xerostomia fail to address the underlying mechanism of dysfunction, new therapies that long-term repair the injured gland are necessary to address this unmet clinical need. Given that Sox10 is involved in SG epithelial stem/progenitor cell self-renewal and differentiation processes, here we aim to determine whether Sox10 can induce plasticity in irradiated salivary gland ductal cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative While our understanding of aging has greatly increased over the past few decades, treatments for and understanding of the pathogenesis of age-related diseases remain elusive. Recently, the ability of the lysosome (vacuole in yeast) to compartmentalize amino acids, particularly cysteine, was linked to mitochondrial dysfunction during the process of aging. In this study, we will investigate systems that collaborate with the vacuole to maintain cellular homeostasis during aging and also investigate this in a yeast model for Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This study will establish the cause-and-effect relationship of local muscle fatigability on walking stability through a combination of sophisticated motion capture and electromyographic time-frequency analyses with an innovative suite of walking balance perturbations designed to emulate real-world balance challenges. Through our approach, we will address several gaps that are currently impeding the field to have an immediate impact on our understanding of the directional dependence of fatigability on walking stability and on the influence of age and falls risk on the effects of local muscle fatigability. This work will also serve as a benchmark for underlying changes, in later research, neurological injury and neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Maintenance of neuronal protein degradation through the endosomal-lysosomal pathway is essential for post-mitotic, aging neurons. Lysosomal membrane permeabilization (LMP) occurs commonly in aging related pathologies of the nervous system, but the cellular responses to disruption of the neuronal proteome during LMP are poorly understood. Identifying compensatory endosomal responses to LMP may allow us to develop novel therapeutic approaches for a vast number of neurological disorders that both affect the aging population and exhibit LMP pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: Although divergent transcription is estimated to occur at over 70% of active promoter regions throughout eukaryotes, the mechanism by which these divergent transcripts are generated remain a mystery. Using a bidirectional promoter composed of endogenous upstream activating sequence architecture and flanking core promoters, I observed that two preinitiation complexes (PICs) can dimerize in vitro via the coactivator Mediator complex. This proposal will determine the structure of the dimerized Mediator-PIC, a novel transcription complex, and its role in divergent transcription.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial antibiotic persistence contributes to treatment failure, relapsing infections and selection of antibiotic resistance, yet mechanisms of persistence remain ill defined. In this project I will characterize properties and vulnerabilities of Salmonella persisters during infection to identify potential targets for their elimination. I will focus on the recent observation that chromosome accumulation confers a survival advantage to persisters and I aim at deciphering the benefit of such new genetic material.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative Two million people in the U.S. are diagnosed annually with life-threatening infections caused by antibiotic resistant bacteria that are responsible for 35,000 deaths each year with an economic impact estimated to be as much as $20 billion a year in direct healthcare costs. Due to the spread of antibiotic resistance, very few drugs remain that can treat these infections. The objectives of this Epicenter are to develop novel interventions that will prevent the colonization and spread of antibiotic resistant (AR) bacteria that cause hospital acquired infections (HAI), and to develop diagnostics and interventions to combat the colonization by the rapidly emerging fungal pathogen Candida auris.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE While the vascular system in the retina is one of the most studied vascular beds, there remain significant knowledge gaps in our understanding of the processes that lead to retinal vascular dysfunction. However, there are no in vitro perfusable models of the iBRB that can be used to assess pathological conditions. Here we propose establishing 3D human iBRB models, including a post‑capillary venule (~100 µm diameter) model and a capillary plexus (<50 µm diameter), and incorporate additional functionalities, including oxygen tension and matrix mechanics to create models with physiological characteristics as healthy functioning tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Streptococcus pneumoniae is an important pathogen carried asymptomatically by a large proportion of the population that exhibits a transition to virulence characterized by a complex gene expression program. Small non-coding RNAs (sRNAs) are often critical mediators of virulence in bacteria, but are under characterized in S. pneumoniae. This research will identify mRNA targets for sRNAs necessary for virulence to illuminate the regulatory pathways leading to virulence.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) on Notch Signaling in Development, Regeneration and Disease is to provide a stimulating, international and cross disciplinary forum for the dissemination and discussion of new unpublished research, concepts, and therapeutic opportunities at the forefront of Notch-related biology. The Notch signaling pathway is a central mediator of short- range inter-cellular communication in multicellular organisms, and alterations of Notch activity cause or contribute to a growing list of human developmental syndromes, adult onset diseases and cancers, expanding the interest in this pathway well beyond the boundaries of basic developmental and cell biology and into the areas of stem cell biology, cancer biology and therapeutics. Building on past success of the conference, the 6th Notch GRC/GRS will bring together a diverse community of scientists from academia, biotech and the pharmaceutical industry working in multiple model organisms and organ systems, including researchers focused on human disease, to create a stimulating scientific environment where cutting edge technologies, ideas and discoveries can be exchanged and where students and research fellows will gain exposure to leaders in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cutting-edge methods provide a new means of using genetics to understand causal relationships between biomarkers and disease but perform poorly in marginalized populations especially burdened by complex diseases. We will leverage a polygenic risk score to understand the validity of a genetic causal inference method in diverse populations, incorporating possible ancestry, clinical, and environmental interactions. This work will create a framework that extends genetic tools to better understand what causes disease across populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the integrity of the corneal epithelium is frequently compromised as the result of trauma, surgery, side-effects of anti-cancer drugs, and as a complication of multiple diseases including diabetes and autoimmune disorders. Identifying the molecular mechanisms that regulate the integrity of the corneal epithelium is the first step in developing therapies that promote the homeostasis and regeneration of the corneal epithelium before vision becomes jeopardized. This project is relevant to the NEI’s mission to support research with respect to the molecular basis of visual function and the preservation of sight.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and its associated cutaneous lupus lesions remain difficult to treat and are driven by dysregulation of type I interferon production. This project will uncover novel mechanisms that regulate the production of type I IFNs in the skin, the interactions between skin-derived interferons, and how therapies that target type I IFNS impact the changes in skin biology in SLE patients to develop new preventative and therapeutic strategies for this devastating disease. Discoveries made through this research are directly relevant to the NIH's mission to foster fundamental discoveries and their applications to protect and improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ongoing epidemic of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), particularly in men who have sex with men, is worsening as the fear of HIV and the acceptance/use of barrier methods decreases. STI diagnostics are the critical gateway to treatment and technology for point-of-care (POC) STI tests that can be accessed at local clinics and performed by “lay health workers” during the patient visit are needed to address ongoing STI socioeconomic health disparities. This project overcomes current limitations using a simple (3 step), cheap, and fast, assay for ultra-sensitive detection of STIs at the POC and efforts include first optimizing the assay to enable detection of even the lowest level infections and then testing performance using clinical samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A significant contributor to the unsettling fact that cardiovascular diseases kill almost twice as many Black adults compared to White adults in the United States, is the lack of equitable population representation in genomic studies. I propose to address this significant shortcoming by using an African ancestry-focused approach to identify genetic variations associated with heart, lung, blood, and sleep phenotypes and elucidate how both individual and local ancestry contributes to disease risk. This work has the potential to expand our knowledge of genetic risk in a historically under-represented population and advance the development of effective and equitable precision medicine technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Processing visual information is a key nervous system function for many animals. However, understanding the neural computations that underlie visual processing has been difficult due to large variability in these circuits. The aim of this proposal is to leverage modern electrophysiological and computational approaches to map and probe the distributed brain network underlying visual processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) is the most common bacterial sexually transmitted infection in the US; consequences of untreated CT include pelvic inflammatory disease, ectopic pregnancy, and increased healthcare costs. This proposal will assess how the cervicovaginal metagenome and immune response contribute to rapid spontaneous CT clearance (without antibiotics) because CT clearance likely provides the greatest protection against reproductive sequelae when it happens early in infection. Findings from this work will identify potential therapeutic targets to promote rapid CT clearance, which can ultimately be translated into antibiotic-sparing CT treatments, and inform CT vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can affect any part of the eye, in the U.S. alone, 30,000 people suffer from recurrent corneal HSV-1 involvement – Herpes simplex keratitis (HSK). In addition to risk of severe vision loss, HSK impacts quality of life and poses a significant economic burden. A 2003 study estimated a cost of 17.7 million dollars annually due to HSK. Page 1 of 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food insecurity—inadequate access to enough food for every person in a household to live an active, healthy life—threatens critical early childhood growth and can put children at risk for poor short- and long-term health. Understanding how factors at multiple levels (household, neighborhood, policy) influence how food insecurity affects child weight over time is important for developing evidence-based policies and interventions to reduce food insecurity and reduce disparities in child weight outcomes. The goal of the proposed mixed-methods study is to inform implementation of WIC and other food assistance policies by using focus groups and statistical analyses to examine how household food insecurity is associated with weight trajectories among young children, and how this association is modified by neighborhood environment and public food assistance programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A new blood test (miR371) appears to be highly accurate in predicting active germ cell tumors. Current clinical tests such as CT scans and standard tumor markers appear less accurate than miR371 and can lead to misdiagnosis of active germ cell malignancy, overtreatment and unnecessary treatments and significant expense and toxicity. We are proposing a clinical investigation to evaluate the ability of miR371 testing compared to or integrated with CT scan images to reduce, replace or potentiate the use of the current clinical tools and reduce the exposure of patients to unnecessary and somewhat toxic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative - Relevance to Public Health Influenza virus infection represents a major cause of morbidity and mortality. Despite currently available vaccines and antiviral drugs which have a limited impact, there is still an urgent need for developing novel therapeutic agent to improve innate immunity based on full understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying tight regulation of innate immunity in influenza virus infection. The currently proposed studies will lead to the identification of novel therapeutic targets and development of new therapeutic strategy for influenza virus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the LSUHSC-NO PREP is to prepare individuals from backgrounds underrepresented in the biomedical sciences, who have recently completed their baccalaureate science degrees, for successful enrollment, retention, and completion of a Ph.D. training program. We aim to enhance the diversity of the biomedical research workforce by preparing PREP Scholars for the rigors and challenges of a biomedical doctoral degree program so that they will successfully obtain a Ph.D. degree and contribute their expertise to the biomedical scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the effectiveness of CAR T therapy for patients with refractory B cell malignancies, approximately 50% of patients relapse within one year of treatment. A common cause of relapse is the emergence of CAR-resistant leukemias. Our proposal develops two key models for studying mechanisms of relapse following cellular therapy for leukemia and identifies avenues for improving durability of remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The current standard treatment for the severe inflammatory condition affecting the kidney known as crescentic glomerulonephritis involves the use of systemic immunosuppressive agents, which cause toxicity that can result in death. This proposal seeks to understand better how the immune system becomes activated in the kidney-draining lymph node during crescentic glomerulonephritis in mice and to develop a novel treatment platform consisting of a nanoparticle that delivers immunosuppressive agents selectively to the kidney-draining lymph node. We predict that delivering immunosuppressive agents selectively to the kidney-draining lymph node with this nanoparticle will treat crescentic glomerulonephritis more effectively as well as reduce the toxicity caused by conventional systemic therapy, a finding that could provide a springboard for the use of this nanoparticle in future clinical trials involving human patients. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NIEHS recognizes that promoting healthier lives involves discovering how the environment affects people. It is essential that the workers making these discoveries represent everyone, including individuals who are traditionally underrepresented. The SURE-EH program will provide research experience and educational opportunities in the environmental health sciences to University of Washington undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because cervical cancer is a common cause of cancer amongst women and treatment decisions are based heavily on accurate and early imaging. By developing a technique that evaluates response to treatment earlier than the current standard of care, we will decrease morbidity and mortality by treating cervical cancer at an earlier time point, preventing further progression of disease. The development of new biomedical imaging techniques to fundamentally improve the detection and treatment of disease is directly relevant to one of the key missions of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The prevalence of obesity and diabetes mellitus in the United States places an enormous national burden on the health care system. The proposed studies address a critical need to understand the signal-specific regulatory strategies used to promote growth and control insulin secretion in the islet beta-cell population. The results of this project will expedite the development of novel and highly specific salutary approaches to improve metabolic health and reduce health care costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Knowledge of molecular status for a variety of markers in gliomas has moved to the forefront in clinical decision- making. This requires direct tissue sampling either from an invasive brain biopsy or open surgical resection. In this Bioengineering Research Grant proposal in response to PAR-19-158, we will develop and validate a non- invasive method to determine a panel of the most critical molecular markers (IDH, 1p/19q and MGMT methylation) with near tissue-level accuracies using routine T2-weighted (T2w) MR images and deep learning algorithms to significantly reduce and in many cases eliminate the need for stereotactic biopsy in glioma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Many genera of viruses are comprised of different species, each continually evolving new exterior protein landscapes that can make broad spectrum countermeasure development very challenging. We have developed novel nanobodies that target interior proteins which are less prone to evolution and enable uniform binding of all species of the genus Ebolavirus. Our goal is to explore the antiviral potential of these nanobodies in in vitro tissue culture systems to determine if they can inhibit a broad spectrum of ebolaviruses that have emerged over the past 45 years.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE  Monogenic neurodevelopmental disorders like Rett syndrome appear to be ideal candidates for gene therapy; however, targeting the causative gene (methyl-CpG binding protein 2, MeCP2) itself with traditional gene replacement strategies is complicated by a stringent requirement for protein dosage. Here we propose that the administration of locked nucleic acid (LNA)-modified antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) designed to outcompete endogenous repressive-miRNA for regulation of the MeCP2 3’untranslated region is a viable therapeutic approach for RTT patients with missense or late-truncating mutations. Our preliminary support this theory, as mir-22, mir-132, and mir-483 site-blocking ASOs increase MeCP2 expression in a dose-dependent manner which is capped at subtoxic levels by the relatively modest contribution of each endogenous miRNA to MeCP2 regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the past three decades, the incidence of early onset colorectal cancer (EOCRC) has been steadily increasing. Genetic analysis of patient-derived colonic tissues and tumors indicate that deregulation of the Wnt/ß- catenin signaling pathway may contribute to colorectal carcinogenesis in this patient population. Work in this proposal will define critical downstream targets of aberrant Wnt/ß-catenin signaling and identify novel pathway interactors that drive EOCRC. This research is needed to support targeting this pathway, or genes whose expression it regulates, to improve patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Contusion expansion is a common and devastating secondary injury after traumatic brain injury, causing death, extensive long-term disability, and a significant health-economic burden to society; yet there is no cure. Current guideline-based care is reactive and non-specific- it neither prevents nor limits contusion expansion and struggles to mitigate the life threatening consequences. This study focuses on key actionable pathways and will identify biomarkers and precise therapeutic targets to predict and prevent contusion expansion, thus directly advancing the NINDS mission to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Progress in the use of epitopes for cancer immunology and immunotherapy is hampered by a disconnect in information technology, which segregates investigators from the data and tools needed to appropriately conduct their research. Development of a Cancer Epitope Database and Analysis Resource will overcome this issue by harmonizing and centralizing the capture of cancer epitope data, and by using these data to establish and evaluate epitope analysis and prediction tools that will be made freely available to the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will adapt methods from our current SEPA project to establish DNA barcoding for use in informal settings. Our objective is to equip visitors to science centers and nature preserves and members of community conservation groups to inventory species in local habitats. These citizen scientists will contribute new information to global biodiversity databases and improve range maps that show how species are responding to environmental change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Schistosomiasis-induced pulmonary hypertension (Sch-PH) is a major cause of pulmonary arterial hypertension worldwide, a group of incurable illness marked by progressive narrowing of the blood vessels in the lungs and eventual death due to right heart failure. Despite the high prevalence of the disease, the limited understanding of how Sch-PH develops precludes the establishment of effective treatment. This proposal aims to examine the potential role of glucose metabolism in generating the pathologic changes of Sch-PH, with the ultimate goal of identifying metabolism-modulating therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is one of the most important public health challenges of our time, with women disproportionately impacted. We will uniquely examine whether mitochondrial function plays a critical role in understanding sex differences in memory circuitry function and the early emergence of AD-related pathology. This study will advance our knowledge on the long-term implications for the co-occurrence of brain and metabolic disorders, and the sex differences therein, and highlight potential mechanistic targets for therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative ROADmAP incorporates evidence- and theory-based cognitive-behavioral change strategies, including features from the Diabetes Prevention Program, to decrease overweight/obesity rates among taxi/for-hire vehicle (FHV) drivers. It is innovative in 3 key respects: 1) It is the first study to utilize the Multiphase Optimization Strategy to develop an optimized, scalable lifestyle intervention specifically adapted for drivers, including in a virtual environment; 2) It will be implemented in community-embedded settings to address barriers to access experienced by underserved low socioeconomic status, mulitlingual driver communities, reaching drivers who may not otherwise be reached by the traditional health care system; 3) It is the first to use implementation science to facilitate more rapid translation of an effective lifestyle intervention to a multilingual format, in the taxi/FHV driver environment, with tremendous dissemination potential for gig economy essential workers. If successful, ROADmAP can potentially lead to broad implementation among large and growing taxi/FHV and other driver populations (e.g. bus, truck drivers) throughout the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  RAS proteins (KRAS, NRAS, and HRAS) are the most extensively studied set of mutationally activated oncogenes. Yet we do not completely understand the structural impact of RAS mutations in cancer. In this proposal, I will create and analyze a unified RAS structural classification and nomenclature to compare the impact of oncogenic mutations on KRAS, HRAS, and NRAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Doctors use prediction models to help them prevent heart attacks and stroke in healthy adults. However, these models do not apply to everyone, including transgender and cisgender adults using hormone therapy. This project aims to provide new methods of predicting and preventing heart attacks and strokes in these unique groups of people.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To meet the need for increasing research ethics capacity in Malaysia and Southeast Asia, in partnership with collaborators from the Berman Institute of Bioethics at Johns Hopkins University, this initiative aims to enhance the leading-edge Master of Health Research Ethics (MOHRE) program at Universiti Malaya (UM). Program enhancements will include increasing program flexibility to increase enrolment of working individuals positioned to make meaningful contributions to research ethics, strengthening the program by using a newly articulated competency framework, and implementing a robust UM faculty development program. By the end of the project period, the MOHRE program will be more sustainable and be positioned to help meet local and regional needs in research ethics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study identifies the impact of adverse community-level policing (CLP) exposure on Alzheimer’s disease related dementia (ADRD) racial disparities. This proposal leverages data collected from the Health and Retirement Study to explore the correlations between life course adverse CLP exposure with incident dementia, cognitive decline, accelerated aging, and poor psychological health in Black and Latinx/a/o older adults. Results from this study may illuminate a modifiable political factor that could be targeted for intervention to reduce disproportionate incidence of ADRD in historically marginalized communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During cell division, called mitosis, a critical step for maintaining healthy living cells is segregation of the replicated chromosomes to two daughter cells, which is mediated by a dynamic structure called the mitotic spindle. We do not fully understand how the spindle forms, or how it adjusts its size and shape in different cell types. Investigating this process is important, since errors in spindle function can lead to cancer and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Lung squamous carcinomas (LUSC) are a leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the U.S., however they are highly idiosyncratic and rarely driven by solitary actionable pathways. We have uncovered a previously unappreciated CDR1as/CDR1 axis that regulates LUSC metastasis and is highly associated with patient survival. This proposal seeks to uncover the fundamental mechanisms responsible for how CDR1 regulates LUSC metastasis through Golgi function, vesicular trafficking and metastasis, and to evaluate the biologic and therapeutic implications of targeting the CDR1as structure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric cardiomyopathies (PCM) are rare but devastating disorders of the heart muscle with most children diagnosed before one year of age and limited treatment options often culminating in childhood death. The genetic underpinnings remain poorly understood and are complicated by patients carrying multiple genetic variants and by different variants in the same genes causing different types of PCM. Here we develop bioinformatic tools to prioritize the recently identified 343 PCM candidate genetic variants for modeling in the fly (Drosophila), followed by efficient “gene-level” and “variant-level” functional validation in the fly heart, to provide the much-needed in vivo data to confirm the causality of the candidate variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural diseases diagnosed before birth, such as diaphragmatic hernia, cause significant morbidity in children due to tissue damage and inadequate organ development. Fetal therapy, to allow more normal organ development, through invasive procedures has demonstrated some benefit but more minimally invasive procedures are needed to allow for treatment earlier in pregnancy to further improve organ development. Synthetic nanoparticles, made from biocompatible polymers, serve as a platform to treat structural fetal diseases in a minimally invasive fashion and we will study these particles with the intent to treat fetal lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria remains one of the major world public health problems, causing about 200 million clinical cases annually and claims nearly half a million lives, mostly children under the age of five and pregnant women. Both treating and preventing the malaria infection with novel drugs that kill the parasite in new ways is highly desirable and challenging. This project investigates a natural product inspired novel antimalarial prodiginine chemotype that is potent across the parasite life cycle with potential to prevent relapsing infections and possible novel mode(s) of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need for effective nutritional strategies to limit energy intake and regulate appetite, and one such strategy that has gained increasing attention is time restricted eating (TRE), or restriction of food intake to a specific window of time during the day. The goal of this project is to evaluate the effects of a 52-week behavioral weight loss program using early vs. late timing of TRE as compared to standard of care (daily caloric restriction) on body weight and cardiometabolic outcomes. This project may result in changes in dietary recommendations and is therefore of significant benefit to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Health Relevance HIV-1 infection to non-dividing myeloid cells, such as macrophages and microglia (brain macrophages), contributes to HIV-1 pathogenesis. Particularly, HIV-1 infected macrophages serve as a key long-living viral reservoir that persistently produces viral progenies even during the course of intense antiviral therapy. This application attempts to elucidate novel regulatory circuits of a host defense mechanism executed by a host restriction factor, SAMHD1, that kinetically delays multiple steps of HIV life cycle in nondividing viral target cell types, ultimately providing new anti-HIV target strategies that effectively suppress HIV-1 life cycle in non- dividing myeloid cells that contribute to HIV-1 persistence and neuro-AIDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  We need to enhance our collective ability to reduce the overall immense burden of stroke on society, and its disproportionate toll on key sociodemographic groups. The goal of this one-day annual symposium over 4 years is to partner with the pre-eminent national stroke society to encourage more research into disparities around stroke, by providing leading edge science aimed particularly at scientists from various professional and scientific disciplines, with an interest in disparities research. Special efforts will be made to sponsor some early career scientists and invite under-represented in medicine minority and women scholars to participate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Congenital defects of the outflow tract are clinically serious but poorly understood. This project applies innovative experimental technology and computational analysis to elaborate novel molecular switches that govern how mechanical forces drive endocardial-mesenchymal collective signaling in the outflow tract by potentiating growth vs. maturation programs in the outflow tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Genome Wide Association Studies (GWAS) have identified over 100 loci contributing to the risk of Atrial Fibrillation, however, the molecular mechanisms underlying their genetic implication remains unknown. We propose to apply a novel single cell genomic and analytic approach to identify causative risk variants and their target genes, analyze the molecular basis of the risk loci, and interrogate several risk SNPs in detailed molecular, genomic, and electrophysiological studies in human cardiomyocytes. The results will generate biological insight from genetic implication, delivering a greater understanding of the genetic basis of Atrial Fibrillation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Targeting of the EGF receptor with therapeutic antibodies like cetuximab (and panitumumab) is clinically used in advanced colorectal cancer, however, cetuximab resistance is nearly universal. Our work with three dimensional cultures of CRC cell lines and normal colon and patient-derived tumor xenografts and organoids identified two new modes of resistance to cetuximab that was driven by activation of multiple receptor tyrosine kinases. In this application we propose to identify, characterize, and prevent/overcome these and new resistance mechanisms in CRC with the aim to improving patient selection and efficacy of personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is known to be primarily triggered by food antigens, the mechanisms underlying this food-induced inflammation remain unknown. We expect to demonstrate that IgG4 forms immune complexes with food and stimulates local immune cells in EoE, thereby contributing to food-induced inflammation in this disease. Characterizing the role of IgG4 in EoE could lead to a paradigm shift in our understanding of this condition, as well as novel diagnostic and treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor (EGFR) and Hippo signaling play critical roles in the development of many types of cancers. The current proposal will explore a novel function of a phosphoinositide kinase in the control of EGFR and Hippo signaling, and will test its role in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) progression. The control of this kinase will lead to novel strategies to treat HNSCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: Abnormal white patches of tissue in the mouth, or leukoplakias, are common and may become cancerous over time. This project aims to understand what events make these patches arise, and if we can predict which ones might go on to become cancer. This will permit us better select which people need treatment, as well as possible treatment strategies for these white patches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Program Narrative Cancers remain the second leading cause of death in the United States with head and neck carcinomas being the sixth most common cancer worldwide. Within this group, mucoepidermoid carcinomas (MEC) are the most common type of malignant salivary gland cancer and the CRTC1/MAML2 (C1/M2) gene fusion arising from a t(11;19)(q21;p13.1) chromosomal translocation is pathognomonic for MEC, and drives aberrant co-activation of the transcription factors CREB and MYC. Using a combination of validated xenograft and genetically engineered mouse models of C1/M2-driven MEC, we will apply our cutting-edge optical reporter technology to systematically and comprehensively define the role of CREB and MYC in coordinating transcriptional programs that drive development and maintenance of salivary MEC, which will enhance our understanding of this disease process and provide an opportunity to develop targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the mechanisms by which cells transport and position intracellular organelles is crucial for defining normal physiology and a wide range of diseases. Our research team is taking an integrative approach to understand this problem, with the goal of achieving an atomic- to-cellular-to-in vivo level understanding of the mechanisms of organelle transport. The roles of spatial organization and dynamic assembly of filaments, mechanical forces, motor activity, and other regulatory elements will be investigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Nonhomologous end joining is a pathway for repair of chromosomal DNA double strand breaks, and determines the effectiveness of many cancer therapies, including ionizing radiation. This repair pathway surprisingly often repairs our DNA with elements of RNA; here we propose to investigate how RNA in our DNA chromosomes is then removed, with a focus on therapeutically relevant circumstances. We will additionally work to better understand how clinically employed inhibitors of nonhomologous end joining function in cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) currently affects 1 in 4 individuals in the USA, and is a leading cause of liver transplantation; no FDA-approved treatments are available. Aberrant transcriptional control of gene expression constitutes a central aspect of the pathophysiology of NAFLD. Using state-of-the-art high- throughput technologies, this research will generate key information on a fundamental mechanism of transcription control, and will facilitate the future development of drug therapies directed at correcting dysregulated gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent theories suggest that failures of self-control, which are a fundamental part of human behavior and are often triggered by exposure to stress, may emerge because self-control is perceived to be effortful (or ‘costly’) to individuals. Here, we use behavioral, computational and neuroimaging approaches to quantify these self- control costs, identify how they are represented in the brain and examine how they change under different forms of stressor exposure. Identifying behavioral metrics and neural mechanisms for the cost of self-control may offer a more precise approach for predicting when and how stress will compromise self-control processes and further our understanding of self-control failure, which is a transdiagnostic feature across a range of psychiatric disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extracellular vesicles (EVs) show great promise as next-generation targeted drug delivery systems, but their complexity and heterogeneity in structure, composition, and function have stalled their translational use. In this study we propose physicochemical approaches to homogenize EVs and fuse them with synthetic drug loaded liposomes to engineer a drug delivery vehicle that delivers a therapeutic payload with high intracranial uptake. We will test the safety and biodistribution of the engineered product as well as its efficacy in a glioblastoma orthotopic mouse model.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) can help improve blood sugar management in type 2 diabetes. A sequential, multiple assignment, randomized trial will evaluate clinical pharmacists, community health workers, and telehealth in supporting CGM use to improve blood sugar control. The study will also investigate the translation of supported CGM into primary care and estimate both cost and cost-effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decreases in cerebral blood flow and brain metabolism are implicated in neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease, and cognitive decline. Astrocytes, with processes that completely cover the blood vessels have been shown to regulate local blood flow through multiple mechanisms. The goal of this proposal is to explore a role for one of these mechanisms, controlled by glutamate transporters, in the decreased brain blood flow seen in Alzheimer’s disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a highly prevalent metabolic disease for which new therapies are needed. The proposed research would use rare coding human genetic variation to suggest new genes that could be modulated to treat T2D by improving insulin response in fat tissue. The project would combine two approaches – analyses of large-scale human genetic data and high-throughput molecular experiments – to address gaps in our understanding of genes in insulin response pathways and their relationship to human risk of T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although preserving kidney health is prioritized in young patients with spina bifida, current tools and approaches for assessing kidney health are inaccurate, not patient-centered, and not widely implemented. This study will use advanced quantitative, qualitative, and implementation research methods to develop new tools and consensus strategies for assessing kidney health. The new knowledge and interventions developed in this study will be extended to improve kidney, bladder, and overall health among this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This proposal aims to understand how the RNA-binding protein, IMP1, coordinates essential mechanisms of intestinal epithelial regeneration. Advances made with these studies will allow for the development of new therapeutic strategies that may augment autophagy (or other) pathways in order to restore intestinal epithelial homeostasis. This work has the potential to improve therapy for patients, especially patients who experience injury to the gastrointestinal epithelium as a result of radiation or chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have described two different subtypes of progressive apraxia of speech (PAOS), known as the phonetic and prosodic subtypes, and in cycle 1 of this grant prove that there are important differences at presentation between the subtypes, as well as different associations with two Alzheimer’s disease related tauopathies. In cycle 2, we plan to study 120 patients with PAOS, follow those who are living over time to see how the disease evolves, perform new types of brain scan techniques, and study the largest collection of autopsied brains on PAOS to better understand how brain damage relates to subtype. Knowledge gained from cycle 2 will help to improve diagnosis, provide patients with useful information to help them better prepare for the future, and help to explain the cause of PAOS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RNA abundance and lifetime is regulated by fundamental processes that includes the eukaryotic RNA exosome and its upstream cofactors, essential multi-subunit complexes that contribute to RNA homeostasis through 3’ to 5’ processing and degradation in surveillance pathways that monitor the quality of nuclear and cytoplasmic RNA and in signaling to control the duration of RNA expression. Post-translational protein modification by ubiquitin (Ub) and ubiquitin-like (Ubl) proteins such as SUMO (small ubiquitin-like modifier) regulate protein activities in processes that include the cell cycle, protein degradation, protein localization, nuclear transport, cytokinesis, chromosome segregation, and transcriptional regulation. This proposal seeks to continue exploration of these essential eukaryotic processes of Ub/Ubl-protein modification and RNA decay through structural, biochemical and genetic studies that will illuminate molecular mechanisms underlying defects associated with human diseases that include cancer, inflammation, and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Blood flow through the brain capillaries is impaired in Alzheimer’s disease, and preclinical research is needed to understand the bases for this impairment and to identify therapeutic avenues to improve capillary flow. This project will use cutting-edge microscopy and genetic approaches in live mice to study pericytes, a cell type that regulates capillary blood flow, and determine how contractile signals to these cells contributes to normal blood flow and reduced blood flow in models of Alzheimer’s disease-like pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The occurrence of increased cardiovascular-disease mortality among patients with very high plasma concentrations of high-density lipoproteins (HDL), the so-called “good cholesterol,” is a paradox for which underlying mechanisms are unknown. HDL is richer in free cholesterol (FC) in animal models of this disorder than in normal animals, so we will test in humans the hypothesis that, compared to normal patients, those with high HDL concentrations and cardiovascular disease have HDL that is richer in FC that rapidly transfers to macrophages, a key cell type in the development of cardiovascular disease. Validation of our hypothesis would provide a compelling rationale for the validation of diagnostics that quantify HDL-FC levels and for the development of therapeutic inhibitors of HDL-to-macrophage FC transfer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The burden of chronic hepatitis B (CHB) is greater among foreign-born Asian Americans who account for more than 50% of Americans living with CHB. The proposed study leverages our two unique clinic-based cohorts of CHB patients to examine the multi- step and multi-level process to chronic liver diseases and liver cancer. Our prospective longitudinal study will provide the groundwork to understand the etiology and mechanisms of disparities in chronic liver disease progression in among Asian Americans and other high-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ecological structure of the human gut microbiome helps determine nutritional and phenotypic responses to diet. However, a clear mapping does not yet exist between diet, gut microbial ecology, gut microbial community metabolism, and human metabolic phenotypes. In this proposal, we design and test an integrated host- microbiome-diet metabolic model for rapidly and accurately predicting personalized responses to dietary inputs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: We propose to develop a novel engineered T cell therapy against malignant mesothelioma, a rare and incurable cancer. We have developed a prime-and-kill circuit T cell that targets a tumor specific cell surface antigen to activate the circuit and a credentialed tumor associated antigen to enhance anti-tumor activity and overcome limitations associated with current cell therapies in solid tumor treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improved education in childhood is thought to improve adult health and brain function. Our grant proposal will show whether it is possible to conduct an ambitious study in which we hope to re-contact 11,240 participants in a successful education experiment that began in 1985. This will allow us to understand whether students in small size classrooms age better, have better physical health, and have better brain health than students who were in regular size classrooms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Fuchs Endothelial Corneal Dystrophy (FECD) is an age-related degenerative disease, the primary cause of progressive blindness from corneal endothelial cell death and the second most common cause of corneal transplants in people above 40 years old in the U.S.A. In FECD, prominent stress factors such as oxidative, ER and Mitochondria stress contribute to cell death of corneal endothelial cells, whose primary function is to maintain corneal transparency. Understanding the cross talk between these stress factors may facilitate the development of pharmacological treatments for FECD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oxidative stress, caused by excessive reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, can lead to cell and tissue damage, and thus contributes to the development of various chronic conditions such as aging, cancer, diabetes and heart diseases. This proposal aims to dissect the molecular mechanism underlying an enzyme family called NADPH oxidases, the primary function of which is to produce ROS. Outcomes of our research program will lay the foundation for the development of new strategies to combat oxidative stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  This project explores the possibility of creating Chimeric Antigen Receptor bacteria (CAR-bacteria) that can be used to target and destroy cancer cells. We combine the expertise of nanobody-mediated targeting (Chang), cancer immunology (Bui), and a synchronized lysis circuit (Hasty) to create truly novel “bugs as drugs”. Future studies could optimize the circuitry, recognition, and payload in the bacteria to provide even higher therapeutic efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent females detained or on probation in juvenile justice settings present with a unique health risk profile, including elevated risk of unplanned pregnancy, substance use, HIV/STI infection, and the overlapping risk of substance-exposed pregnancy. This study will test the efficacy of a targeted bundled prevention intervention for this vulnerable population, many of whom are ethnic minorities disproportionately at risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes self-management training (DSMT) is an evidence-based, recommended guideline of diabetes care that is underutilized, especially among underserved patient populations disproportionately affected by type 2 diabetes. Patient-facing Health Information Technologies and behavior change approaches inspired by Behavioral Economics can be used to increase engagement with DSMT. The specialized training and expert mentorship provided in this K01 will guide the specific aims of the project to culturally adapt, usability test and conduct a feasibility evaluation of the ‘DM-BOOST para Latinx’ intervention, designed to increase patient engagement and experience with DSMT among Spanish-speaking Latinx patients.
