IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest major cancers, and treatment strategies have not improved significantly for decades. A hallmark of pancreatic cancer is the formation of a dense stromal compartment, which provides metabolic support to the cancer cells and limits therapeutic efficacy. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanisms of metabolic crosstalk between the stroma and the pancreatic cancer cells that facilitate tumor growth and promote therapeutic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Neurotoxic damage to the nervous system weighs heavily in patients’ decision to use chemotherapy for its life-saving benefits in treating cancer. The toxic effects of the most commonly used and successful chemotherapies significantly reduce quality of life by causing neurological disorders both during and long after treatment, causing pain, strange sensations, fatigue, and difficulty with balance and walking. Building on our recent discoveries, the preclinical studies we propose take a new direction that has the promising potential to identify novel targets for treating neurotoxic damage the neurons ultimately responsible for movement disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The mandate of NIDDK is to reduce the disease burden of diabetes and other hormonal diseases, obesity, kidney and gastro-intestinal and liver diseases in the US and the world at large. We need to provide the scientific manpower to lead this effort and this proposal aims to enhance the pipeline by interesting medical students to do research in these fields. In the past 4 years we have supported 51 students in laboratories of successful scientists who investigate the nature and treatment of these diseases.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  The current used X-ray medical imaging devices are not portable, too insensitive and may cause cancers to patient. We propose to develop metal halide perovskites-based X-ray detectors with strong signal, low noise, light weight, and foldable. They will be much more sensitive and convenient for trauma care applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The patient-clinician interaction is central to most therapies and is supported by key interpersonal mechanisms of action, though the neural underpinnings of this effect are mostly unknown. As previous research has implicated brain-to-brain concordance of the temporoparietal junction, a region known to be intimately linked with theory of mind processing, we will use hyperscanning functional MRI to evaluate the impact of targeted theory of mind training in fibromyalgia patients on brain-to-brain concordance and how such training can synergistically couple with acupuncture therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the increasing clinical evidence of intracranial calcifications and craniosynostosis during prenatal ZIKV infection, yet the etiology remains an enigma and is currently unexplored. Herein, I seek to address the molecular mechanisms underlying ZIKV-induced calcifications and resulting craniofacial abnormalities. The insights gained will serve as a preclinical platform for development of therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The kynurenine pathway (KP) is a conserved molecular pathway which consists of several bioactive metabolites that are detrimentally elevated with inflammation, aging and frailty in mammals. The goal of this study is to determine how suppression of KP metabolites affects functional decline, characteristics of aging, and lifespan in mice. In order to meet these goals, we will genetically and pharmacologically suppress specific components of the KP and measure functional decline, pathophysiological metabolic changes, lifespan and cellular changes associated with aging in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This is a request to fund a training program combining basic neuroscientists and clinicians hoping to gain a fuller foundation in neurobiology. The interactive environment allows these basic neuroscientists and their clinical counterparts to train together so that they appreciate the bidirectional nature of translational neuroscience. This program creates neuroscientists with an understanding of psychiatry and psychiatric scientists with a good feel for the neuroscience that underlies disorders of cognition and mood.
PROJECT_TERMS: Mental Health;Neurosciences;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in the Neuroscience of Mental Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Over-screening for breast cancer occurs frequently in older women with limited life expectancies even though it may inappropriately subject them to short-term harms with little chance of benefit. Clinician-patient communication holds promise to reduce over-screening in older women but its impact may be weakened by conflicting messages from other sources. This proposal aims to better understand the impact of messages from different sources on older women's screening intentions in order to inform a communication intervention, as next step, to reduce breast cancer over-screening among older women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroinflammatory diseases collectively cause significant morbidity and mortality, and a major roadblock to their effective diagnosis and treatment continues to be poor understanding about the underlying infectious or autoimmune etiologies in a large proportion of cases. This multi-center study combines incredibly deep clinical phenotyping capabilities with the most advanced molecular biology and bioinformatic tools to identify novel infectious and autoimmune causes of neuroinflammatory disease and better understand pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: There are over 2 million annual cases of traumatic brain injury contributing to debilitating sequelae such as epilepsy and cognitive disability emphasizing the need to identify mechanisms and therapies. Studies proposed here will test a novel molecular pathway involving immune receptor mediated activation of a specific endopeptidase as a mechanisms for abnormal birth, integration, and function of neurons in the dentate gyrus after brain injury. The experiments will test whether circuit changes after trauma impair brain rhythms involved in memory processing and examine the therapeutic potential of posttraumatic inhibition of the endopeptidase in preventing epilepsy and memory deficits after brain injury.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Fever is one of the most common reasons for care-seeking in Thailand, but most causes of fever are never identified. Understanding the burden of what causes fever is vital to design appropriate and targeted public health interventions and reduce disease burden. Here we evaluate methods to efficiently measure the population-level burden of scrub typhus, melioidosis, and typhoid fever from blood antibody levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 40% of prescribed drugs target G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), which activate transducer proteins called G proteins and arrestins to produce effects that can be either beneficial or detrimental to human health. It is not known how GPCRs select the correct transducers needed to produce appropriate cellular or therapeutic responses, or how the cellular context affects this molecular mechanism. This project aims to increase understanding of how GPCRs interact with their transducers to produce coordinated cellular signals, and may facilitate the development of drugs with the capacity to fine-tune cell signaling and better treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Unlike other common cancers for which early detection and surgical resection have reduced cancer deaths (e.g. colon polyps for colon cancer, ductal carcinoma in situ lesions and breast cancer), pancreas cancer precursors, such as commonly observed pancreatic cysts, are poorly understood. Towards the long-term goal of early detection of pancreatic cancer, our objective in this proposal is to accurately detect and characterize pancreatic cysts before they turn into aggressive cancer. The outcome of this research will be a new diagnostic tool, named Cyst-X, which will establish a better clinical strategy than the current guidelines by recommending a more selective use of invasive testing, surgery, and surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will validate one molecular pathway contributing to the cisplatin resistance of ovarian cancer cells, Matrix Metalloproteinase 3 (MMP3), as a potential therapeutic target. In addition, we will identify MMP3-associated molecules that hold therapeutic potential. Therefore, this research project is highly relevant to the public health because the discovery of novel targets for intervention will impact 50-70% of ovarian cancer patients, mainly those who become resistant to cisplatin treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will determine that endogenous GABA signaling in the islet is a key paracrine modulator of delta cell function as a signaling hub. It will demonstrate that the delta cell and somatostatin play important roles as immunomodulators in their interaction with the local sensory nerves and immune cells, thus protecting the islet from damaging inflammation. As a major expected outcome, we will prove that delta cell, as a master regulator of 1) endocrine function, 2) local immune responses and 3) sensory nerve excitability, is essential for islet homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Emerging ‘superbugs’, which are resistant to multiple antimicrobials, pose a daunting threat to current treatment protocols. Acinetobacter baumannii can develop multidrug resistance without acquisition of new resistance genes. Basic characterization of the underlying intrinsic resistance mechanisms will guide new antimicrobial development and improve current therapeutic treatment protocols. Therefore, this work is relevant to NIH mission to pursue fundamental knowledge, to reduce the burden of human illness and combat emerging threats to global public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mechanisms controlling the transition from acute to chronic pain are not well understood, but many lines of evidence support the wasabi receptor, TRPA1 is involved in this process. These projects seek to determine how a novel gain-of-function TRPA1 mutation confers channel hyperactivity and the mechanism of calcium regulation of TRPA1 by an interplay of direct calcium binding and calmodulin. These studies will provide a greater understanding of TRPA1 regulation and may uncover new avenues for rational drug development to treat chronic pain and inflammation with non-addictive therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Successful memory for future actions is essential to adults’ capacity to engage in health and safety-related activities (e.g., remembering to take medication). Unfortunately, limited knowledge exists regarding the processes that couples employ as they navigate both normative (e.g., forgetfulness) and non-normative (i.e., mild cognitive impairment, dementia) cognitive aging, thereby impeding intervention development. This research investigates the biobehavioral pathways (i.e., physiological stress response, behaviors, and social processes) which positively and negatively impact middle-aged and older spouses’ prospective memory performance in order to achieve long-range intervention outcomes that will: positively impact couple resiliency, reduce everyday memory failures, and ultimately allow more older adults to age in place.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) live with many supportive care needs, yet the supportive care specialty remains poorly integrated into CKD care. This project describes the current state of dissemination of supportive care in pre-dialysis CKD care, its association with patient centered outcomes, and tests the effectiveness of integrating supportive care into CKD care. The information obtained from this study will provide important knowledge of approaches to care that have the potential to improve quality of life, outcomes, and satisfaction with care for CKD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Nerve cells control behavior and metabolism through the release of signaling molecules that are packaged in specialized compartments called dense-core vesicles, and abnormalities in the release of these molecules contributes to a wide range of mental disorders. It is common for individual neurons to carry multiple types of these signaling molecules, but it is generally not known whether they are stored and released together or separately in different dense-core vesicles. This exploratory study will begin to dissect the mechanisms by which neurons generate multiple types of dense-core vesicles, which should provide insights into the roles of these signaling molecules in normal physiology and disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE Multiple cohort clinical studies demonstrate that visual-impairment diseases including glaucoma and cataract increase risk of developing dementia and AD, and cataract extraction is significantly associated with lower risk of dementia development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV and cocaine use are strongly linked to stroke, but substance use outside of alcohol and tobacco are not included in stroke risk calculators, even those adapted for people living with HIV (PLWH). Whether including the use of cocaine would improve the detection of people at the highest risk for stroke is unknown. We propose a study to determine the simultaneous influences of cocaine, polysubstance use, inflammation and traditional risk factors on stroke and cerebrovascular conditions that directly precede stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who have experienced hypertensive disorders in pregnancy are at significantly elevated risk of future cardiovascular disease. However, a substantial proportion of these women do not transition to primary care in the postpartum year for ongoing cardiovascular disease risk management and those who do may receive suboptimal care that does not adequately address this heightened risk. The proposed study will examine how systems factors, including insurance dynamics and features of healthcare organizations, shape use of primary care and the care received in this setting in the postpartum year using a mixed methods approach. Findings will contribute to an improved understanding of system factors associated with successful transition to postpartum primary care for women at high cardiovascular disease risk, and help to identify interventions, healthcare quality metrics, and policy levers to improve clinical practice.

PHR: Project Narrative – Overall Component The Nutrition Obesity Research Center (NORC) at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC) takes as its central theme “Interdisciplinary Nutrition Research: From Molecules to Public Health.” We propose an Administrative Core and four biomedical research cores: the Animal Metabolism Phenotyping Core, the Clinical and Community Human Assessment and Interventions Core, the Metabolism and Metabolomics Core, and the Precision Nutrition Core. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With age, most stem cells lose their ability to adequately replace damaged tissue cells and respond to tissue regenerative needs, but the causes of this loss in potency remain unclear. Goal of this project is to use the negligibly senescent planarian stem cell system to identify the role of transposon silencing and chromatin maintenance in their ability to avoid age-related changes. This project will contribute to a better understanding of the biology of aging, and to the identification of new strategies to improve the human health span.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Our aim is to elucidate the connection between the gene-level and genome-wide motions of human genome inside the cell nucleus in live cells in real time. By answering such a fundamental question we will learn new biology and physics underlying the dynamics of the human genome, which is critical for gene regulation, cell homeostasis and healthy development. Such knowledge will lead to a new, mechanistic picture of the dynamic self-organization of the human genome, contributing to current efforts to understand mechanisms of cancer, diabetes and developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a devastating complication of cirrhosis with heterogeneous presentations and suboptimal responses to therapy. Volume resuscitation with intravenous albumin is recommended as first-line treatment for all AKI in cirrhosis, though clinicians require additional guidance to distinguish between those who may be harmed by resuscitation (i.e., patients with pre-existing intravascular overload and/or features suggesting high risk of lung vascular leakage) from those who would benefit. In this proposal, we aim to define predictors of renal response to treatment and better personalize IV albumin dosing by introducing an inexpensive and reliable measurement of intravascular volume into the treatment algorithm for AKI in cirrhosis, thus optimizing existing therapies and improving outcomes for this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 6% of the US adult population meets criteria for Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD), yet few effective, long- term treatments are currently available. Glycogen synthase kinase 3 beta (GSK3B) has been implicated in ethanol behaviors through microarray, gene targeting, and pharmacological inhibition experiments, and as such poses as a potential therapeutic target in the treatment of AUD. We propose to further investigate the role of GSK3B in ethanol consumption by identifying precise cell types of interest and its regulation throughout the shift from initial ethanol exposure through progressive, chronic consumption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Life-threatening arrhythmia in the setting of QT prolongation commonly occurs as a consequence of drugs that affect cardiac repolarization. While cardiomyocyte mishandling of calcium leads to contractile dysfunction and arrhythmia, the integrative understanding of drug-induced excitation-contraction coupling abnormalities remains to be defined. For this reason, we seek to integrate our genetic models with advanced imaging and computational methods to investigate if a common mechanism of action underlies small molecule compounds-induced bradycardia or if each compound works in a different way.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The G1 and G2 variants in the gene encoding Apolipoprotein L1 (APOL1) increase risk for developing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) in people with recent African ancestry, but the exact mechanisms and agents driving the pathology are still being discovered. While the pathologic mechanisms of these variants in glomerular cells are actively being studied, the role of macrophage-mediated inflammation in the development of APOL1 kidney disease is still poorly understood. The research outlined in this proposal will use congenic induced pluripotent stem cell(iPSC)-derived macrophages to elucidate the precise mechanisms that increase macrophage inflammation and subsequent kidney injury, and provide a model to study other genetic drivers of inflammation in macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The purpose of the proposed Resource is to provide the biomedical community with access to state-of- the-art facilities for macromolecular crystallography, small-angle x-ray scattering, and x-ray spectroscopy/imaging, tools that are essential for the study of biological systems. They enable information that is prerequisite for understanding fundamentals of life, and provide methods that are central to the development of new therapeutics for human disease. The overarching goal is to provide an integrated Resource that makes mature technologies available to a broad research community, and provides researchers with expert support in their use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer (PC) is one of the deadliest diseases with an overall 5-year survival rate of ~10%, because in most cases, particular at late stages, PC is unresectable, non-permeable to drugs, immunologically suppressive, and highly metastatic. We developed a novel interstitial localized ablative immunotherapy (iLAIT), combining local ablation and local administration of immunostimulants, which has the potential to overcome the major challenges of PC, particularly when synergized with immune checkpoint therapy (ICT). This project is to determine the efficacy and immunological mechanism of iLAIT-ICT in the treatment of metastatic pancreatic tumors in mice, laying the foundation for translating iLAIT-ICT to an effective clinical treatment modality for late-stage, metastatic pancreatic cancer patients, who face severely limited options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative/Public Health Relevance. Although recurrence of pain is commonly experienced by patients, its mechanisms are poorly understood and consequently there is no FDA-approved treatment to prevent the relapse to pain. Based on novel mouse models of recurrence of pain, we propose a critical role of IL-10 signaling in the maintenance of remission. Findings from the present proposal not only are essential to fill a major gap in knowledge of pain research regarding the mechanisms underlying the remission and relapse of pain but also important to the development of therapeutics to prevent relapse and the transition to chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative B-cell-intrinsic MHCII signaling is fundamental to the process of clonal selection during germinal center (GC) reactions, and it is widely assumed that this serves as a diversifying force of selection on mature Ig repertoires. However, this assumption has not been adequately addressed, and has never been considered from the perspective of its potential significance in maintaining benign interactions between hosts and their resident gut flora. Collectively, the experiments proposed here represent the first comprehensive analysis of this assumption, will determine whether this process drives diversification of the gut microbial community in an IgA-dependent manner, and will determine whether MHCII promotes health by enhancing systemic humoral immune responses that restrict bacterial dissemination from the gut.

PHR: NARRATIVE: Center Overview  Research addressing diabetes, related conditions, and their complications is relevant to public health because these disorders cause enormous suffering and death in addition to burdening the American health care system with the highest health and economic costs among chronic diseases. Through sophisticated Biomedical Research Core services, innovative Pilot and Feasibility projects, and engaging Enrichment activities, the Washington University Diabetes Research Center (DRC) conducts research that is an important component of efforts to treat, cure, and prevent diabetes and related endocrine and metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) is a hematologic malignancy driven by a somatically acquired mutation most commonly in JAK2 (JAK2V617F), which currently lacks effective therapies for early stage patients, thus necessitating the development of novel treatment modalities. Preliminary clinical and experimental work has identified inflammation as an important factor that influences the relative growth rate of mutant cells, and preliminary collaborative mathematical modeling work indicates that this can potentially have a variety of consequences for the evolution of mutant cells at homeostasis. Novel computational methods, in combination with experimentation, are used to identify mechanisms of JAK2V617F mutant selection, to predict the evolutionary trajectories of JAK2V617F mutant cells under various inflammatory conditions, and to identify and test therapeutic targets to steer cellular evolution away from disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The immunological synapse formed between antigen presenting cells and T cells is a complex network of hundreds of protein ligand-receptor interactions that modulate the strength, course and duration of an immune response. This proposal aims at developing novel computational techniques to identify cognate binding sites, and binding partners within the superfamily of cell surface anchored Immunoglobulin proteins and to experimentally verify these predictions. The new insights gained will be leveraged in combination with high throughput experimental protein engineering technique to redesign receptor interfaces for specificity, to develop new reagents to further interrogate the function of the immune synapse and to obtain biologic drug leads for immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During neonatal obstructive cholestasis, bile acids accumulate in the liver and blood through both impaired clearance and impaired suppression of synthesis. Our research will use a translational model of preterm piglets with bile duct ligation to examine the time-dependent adaptation of the liver to bile acid signaling, as well as, the contribution of classical and alternative bile acid synthesis pathways to determine which molecular targets are impaired. This research has important clinical relevance for the identification of pathways that may be targeted by pharmaceuticals to reduce liver injury that occurs during neonatal obstructive cholestasis from bile acids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Harvard Digestive Disease Center (HDDC) is a community of scientists focused on the study of epithelial cell function and mucosal biology including inflammation and host defense of the gastrointestinal tract. The Center facilitates research in these fields by providing technical resources, core services, scientific expertise, and an important meeting point to foster close scientific and intellectual relationships among our members. We have a major commitment to training, mentoring and supporting young scientists in digestive disease research and to fostering the early careers of new faculty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interactions between different biomolecules, including proteins, lipids and metabolites, give rise to higher cellular, tissue and organismal functions. Perturbation of these interaction are observed during aging and in disease and can help identify disease mechanisms. We propose to develop an analytical multi-omics pipeline to identify functional relationships between different biomolecules and determine mechanisms contributing to brain aging and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients who self-identify as Black have a disproportionately high risk of developing kidney disease, and this health difference is partially driven by naturally occurring DNA variants in the APOL1 gene that are specific to individuals of African ancestry. Our goal is to investigate how these APOL1 variants, which evolved in the context of the immune response, alter the function of immune cells such as macrophages. New scientific information produced by our proposed work will offer novel insights for how macrophages contribute to APOL1-related kidney disease, identifying an additional cell type to consider in disease pathogenesis and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The Gateway to Global Aging Data is a data and information platform developed to facilitate longitudinal and cross-country analyses on aging, especially the Health and Retirement Study and its International Network of Studies (HRS-INS) around the world (19 surveys in 47 countries). The Gateway makes analyses of HRS-family surveys across time and countries much easier, lowering the costs of entry for new researchers and saving time and effort even for experienced researchers. The proposed expansion to include additional longitudinal surveys, the Harmonized Cognitive Assessment Protocol (HCAP), the COVID-19 surveys, and two new surveys in Brazil and Chile will help numerous interested researchers and thereby accelerate the speed of scientific discoveries in late-life cognition and dementia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks support for a new Child Health Research Career Development Award (CHRCDA) Program to be established at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) Department of Pediatrics entitled “Developing Diverse Physician-Investigator Leaders for the Future of Child Health”. Promising junior faculty Pediatric Physician-Investigators will receive intensive leading-edge basic research training in world-class laboratories of prolific scientist mentors across a broad range of important topics central to child health and development. This experienced will be integrated with a variety of formal, high quality proven career development activities to ensure successful advancement in academic pediatric medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Kidney transplantation is a life-saving procedure for patients with end-stage kidney disease, however, the long-term survival shows only a small improvement in recent decades, with a half-life of about 10 years and organ shortage is a global crisis. The present proposal will examine the significant role of macula densa NOS1 on the long-term renal graft function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical and operational research assessing the efficiency of HIV care programs require reliable information systems and capacity building for sustaining this activity in the long term. The IeDEA West Africa collaboration has already implemented a network of HIV care centers in eight countries within West Africa that will continued to be used for this primary purpose. It will also reinforce its commitment to study specific comorbidities (tuberculosis) and emerging health events in chronic HIV care including cancer, mental health and other non- communicable diseases. Follow-up of HIV-infected vulnerable populations including children, adolescents and women of reproductive age will be strengthened and a specific research agenda on key population initiated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is the strongest risk factor for nearly all common chronic diseases, and scientists have now identified both shared and unique biochemical pathways across organs and cell types that are altered with age. However, it is unknown if rejuvenation of tissues with young blood can reverse these age-related changes, or rather induces nascent beneficial programs. Here we propose to identify molecular “rejuvenation” signatures across disparate organs and cells with the goal to uncover novel therapeutic targets to slow aging processes and increase healthspan.

PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and available therapies are limited in their efficacy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: As of 2019, more than 736,900 patients have received cochlear implants (CI) worldwide. It is important to assess the functional status of the cochlea and 8th nerve prior to implant surgery. The development of an integrated eeABR acquisition system with the proposed artifact cancellation, stimulation and signal processing techniques is expected to greatly improve the quality of eeABR recordings and make the technique more widely available. As such, the proposed work will greatly impact public health by developing better objective 8th nerve assessment techniques prior to CI surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Candida auris is an emerging fungal pathogen with high transmission rates within healthcare facilities, and high mortality rates associated with bloodstream infections. This project will investigate the genetic mechanisms facilitating the ability of C. auris to colonize skin, which serves as a source for transmission between patients as well as the reservoir for deadly bloodstream infections. Uncovering these mechanisms can help to identify key vulnerabilities in this emerging fungal pathogen for therapeutic intervention and prevention of colonization and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The World Health Organization (WHO) released a report in October 2022 highlighting the increasing worldwide threat of invasive fungal infections, including drug-resistant infections, especially among expanding populations of immunocompromised individuals (https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240060241). Its goals were to direct attention to the growing problem of fungal diseases, to galvanize support for public health measures, to promote research and development (R&D) in this area, and to support development of new therapies to treat fungal infections. This proposal is a collaborative effort between industry experts with decades of experience in antimicrobial drug R&D and university scientists that aims to develop novel inhibitors of fungal DHFR, an essential fungal target with a unique mode of action, into new, broad-spectrum drugs to tackle the problem of emerging and drug-resistant fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Radiation cystitis is a severely debilitating chronic fibrotic bladder condition that results from radiation therapy for cancers in the pelvis for which no safe and effective treatment exists to date. Amphiregulin is a pro-fibrotic protein that is highly expressed in the bladder after radiation therapy and thus we hypothesize that amphiregulin mediates radiation-induced bladder fibrosis and can serve as a predictive marker for radiation cystitis. The successful outcomes of this study will determine if amphiregulin is a viable therapeutic target for radiation-induced fibrosis which will also be relevant for other benign bladder conditions characterized by a fibrotic bladder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Early identification of patients at risk for memory loss or Alzheimer’s disease related dementias (ADRD) are urgently needed so that preventive measures can be instituted early. We propose to develop and validate a blood fatty acid profile to identify disordered fatty acid patterns predictive of the development of ADRD or memory loss, using existing data from four well-respected US cohort studies. Our ultimate goal is to market a blood fatty acid profile which, either alone or in combination with other risk factors, improves the prediction of impending memory loss and/or ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical decision support (CDS) has the potential to improve patient outcomes by facilitating adherence to evidence-based practices, but it is burdensome to monitor and is oftentimes ineffective as a result. Phrase Health created Outcomes, a process evaluation web-based product to diagnose when and why CDS is not leading to the intended improvements. We are developing an “out of the box” library of quality improvement (QI) project templates for the Outcomes product that are based on asthma, bronchiolitis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) best practice guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastasis or spread is the foremost cause of cancer-related deaths. We have developed a wearable, non-pharmacological approach to non-invasively apply induced electric fields (iEFs) and shown in a mouse model, that aggressive breast tumors and their metastasis to the lungs can be reduced significantly. In this work, we are establishing the safety of iEF therapy as a standalone treatment for aggressive breast cancer and assessing efficacy of combining iEF therapy with currently used chemotherapies with the aim of improving effectiveness and patient tolerance of current standard of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many advanced, metastatic cancers are particularly hard to treat and possess features of chromosomal instability, or the inability to properly separate chromosomes during mitosis. Preliminary data from our laboratory demonstrate that these metastatic cancers disproportionally rely on a gene, NDE1, for growth and survival. Here, we investigate the mechanism behind NDE1 dependence and explore the therapeutic benefit of targeting NDE1 in cancers with chromosomal instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Heterochromatin is a conserved feature of eukaryotic chromosomes with roles in the regulation of gene expression and maintenance of genome stability, and contributes to normal development and disease progression in humans. A basic understanding of the mechanisms that mediate the assembly and epigenetic inheritance of heterochromatin will not only provide a framework for understanding how the epigenetic regulatory mechanisms can fail, but also provides the substrate and knowledge to design therapeutic strategies based on intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance This project aims to develop earphones free of metallic components for use in next-generation ultra-high- field MRI scanners, overcoming shortcomings of current models. This will support basic and clinical research on auditory brain mechanisms at greater spatial and temporal imaging resolution than currently possible. Such research is fundamentally important in the effort to advance brain science and, more specifically, to help understand central disorders relating to speech and hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Maternal morbidity and mortality associated with pre-eclampsia, a pregnancy associated condition, is a serious health crisis within the United States. There is currently a lack of accurate and objective tools for predicting and diagnosing pre-eclampsia, exacerbating the poor conditions for mothers and the healthcare system. Ricovr will apply its novel biosensor technology to develop an affordable point-of-care test to aid in pre-eclampsia diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intestinal health relies on an intact single layer of barrier cells that originate from a progenitor population of intestinal stem cells. How these stem cells sense environmental cues in order to make adjustments during infection and damage to maintain a healthy intestinal barrier is poorly understood. This proposal will establish a fundamental mechanism where intestinal stem cells take up dead neighboring cells to regulate their growth, turnover and differentiation, thereby establishing a new for therapeutic discovery in a variety of inflammatory intestinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 50 million Americans suffer from debilitating chronic pain; given that most of these patients do not have effective treatment options there is an urgent clinical need to understand the neurobiological mechanisms underlying the emergence of chronic pain to facilitate the development of novel therapeutics. This project is designed to uncover how astrocytes, critical modulators of synapse development and function, contribute to the persistent amplification of nociceptive signal transmission in pathological conditions. A better understanding of how glial cells contribute to persistent pain would aid in advancing chronic pain prevention and management strategies by identifying novel non-neuronal therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retrotransposonable elements (RTEs) which are genomic elements that have the ability to replicate and insert themselves into new genomic locations through RNA intermediates, are largely silenced in most cell types, but are active during neurodevelopment. Overly active RTEs have been correlated with a number of neurodevelopmental disorders, but discrete mechanistic roles remain elusive. This proposal aims to understand whether RTE activity regulates neurodevelopment, the mechanisms by which overactive RTEs can cause diseases, and whether inhibiting RTE activity can prevent neurodevelopmental disorders such as microcephaly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Disruptions of the complicated neuron signaling network underlie a variety of neurological disorders including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, among others. This proposed, first-of-its-kind, head-mounted voltage imager will provide neuroscientists with the capability of studying the detailed dynamics of neuronal activity in the brain of freely-behaving animals, which in turn, will support the understanding of disease mechanisms and development of new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Bronchopulmunary Dysplasia (BPD) is a disease of pre-term infants whose lungs are injured upon exposure to excess oxygen from ventilators, impairing effective gas exchange in the lungs and AyuVis Research is developing a novel class of immunomodulating small molecule derived from chitin that decrease inflammation, improve lung vascularization, decrease pulmonary hypertension and altogether prevent the depelopment of BPD in preclinical large animal model. Our objective in this proposed grant application is to assess the safety and pharmacokinetic profile of our lead compound in a Phase I SAD/MAD Clinical Trial in healty human volunteers, followed by an exploratory efficacy Phase-2a Trial in preterm infants at-risk of developing BPD. These proposed studies are key stages in the development of our much needed prophylactic treatment for BPD in infants and treatment for other life-threatening lung conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer-related fatigue (CRF) is the most common and distressing long-term side effect of breast cancer disease and treatment. Physical activity is the first-line treatment recommended to reduce fatigue levels in breast cancer survivors, but no scalable, tailored physical activity intervention designed to meet the specific needs of breast cancer survivors with CRF exist. The public health significance of this study lies in its potential to better understand how to promote physical activity in BCS with CRF to inform future intervention development and, ultimately, improve health outcomes and quality of life in this large and growing population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Tuberculosis represents a significant healthcare burden especially for developing countries and today’s anti- TB treatment can effectively cure TB if it is monitored properly. Unfortunately, for countries with most of the TB burden, they do not have the resources to reach the maximum effectiveness the current anti-TB drugs can offer, including the ability to assess the drug exposure by monitoring their blood levels. For this Phase I project, we are going to demonstrate the feasibility of an anti-drug level monitoring system that is affordable and convenient to use by using existing blood glucose meter platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Accumulation of acetyl-tau (ac-tau) impairs synaptic plasticity and spatial memory, appearing in the brains of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients at the earliest Braak stages prior to p-tau and is not detectable in the healthy brain. Ac-tau is a compelling therapeutic target for monoclonal antibody (mAb) treatment of tauopathy in AD, since ac-tau is a highly pathogenic tau modification that impairs tau homeostasis and induces tau mislocalization and synaptic toxicity. Aeton Therapeutics is developing a humanized anti-acetyl-tauK174 mAb to treat tauopathy and tau-mediated neuroinflammation in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs) have an annual prevalence of over 11% of the US population with 15% - 20% of cases being resistant to first-line antibiotic therapy. Despite the severity and prevalence of UTIs, the existing culture-based standard-of-care takes several days to return a result, commonly resulting in empiric treatment of UTIs, and categorizing UTIs as one of the largest contributors to antibiotic resistance. Our technology is a point- of-care diagnostic platform that can identify UTI-causing pathogens and key genetic markers of antibiotic resistance from a patient urine sample in 15 minutes, enabling immediate administration of targeted of antibiotic therapy. .

PHR: Project Narrative: The currently ongoing pandemic of coronavirus disease-2019 (COVID-19) is posing a severe infectious threat to human population across the globe, with more than 6.8 million deaths occur due to SARS-CoV-2 since its emergence in 2019 in Wuhan. Our proposed drug discovery research is of great potential in creating new broad-spectrum therapeutic agents to combat these disastrous viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Clostridioides difficile infection is responsible for thousands of deaths each year, and current antibiotic treatment is often ineffective resulting in a high rate of recurrent infections. These studies will determine the mechanism by which IFN-λ facilitates protection against C. difficile infection while uncovering a novel role for IFN-λ in the immune response against an enteric bacterial pathogen. A better understanding of how IFN-λ signaling contributes to protection in our model will aid future studies in developing life-saving treatments against infection with C. difficile as well as other enteric pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Septins contribute to the development and maintenance for nearly every major organ system in humans. Membrane association is a critical step in septin function, but how septins are localized to different regions of the plasma membrane is not well understood. Discovery of the fundamental mechanisms driving septin assembly and function is essential to understand how septin sequence and expression changes lead to neurodegenerative diseases, cancer, and cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative - Methadone, an opioid agonist therapy, is the most effective treatment for severe opioid use disorder (OUD), and opioid treatment programs (OTPs) are the only medical settings allowed to administer this treatment. A March 2022 review encouraged regulatory revision to promote patient-centered care and facilitate access to take-home methadone; however, in order to safely and effectively implement take-homes, OTPs need evidence that methadone is used as directed and not diverted. This project will advance the Sonara platform, a HIPAA- compliant web-application that features integrated video dosing recording of patients drinking the take-home dose, and a tamper-evident seal that inhibits diversion attempts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic defects in the gene KCNQ2 can result in severe epilepsy affecting infants and children, but there are currently no specific therapies that target this gene. In this proposal, we are focusing on a specific element in the gene called an upstream open reading frame (uORF) that we discovered impairs optimal KCNQ2 translation into protein. Our work will determine if removing or blocking this uORF, possibly with a new class of drugs called antisense oligonucleotides, can boost levels of KCNQ2 protein in neurons as a potential strategy to overcome the predisposition to seizures and epilepsy caused by genetic defects in this gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The aim of this study is to identify novel circulating lipids associated with the risks of Alzheimer’s disease, dementia and cognitive decline. The research is conducted in the Cardiovascular Health Study, a cohort of older adults as well as using postmortem, well phenotyped brain samples from patients across the spectrum from normal to diagnosed Alzheimer’s disease. This research, which takes advantage of a novel technology to measure up to 1300 lipidomics species, will provide new targets for future interventions to reduce risks of dementia and cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This supplement proposes a two-year research and career development plan that allows Dr. Bah to work alongside mentors, assist on the parent grant deliverables, and conduct his own study aims that are building off of the parent study, “Social and Biological Mechanisms Driving the Intergenerational Impact of War on Child Mental Health: Implications for Developing Family-Based Interventions”, R01 MH128928-01. The aims of the proposed supplement are to explore Sierra Leonean definitions, perceptions, and behaviors that depict positive parental engagement, how they differ between mothers and fathers, and respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA) assessment of dyadic interactions. To guide this study, we will explore the social interaction learning (SIL) model that has been used to guide studies on parent-child interactions in a post-conflict setting 11.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in eight people in the United States aged 12 years or older has hearing loss in both ears, with varied root causes. This project will result in a new research platform that is completely open and accessible to anyone to conduct research studies (designs and source code will be openly available on the web). It will also allow researchers to store their data in an online hub that can be accessed by anyone to use and review the data. The ultimate objective is to spur innovation in the development of treatments and interventions for hearing loss.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes affects over an estimated 422 million individuals globally and nearly 1 in 10 Americans, yet the causes of diabetes are still poorly understood. Our mission is to assess how genetic changes can alter the ability of insulin-producing pancreatic β-cells to respond to inflammatory stress, ultimately resulting in β-cell damage and dysregulated blood sugar. We hope that our findings will provide new insights into the source of diabetes development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diminishment or distortion in the sense of smell (olfaction) with age is common, an unmet health care need, and compromises quality of life, nutritional status, and personal safety. The olfactory stem cells and the sensory neurons in the nose disappear, and the population of dormant stem cells, called horizontal basal cells (HBCs), that are held in reserve fail to activate, despite the pathological changes in the tissue. Ultimately, we seek to synthetically activate the HBCs by developing and treating with an siRNA drug as the first approved therapy for treating age-related smell loss; our goal is closely aligned with one of the mission areas of the National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Computational chemistry augments the vast majority of modern drug discovery efforts by providing crucial insight into drug binding, and relative binding free energy calculations have had a major impact by expediting the hit-to-lead phase of discovery. For small molecule drug discovery, the success of computational lead optimization is well documented, and peptide drug discovery is situated to similarly benefit from such analyses following the development of reliable computational approaches. We propose to develop a novel machine learning-based peptide simulation model that circumvents the major barriers for accurate binding free energy predictions by combining the efficiency of classical models with the accuracy and flexibility of quantum mechanics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) are crucial membrane-bound receptors found throughout the central nervous system that have been implicated in a variety of disease states. High levels of similarity between nAChR subtypes, however, have limited their pharmacological utility, as few ligands that are both selective and potent have been identified. This proposed project investigates a series of alkaloids from Aristotelia chilensis, accessed through isolation and biomimetic synthesis, for their activity as subtype-selective nAChR antagonists, which will lay the foundation to develop new tools to improve the field’s understanding of the nAChRs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histone proteins are core genome organizers that are essential for regulating gene expression and chromatin structure, which are roles emphasized by an emerging class of rare pediatric neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs) caused by germline missense mutations in replication-independent (RI) histone genes. Using an innovative approach that harnessed the power of large-scale databases, we predicted a subset of novel putative histone-encoding disease candidate genes most likely to cause disease when mutated, and subsequently identified a previously unpublished cohort of unrelated patients with a recurrent germline missense mutation in the RI histone MACROH2A1 (c.80G>A, p.R27Q) who presented to clinical attention with an NDD that shares a striking degree of phenotypic overlap with other mutant-RI histone-driven histonopathies. In this study, we will interrogate, for the first time, the fundamental features of MACROH2A1 in a human model of neurodevelopment and then quantify the resulting epigenetic dysregulation caused by this shared mutation, leading to evidence for a unifying model of heterozygous missense mutations in RI histones acting through a conserved pathogenic mechanism, which would provide the foundation for therapeutic development; and resulting in the advancement of the field of histone neurobiology, the benefits of which could extend to providing insights into common neurodegenerative pathologies, like Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 1.25 million Americans have Type 1 Diabetes, where the immune system targets insulin- producing b cells within the islets of Langerhans for destruction, and there is no cure as we do not know how to stop this immune-mediated attack. We have generated a novel mouse model in which the sialic acid transferase ST8Sia6 is expressed in b cells in NOD mice, which reduces the incidence of diabetes by 90%. The focus of this proposal is to examine the changes in the immune response which protect pancreatic b cells from immune-mediated attack in this model, and to determine if this improves efficacy of islet transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Antibodies that block immune checkpoint receptors such as PD-L1 and PD-1 have impressive efficacies against an array of human cancers due to their ability to enhance anti-tumor T cell responses. Despite the observed clinical success of these immunotherapies, the interactions between PD-L1 and its binding partners that dictate its function in promoting immunity are still rather poorly understood. In this proposal, we uncover a novel regulatory mechanism by which PD-L1 and CD80 expressed on activated DCs dictate chemokine-driven migration during a type I immune response and downstream memory T cell responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative – Invizyne Technologies, Inc Late-stage functionalization of drug molecules by adding methyl (or other alkyl) groups can greatly alter the pharmacological properties by orders of magnitude – the ‘magic methyl effect’ – yet are difficult to achieve chemically. Nature has evolved methyltransferase (MT) enzymes as powerful tools to add specific methyl groups to molecules and Inivzyne’s cell-free S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) regeneration system, SimpleSAM, exploits MTs and SAM regeneration for discovery and industrial production of methylated pharmaceutical chemicals. Completion of this Phase I SBIR focuses on the development of GlyCoSAM, a deployment-ready platform technology for enzyme- based biomanufacturing of methylated chemicals which can ultimately enable production of previously inaccessible pharma- and nutraceuticals via green chemistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2) are an important driver of inflammation in allergen-exacerbated asthma, but the mechanisms that govern their activation and proliferation are poorly defined. I have used the Collaborative Cross recombinant inbred mouse panel to identify a 0.343 megabase quantitative trait locus (QTL) with 72 protein-coding genes associated with the number of lung ILC2, which is a function of their activation and proliferation in response to aeroallergen challenge. We hypothesize that CD22, a cell-surface receptor previously implicated in the inhibition of B cell proliferation, is the gene within the QTL that is responsible for driving this ILC2 phenotype, and we aim to define the ability of CD22 to inhibit ILC2 proliferation, and as a consequence, suppress innate type 2 inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with Down syndrome have a 75-90% lifetime risk for Alzheimer’s disease, however there is a large variability in the timing of AD pathology and symptomology. Cross-sectional evidence suggests that body mass index may be a risk factor related to Alzheimer’s disease outside the Down syndrome population; there is an urgent need for longitudinal studies that can determine the time-ordered nature of these associations within Down syndrome. The research specific aims of this F31 project will leverage existing longitudinal data (three cycles of data collection) to examine the effect of body mass index and weight change on imaging biomarkers of Alzheimer’s disease pathology (PET Aβ and tau PET), cognitive decline (episodic memory, executive functioning, motor planning and control, and dementia symptoms), and clinical Alzheimer’s disease status (cognitively stable, mild cognitive impairment, and Alzheimer’s disease) and explore whether inflammation (biomarkers of serum c-reactive protein, interleukins-6, interleukins-10, and tumor necrosis factor alpha) mediates these associations, in a large cohort of adults with Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed experiments are aimed at understanding how different parts of the brain form in the correct place. Brain formation is sensitive to disruptions by a variety of factors (e.g., environmental toxins, infectious agents, and genetic conditions) that give rise to a range of neurodevelopmental disorders – ranging from motor control problems such as ataxia, to cognitive defects such as autism. The results from our experiments will begin explaining the basis of such disorders and will help inform studies aimed at treating them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE While millions of patients receive life-saving chemotherapy every year, their untoward effects on the gastrointestinal (GI) track can be severe enough to limit treatment, increase hospitalizations, and/or increase risk of death. While much attention has been paid to the development of newer and more effective agents, their GI toxicities remain problematic. Covira Surgical is developing a first-in-class agent to prevent chemotherapy- related gastrointestinal toxicities that limits direct epithelial damage, dysbiosis and lethal gut-derived bacteremia and sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There are many inherited genetic diseases that affect the retina, causing vision loss and blindness primarily through deterioration of the light-sensing cells of the retina, photoreceptors. Gene therapies offer the potential to address many of these retinal diseases, but we lack a safe, effective method to deliver gene editing molecules to photoreceptors. We are using new chemical approaches to make safe, effective vehicles to help genetic medicines reach photoreceptors and address the root cause of many retinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Embrient Inc is pleased to submit our request for an HHS / SBIR / NIBIB grant, entitled, “Developing a Novel Incubator to Increase Cell Culture Reproducibility.” By funding this grant, you will support our efforts to design and test an incubator that employs laminar flow principles, aiming to achieve zero or near-zero chamber recovery time when the incubator door is opened. This innovation holds the promise that future cell culture experiments utilizing our incubator can maintain stable conditions akin to the human body, without the extensive fluctuations that affect the reliability of current market incubators. As a result, research outcomes will be more dependable and reproducible, advancing scientific progress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced metastatic lung cancer is difficult to treat because many tumors lack immune cells critical for fighting cancer. Aakha Biologics is developing a novel biologic drug that has the potential to both attract these immune cells to the tumor and activate them to kill the tumor. If successful, this biologic drug could provide a treatment for patients whose cancer is not responsive to currently available treatments. This project aims to complete studies that will further develop this biologic drug and ultimately support the submission of an application for a human clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate diagnosis and assessment of brain metastases in patients with systemic cancers has important implications for patient prognosis and treatment strategy. The proposed two-way magnetic resonance tuning nanoprobes and complementary subtraction imaging technology with ultra-high tumor-to-normal tissue ratios will provide neuroradiology practice with a highly capable, accurate and consistent approach for detecting and evaluating early brain metastases. This new imaging technology has great potential to be translated in clinic to improve survival and reduce the mortality rate in patients with brain metastases in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Exposure to high levels of environmental metals is known to be toxic, and the kidney is a harbinger of toxicity. Yet, current tests for kidney disease are insensitive for metal toxicity and do not evaluate the kidney tubules, which are the kidney components directly impacted by metals. With the development of novel non- invasive markers of kidney tubule damage, this program of research will harness these biomarkers to develop a kidney tubule monitoring panel that can be used to monitor populations at risk of metal toxicity, and to monitor the health impacts of programs that clean hazardous environmental metal contamination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Drugs of abuse, such as cocaine, are known to cause stable changes in neuronal function throughout the reward pathway and lead to drug-seeking and drug-taking, even following long periods of abstinence. Yet, the specific long-term molecular mechanisms that can lead to relapse remain unclear. The experiments in this proposal will examine the role of the histone modifying enzyme HDAC3 within the cholinergic population of medial habenula cells, and its role in mediating relapse cocaine-associated behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  In this Phase I SBIR, we propose to develop a prototype of the HealthyU-Native program conceptualized to improve the success of secondary Native American and Alaskan Native (NA/AN) students when engaging with health information, processes, and institutions by providing a culturally responsive, web/mobile app-based health literacy curriculum. The product will support students in school and community settings. Ultimately, reducing disparities in health literacy will lead to improved health outcomes for NA/AN students providing personal, social, and economic benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project narrative (Public Health Relevance)  Globally, liver diseases are on the rise. At least half of people living with type 2 diabetes have nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and are at higher risk to develop nonalcoholic or alcohol associated steatohepatitis and cirrhosis. miRNA signatures are considered as potential diagnostic and prognostic biomarkers for human diseases. Recently, miRNA-based diagnostic tests using RT-qPCR technology are being used to detect cancers. The goal of this grant application is to develop a high multiplex RT-qPCR method that enables the detection of multiple miRNAs from various specimens in a single reaction on existing qPCR systems. Many liquid biopsy applications (such as liver and metabolic diseases, oncology, neurological and cardiovascular diseases), that require analysis of multiple miRNAs, will highly benefit from this technology.

PHR: NARRATIVE Fluid Discovery aims to commercialize a single-cell proteomics approach, Self-Assembled Partitioning Proteomics (SAP-pm), for Alzheimer's research – enabling the quantification of thousands of proteins in hundreds of thousands of individual cells, while being multiplexed with DNA and RNA sequencing. This innovative approach overcomes limitations of existing technologies and allows for tri-omic profiling, shedding light on the mechanisms of proteomic dysregulation and unveiling new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single cell genomics technologies have had a tremendous impact on our understanding of the fundamental unit of life but lack the ability to collect simultaneous dynamic functional cellular analysis. The proposed technology combines imaging-based dynamic phenotyping and genomic analysis at single cell level in a high-throughput manner. This new approach has the potential to impact and expand functional single cell analysis beyond existing solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance Immertec has developed software to stream high-quality stereoscopic video to virtual reality (VR) devices for remote medical training in real-time. Immertec's technology provides options for clinicians to learn specialty procedures and use of new medical devices without traveling to onsite training by allowing a healthcare practitioner from any location to attend live training courses with specialists from a distant hospital or simulation center, interact with critical biomedical image feeds, and converse with a remote instructor or peers. Immertec's technology takes a step toward mitigating health disparities in underserved rural communities that have limited access to medical specialists by providing more options for remote training of specialty medical knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative In an increasingly polarized world, workplaces serve as critical sources of belonging for their employees; however, members of the LGBTQ+ community continue to experience thwarted belonging as many organizations lack the policies and procedures necessary to make LGBTQ+ workers feel safe, connected, and included, especially given the transformation of the workplace, as precipitated by the COVID-19 pandemic that has led to an increase in burnout and, often, a reduction in the possibilities for work-based social connections. The proposed research will employ a participatory design approach to create and examine the acceptability and preliminary effects of Bridges, an advanced Learning Management System and messaging program that will leverage insights from behavior change science to address thwarted belongingness among LGBTQ+ workers. By utilizing the science of behavior change and accessible technology to address limitations of current employee programs to increase feelings of belonging, this easily disseminable, potentially cost-effective, and highly tailored solution would overcome the limitations of existing company-sponsored wellness programs and interventions for workplace belonging that target LGBTQ+ workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is more aggressive in youth than in adults and management can be improved through precise, data-driven approaches. Metformin is the only oral treatment option approved for T2D in youth but current dosing strategies are ineffective at maintaining durability of glycemic control. The goals of this project are to evaluate the pharmacological, clinical and physiological determinants of metformin response in youth with T2D and to develop and evaluate a clinically usable precision dosing algorithm in order to ultimately improve clinical outcomes for youth with T2D.

PHR: Narratives:  This project aims to develop a reliable and accurate pyrazinamide susceptibility testing that can be used routinely in tuberculosis laboratories worldwide. The testing is designed to be reliable, inexpensive, simple, and safe to use, providing rapid and accurate results of pyrazinamide susceptibility. The implementation of this testing will guide healthcare providers in giving the most effective treatment to TB patients and help curb TB drug resistance. The impact of this innovation on public health will be significant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual assault is highly prevalent among college students and is associated with high risk for alcohol misuse and co-occurring posttraumatic stress in survivors of all genders, but substantial barriers exist to college students’ ability to access effective in-person preventative interventions for these conditions. The current study proposes to optimize the first app-based preventative intervention with demonstrated efficacy in reducing alcohol misuse, called THRIVE, by testing the unique and synergistic effects of its components in a factorial randomized controlled trial. If we are successful in identifying a highly effective and efficient version of THRIVE, this intervention would represent a highly-scalable strategy to reduce the substantial burden of posttraumatic stress and alcohol misuse on students and campus service systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is a leading cause of disability with an economic burden of >$60 billion per year, with ~60M million people in the US suffering from chronic OA pain – a figure that is increasing due to increasing life expectancy and increasing obesity. Current drug treatments for pain are associated with side effects: ~17,000 individuals die each year from NSAID-associated side effects, and opioid use leads to misuse, abuse and overdose, contributing to the ~50,000 individuals dying each year from opioid overdose. Safer, more effective and less addictive pain relief strategies are desperately needed, and our proposed research investigating a hitherto unrecognized pathway driving OA pain will identify novel therapeutic targets that will ultimately lead to new, safe strategies for alleviating OA pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Taylor, Martin | K08 (PA-20-203) | PROJECT NARRATIVE Selective therapeutic modulation of the two mTOR effector complexes, mTORC1 and mTORC2, is a key goal for the treatment of diabetes and many types of cancers because dysregulation of these signaling complexes play central and often opposing roles in disease pathophysiology, but we lack the detailed structural and mechanistic information about both complexes that would enable development of these therapies. For example, in type 2 diabetes, overfeeding results in hyperstimulation of mTORC1, which measures nutrients, resulting in inhibition of mTORC2, which then fails to transmit the critical insulin signal and leads to insulin resistance; in this context, it would be advantageous to selectively inhibit mTORC1, preventing this feedback loop, or selectively activate mTORC2, mitigating insulin resistance. The overarching goal of the scientific arm of this project is to learn about the structure and mechanism of mTORC2 in detail so that we could develop these selective strategies for better treatment of diabetes and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: CAPES OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The potential public health impact of The Center for Accelerating Practices to End Suicide through Technology Translation ( is profound, because the knowledge generated will be relevant to many diverse settings and populations at risk for suicide. CAPES will identify the best evidence-based suicide care technologies and study them systematically to identify key strategies for maximizing their translation to clinical care so they can be put in the hands of clinicians, patients, and families instead of sitting on the “virtual shelf.” This improved ability to identify and monitor suicide risk and provide high-quality care for individuals identified as at-risk will reduce suicide attempts and suicide, which also prevents the suffering experienced by families, friends, and communities that results from losing someone to suicide. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to identify and modulate key structural elements of biosynthetic enzymes that activate and transfer fatty acids for their incorporation into bioactive natural products. The directed evolution of the olefin synthase model system will allow us to dissect how these enzymes select and process specific fatty acid substrates for transfer to polyketide synthase domains. We will also develop a heterologous host for the expression of these fatty acid-activating biosynthetic pathways and the production of targeted bioactive natural products to facilitate metabolic engineering and bioengineering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This study proposes to refine, integrate and disseminate the NeuroImaging Brain Chart (NIBCh) software toolbox and machine learning (ML) model library, an ecosystem of software components enabling constructive integration, statistical harmonization, and ML-centric data analyses across studies. NIBCh enables large-scale analyses of multi-modal brain MRI data by mapping such data into a compact coordinate system of informative neuroimaging signatures implemented by our library of ML models. The over-arching primary goal of our program is to provide the software tools that will allow users to contribute to an actively growing community-based dimensional neuroimaging system that will utilize machine learning models to provide rich, yet precise, compact, concise, and informative representations of brain structure, function and connectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell fate transitions depend upon the establishment of specific transcriptional programs, of which chromatin reorganization is a key regulatory layer. The germinal center (GC) B-cell maturation program is an ideal model to study the dynamics of chromatin architecture because 1) the mechanisms driving the rapid and massive phenotypic shifts are unknown and 2) GC B-cells manifest many hallmarks of cancer cells, meaning these unknown mechanisms maintain their importance in B-cell lymphomas. This proposed research will integrate whole-genome sequencing and chromatin conformation capture maps (pcHiC, Pore-C) to significantly advance our understanding of how 3D chromatin chromunities, interactive networks of enhancers, are rewired to establish cell identity in the humoral immune response and how large-scale chromosomal rearrangements in B-cell lymphomas may drive the formation of aberrant chromunities to promote aberrant phenotypes and drive lymphomagenesis.
