IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a major global health problem, associated with 20% of all global deaths each year, and in the United States sepsis is most common among older adults, people with multimorbidity, and those in communities with lower healthcare access and quality. The objective of this project is to improve understanding of the factors influencing individual sepsis risk, and the relationships between these risk factors, by using community- informed multilevel and agent-based models. By establishing critical new insights into sepsis prevention, the proposed work will greatly impact public health policy, sepsis prevention efforts, and care for older adults with chronic conditions in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Electronic cigarettes (e-cigs) aerosolize a mixture of chemical solvents, flavor additives and nicotine, and inhalation of the resultant aerosol by e-cigarette users has unknown effects on the heart. In this project, we will examine how specific flavoring chemicals that are inhaled during e-cigarette use impact the function of mouse and human heart cells and tissues. Ultimately, this study will advance knowledge of the toxicity of e-cigarettes, which will direct new regulation of e-liquid constituents based on their potential for adverse effects on the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Tobacco and electronic nicotine delivery system (ENDS) use are associated with numerous serious negative health outcomes among youth. Despite evidence to support hospital-based interventions among adult tobacco users, to date no such interventions have been developed or tested for use in the pediatric hospital, where many at-risk youth receive care. This study will design and iteratively refine a novel tobacco and ENDS use intervention for adolescents and young adults and evaluate preliminary efficacy and implementation outcomes of this intervention in the pediatric hospital setting with the overall goal to decrease ENDS use and improve health outcomes in this at-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic variants encoding for sarcomeric proteins are major contributors to the pathogenesis of genetic cardiomypathies such as dilated cardiomyopathy and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Current approach to study these variants lack ability to screen many variants at once. Here we propose to use simulations, experimental measurements and data analytics to classify variants and predict response to therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Retrotransposable elements are viral-like entities that exist within the DNA of our cells. During aging these molecular parasites are prone to activation, with deleterious effects on their host cells, such as inflammation. Our goal is to develop drugs to block these elements, which we expect will alleviate age-associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The hardware components currently used for spatial encoding, excitation, and signal reception in MRI are complex and represent a large portion of the cost and bulk of a scanner. This project will reduce the cost and complexity of MRI by developing a single integrated coil unit that performs all three of these functions, and is wireless, compact, and scalable. Arraying the units around the body and coordinating their operation using novel pulse sequences will enable rapid quantitative imaging with a wide range of magnet designs and could bring about a new generation of simple, compact, modular, and low-maintenance MRI scanners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liquid-liquid phase separation recently emerged as a novel driver of skin barrier formation. Mechanistically, the underlying intracellular phase separation dynamics govern the assembly and disassembly of enigmatic keratohyalin granules, which are hallmarks of epidermal differentiation conspicuously absent in human skin barrier disorders. Deploying innovative biomolecular engineering approaches in human epidermal equivalent models, this proposal will enable the molecular-level characterization and design of functional keratohyalin granules, laying a foundation for future therapeutic manipulation of epidermal phase separation dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project narrative Osteoarthritis is an enormous and increasing public health problem that, like many other chronic conditions, is not a single disease but a heterogeneous condition consisting of multiple subgroups, or phenotypes, with differing underlying mechanisms. Ultrasound is an accessible, time-efficient, and cost-effective imaging modality that provides invaluable data about all joint tissues involved in osteoarthritis and has the potential to identify important phenotypes. The proposed work is relevant to the NIAMS mission and represents a crucial step to establish the foundation for ultrasound as an assessment tool for use in clinics, research, and clinical trials in osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the availability of a hemostatic dressing that is easy-to-use and effective in a range of hemorrhagic wound types will reduce bleeding-associated deaths. This work will provide essential pre-clinical characterization of shape memory polymer (SMP) foams in traumatic wounds to poise their submission to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for clearance for clinical use. This proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission in that it will open new horizons in improving clinical outcomes in a range of bleed types by enhancing our understanding of hemostatic dressing effects on coagulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Rising suicide rates are a serious public health concern, and there is an urgent need for better access to effective prevention strategies that are highly transportable across settings. The study team has shown that a single session of crisis response planning (CRP) effectively reduces suicidal behavior in high-risk groups; however, it is unknown how CRP works, and for whom, curtailing intervention optimization and widespread implementation. The current study therefore combines simultaneous, multimodal neurobiological assessments of cognitive-affective functioning with a clinical trials design to uncover neural mechanisms and predictors of changes in suicide risk following a single session of CRP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall, NNLM Region 5 RML/University of Washington The University of Washington, Reaching More People in More Ways, operates the Regional Medical Library for the Network of the National Library of Medicine Region 5 in the states of Alaska, California, Hawaii, Nevada, Oregon, and Washington and U.S. Territories and Freely Associated States in the Pacific. Region 5 works with six other regional programs to advance data driven health, health equity, and health literacy by offering NNLM services, engagement, funding, and training opportunities. Members continuously learn about National Library of Medicine resources and participate in national and regional collaborations and partnerships to support a highly trained workforce to access biomedical and health information resources and data, improve health literacy, and increase health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative We discovered a previously unrecognized mechanism by which neurons protect against effects of protein aggregation—they physically throw out their threatening trash in membrane-surrounded large vesicles (exophers) for uptake by remote cells. “Exopher-genesis” is increased when neurons are subjected to proteostasis challenges, including expression of human Alzheimer's disease fragment A 1-42. Since we propose that exopher-genesis is a conserved pathway for maintaining neuronal health and we speculate that older age dysfunction of the exopher pathway might contribute to neurodegeneration and spread of neurotoxic species, dissection of the exopher mechanism should provide novel insight on Alzheimer's disease-relevant pathology that might be manipulated for therapeutic benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the molecular basis of how the ribosome translates the genetic information encoded in messenger RNAs into proteins. The main impacts of our work on public health are that: (i) Bacterial ribosomes are prime targets for many classes of clinically important antibiotics. These include the anti- tuberculosis antibiotic viomycin, whose mechanism of action we have recently elucidated. (ii) Many human RNA viruses, including HIV and coronaviruses, depend on programmed shifting of the translational reading frame for their pathogenicity. Our research has recently shed light on how the reading frame is maintained.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We seek to understand whether and how historical and current mortgage discrimination impacts obesity disparities through changes in neighborhood and resident behaviors. We propose to use a large longitudinal cohort of white and Black adults residing in four cities with mortgage discrimination histories to understand the paths by which mortgage discrimination may influence racial disparities in body mass index changes through dynamic neighborhood conditions, discrimination, homeownership, physical activity, and dietary behaviors. The results will deliver the needed evidence to guide housing and neighborhood policy by understanding whether and how long-term effects of historical mortgage discrimination and current biased mortgage lending underlie neighborhood and obesity disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Adolescence is an “age of risk” for the emergence of major depressive disorder (MD), a major public health problem. Using an innovative biobehavioral high-risk approach with a prospective longitudinal design, this application will examine bidirectional relationships between peripheral inflammation and multimodal reward function and their joint prediction of first onset of MD and increases in depression symptoms, particularly anhedonia. It will provide critical tools for identifying vulnerabilities to MD, integrate two separate research traditions to increase our understanding of specific etiological pathways underlying MD, and facilitate development of behavioral and biological interventions for ameliorating reward processing and inflammatory abnormalities that contribute to MD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance to public health: Niacin (vitamin B3, a NAD+ precursor) is widely used as a food supplement to improve heath. Administration of NAD+ precursors has also been shown to ameliorate human deficiencies related to aberrant NAD+ metabolism. Our studies may provide insights into the development of therapeutic reagents for NAD+ deficiency-associated diseases such as diabetes and cancers, and also have broad implications for improving human nutrition and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Precision-CARRS seeks to transform the way we predict, prevent, and treat heart disease, stroke, and heart failure, from identifying late stage disease to earlier disease, that may be different across groups of people. We will leverage the NHLBI-funded CARRS Cohort of 21,864 adult South Asians, a population at high risk for heart disease even at young ages and who might not have obvious reasons to develop heart disease, stroke, and heart failure. Our proposed research program includes inter-connected studies that will help us understand how factors that lead to heart attacks and heart failure develop in different people and will drive a revolution of finding unique factors in people that can be targeted with suitable prevention and care strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The application proposes to create the UW Medical Student Addiction Research (MedStAR) program to provide opportunities for mentored research and education for medical students in 5 western rural-serving states. The MedStAR program will develop a “pipeline” for medical students who are interested in pursuing Addiction Medicine fellowships to become the next generation of physician-scientists focused on the discovery and implementation of evidence-based care for patients with substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma is a soft tissue sarcoma with one of the worst prognosis. This proposal will determine how this treatment approach will best work for patients with this devastating tumor type.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Malignant gliomas are the most common, infiltrative, and lethal primary brain tumors affecting the adult population. The poor prognosis for this disease is due to the presence of highly invasive tumor cells that escape surgical resection. Weakly adherent cells within the tumors likely contribute to local invasion, and leveraging new cellular and molecular methods, this proposal will improve our understanding of invasion mechanisms governed by how cells adhere to their environment and suggest new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to create models of human ectodermal development using human pluripotent stem cells, and to use these to understand the interplay between cell-cell signaling, fate patterning, and morphogenesis. As this stage of human development is almost completely inaccessible to observation and crucial for understanding birth defects and infertility, these models and the information gained will be valuable for engineering treatments for these conditions. We will use these models to gain an understanding of crucial questions about how patterns of signaling are established and interpreted in cell fate decisions and morphogenesis in order to shape the body plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  This project is relevant to human health, as mutations in human PCDH19 cause a female-limited form of epilepsy and are associated with an increased incidence of other brain disorders. In addition, other δ-pcdhs to be studied in this proposal (pcdh7, pcdh9, pcdh17 and pcdh18) have been implicated in autism or schizophrenia. This gene family has also been linked to a variety of cancers as putative tumor suppressors that are downregulated in cell lines or primary tumors. Moreover, PCDH1 is linked to asthma. Understanding the function these genes in neurogenesis could provide important insights into the origins of neurodevelopmental disorders and provide novel drug targets in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The proper alignment of internal circadian clocks with the 24-hour rhythm of the environment is critical for human health. A central goal of chronobiology is to understand the network properties of brain’s master clock and its modulation by environmental cues. Here we use Drosophila melanogaster, an organism that continues to enrich and inform our understanding of circadian timekeeping in the brain, to understand the signals neurons use to create an internal sense of time and how the microanatomical structures of neuronal clocks support robust circadian timekeeping and the proper synchronization with the environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Repetitive negative thinking (RNT) is a core cognitive process central to the etiology and maintenance of many forms of psychopathology. Given that the presence of RNT undermines treatment outcomes, an urgent unmet need is to understand the precise psychological targets and neural systems underlying RNT that could be engaged in treatment. Thus, this project takes an experimental therapeutics approach to assess: (a) target engagement of attentional/cognitive control (as measured by eye tracking, event related potentials, and self- report data), (b) preliminary treatment efficacy of a transdiagnostic treatment for elevated RNT optimized to address attention regulation, and (c) whether improvements in attentional/cognitive control are associated with improved RNT and disorder-specific symptoms (i.e., target validation).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) is a causative factor in the development of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), and lipid-lowering therapy can markedly reduce this risk. Yet, exactly when to begin lipid-lowering therapy has not been well understood. Despite the increasing rates of ASCVD in US young adults aged 18-39 years over the past two decades, use of lipid-lowering therapy remained low, with <7% of young adults with LDL-C ≥160 mg/dL being treated (vs. ~50% in those aged ≥40 years). It is estimated that 52% US young adults have non-optimal LDL-C ≥100 mg/dL and 7% have LDL-C ≥160 mg/dL. However, there is little evidence to guide lipid management in young adults, partly due to the lack of empirical evidence. We propose to study ~805,000 young adults from 4 cohort studies (CARDIA, Framingham, HCHS/SOL, JHS) and Kaiser Permanente Southern California to identify more effective lipid-lowering and ASCVD prevention strategies and reduce health inequity in young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Children and adolescents with asthma living in urban settings suffer from increased disease severity, morbidity and mortality; the NIAID has provided long-standing support of networks to implement improved approaches to care for this at-risk population. Our objective is to demonstrate that the Mount Sinai Health Care System is well-positioned and prepared to create a NIAID Childhood Asthma in Urban Settings Clinical Research Network Center (CAUSE-CRC). We are proposing two Center-studies, which address how the co-morbidities of atopic dermatitis (Project 1) and obesity (Project 2) worsen asthma control in an urban pediatric population, findings of which will guide interventions to improve their outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Innovative new technologies that enable experimentally robust interrogation of epigenetic mechanisms are needed to broaden our understanding of epigenetic regulatory pathways in human development, disease, and therapeutic resistance. Formalin fixed, paraffin embedded (FFPE) tissues contain a wealth of information on human disease, however, extraction of high-quality chromatin (DNA together with associated nuclear proteins) from these samples for use in epigenetic assays has proven virtually impossible. We will explore the use of a unique cavitation enhancement reagent in simplifying and standardizing chromatin extraction from FFPE tissues, with the goal of making archived biospecimens available for a broad range of epigenetic-based biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative While sebaceous glands in our skin secrete an oily film (sebum) for skin lubrication, have multiple other indispensable functions, and are involved in many skin diseases, it is still quite unclear how they are regulated. Therefore, we aim to identify the role of a powerful regulatory protein located in mitochondria, the energy power houses of our cells, called MPZL3, in regulating sebaceous gland function, using state-of-the-art mouse and human skin research tools. Besides helping us to better understand how healthy sebaceous gland functions are regulated, the innovative skin research focusing on MPZL3 proposed here also promises to identify novel drug targets for more effective and better-tolerated treatment of human skin diseases with prominent sebaceous gland abnormalities such as acne, dry skin, scarring alopecia (hair loss) and sebaceous carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute heart failure is a common reason for emergency department visits and hospitalization, but the diagnosis can be challenging because of non-specific symptoms and signs. The current diagnostic approach to acute heart failure has modest accuracy, leading to delayed diagnosis and treatment, which associate with worse prognosis. Our prior work suggests diagnostic accuracy can be improved with the addition of multiple circulating biomarkers discovered through proteomics, and herein we propose to derive and validate a multi- marker model to improve diagnostic accuracy for acute heart failure in the emergency department.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative    The cellular pathophysiology of gastrointestinal motility disorders are extremely complex and elusive.  Damage  or  loss  of  enteric  inhibitory  motor  neurons  is  responsible  for  a  broad  range  of  gut  motility  disorders.  Here,  taking  advantage  of  human  pluripotent  stem  cell  differentiation,  we  propose  to  establish  an  innovative  framework  to  establish  a  new  cellular  model  for  the  study  enteric  inhibitory  neurons and an experimental pipeline for cell replacement therapy in GI dysmotility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic autoimmune uveitis is a prevalent intraocular inflammatory disease, with the potential of causing severe visual impairment and blindness including in young adults, leading to an oversized public health burden. The clinical management of patients with chronic uveitis is challenging due to the limited availability of efficacious treatments, primarily due to our poor understanding in the immunopathogenesis of this condition. We propose to determine the novel immunological memory-mediated mechanisms in sustaining disease chronicity, with the objective of improving our understanding of disease pathogenesis and facilitating future translational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain metastases are a growing problem across cancers. They can take many years to manifest, but are lethal once they do. Here, we propose to investigate breast tumor cells upon their arrival to the brain in order to define the cues that make them dormant, and to unravel the consequent signaling. We believe that solving these mysteries will inspire approaches to prevent brain metastasis by leveraging our discoveries for prophylactic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with dilated, nonischemic cardiomyopathy (DCM), even in the absence of severe cardiac dysfunction, may be at high risk for life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. However, current paradigms are insufficiently sensitive to correctly identify patients with ‘arrhythmogenic’ DCM who are at risk. Our application is built around this unmet need: we will generate a ‘risk stratification score’ that can be used as a clinical tool, uncover the molecular mechanisms triggering arrhythmias in these patients, which are currently unknown, and dissect the mechanisms of lethal fibrosis, thus paving the way for development of novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Screening for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) during well-child pediatric check-ups reduces the age of diagnosis, allowing more time for critical early intervention. This study will follow up screen negative cases to detect children with ASD missed by screening, to calculate sensitivity of toddler screening. This will lead to improvements in detecting and treating ASD as early as possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV that develop HIV-associated neurocognitive impairment (HAND) show increased brain amyloid-β (Aβ) production and aggregation, amyloid plaques, increased Tau hyperphosphorylation (pTau) and formation of neurofibrillary tangles-like structures, but the associated mechanisms are not known. This proposal will investigate the role of CCR5 in these pathologies and determine whether following HIV-1 infection, co- administration of antiretroviral drugs with the CCR5 antagonist maraviroc can prevent the formation of amyloid plaques, pTau, and neuroinflammation, abrogate brain vascular injury, neuronal loss and HAND. These novel studies involve mechanistic in vitro, in vivo, and ex vivo approaches and are relevant for designing therapeutic strategies to prevent or reduce Alzheimer’s Disease-like pathologies in HIV-infected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to learn and form memories is crucial for everyday life. Therefore, it is not surprising that diseases that affect these abilities are devastating and individuals affected are often unable to care for themselves. The fundamental goal of this project is to understand the role of local and long-range interneurons in hippocampal and medial prefrontal cortex oscillations in associative learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Relevance Transcription factors (TFs) of the TALE family play essential roles in embryonic development, and their dysregulation underlies several types of cancer. We find that closely related family members – that appear to function interchangeably in vitro – actually diverge considerably with respect to their function in vivo. By defining the mechanisms that control this heightened in vivo selectivity, our experiments will provide fundamental information about the activity of these TFs in their native environment, as well as their roles in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Production of collagen matrix in the heart is critical for proper growth and maturation of this organ, and related pathways are responsible for the accumulation of fibrotic material in the heart of post- MI patients. Cardiac fibrosis contributes to progressive heart disease, and new therapies directed at limiting the fibrotic response are desperately needed, especially end stage heart failure. This application will investigate the interplay between cardiac fibroblasts and myocytes in the heart, and the role that ECM structural support plays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Dysfunction and death of the insulin-producing β cell underlies virtually forms of diabetes, and the regeneration of β cells through growth and replication represents an approach to the treatment of diabetes that has yet to be exploited. Nutrients are key regulators of β cell growth and development, and this proposal will provide a better understanding of how nutrients induce β cell replication. Using novel mouse models, we will interrogate the molecular pathways that mediate nutrient induced β cell replication, with the intent of eventually targeting these pathways in the treatment of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many aspects of cell biology and tissue physiology are essentially problems in material science. The physics of soft materials sets the background on which living organisms evolved, and changes in the material properties of cells and tissues are a central feature of normal development, as well as numerous pathophysiological processes including atherosclerosis, fibrotic disease, and some forms of cancer. This MIRA application combines studies of the 3-D networks formed by protein filaments and the 2D surfaces formed by phospholipids to determine how the physical-chemical properties of these structures help determine their biological function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomic profiling and cytogenetic analysis have characterized AML as highly heterogeneous disease. Targeted therapies have been developed for some prevalent mutations yet their clinical responses are short- lived as resistance develops over time, prompting the rapid shift toward combination. The proposed research builds on the largest AML patient cohort, and seeks to study the interplay between tumor heterogeneity, microenvironment, and ex-vivo combination therapy response, at an individual cell resolution using new integrative machine learning approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance In this proposal, our collaborative team will study for the first time the detailed molecular structure of mammalian prions (the unorthodox infectious agents responsible for neurological diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and bovine spongiform encephalopathy) using high-resolution analytical techniques. Specifically, we will determine how essential cofactor molecules enable the prion protein to change its shape into an infectious form. The results of this research will help us visualize in molecular detail the process by which prion proteins replicate and thereby facilitate the development of rational therapies and diagnostic tools for prion diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Significant associations have been noted between the aberrant expansion of blood cells with somatic mutations in TP53 or PPM1D and prior exposure to cancer treatments. These mutational events may increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, but causal data linking these mutations in cancer survivors with cardiovascular disease does not exist. The proposed experiments will experimentally examine whether amplification of TP53/PPM1D mutant clones in blood worsens cancer therapy-related damage to the heart, using an anthracycline drug as a test case.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The generation of methods for parallel and single molecule sequencing of peptides/proteins promises a revolution in proteomic analyses. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Both borderline and avoidant personality disorders are marked by profound impairments in interpersonal functioning. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise is an important strategy to promote and maintain healthy cardiovascular, musculoskeletal, and metabolic function; however, the signals and mechanisms which transduce these effects are poorly understood. The proposed research will advance mechanistic understanding of histamine release during exercise and histamine’s involvement in adaptations to exercise. This work will lay the platform for new health interventions targeted toward at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite many decades of research, stroke is a leading cause of mortality and long-term disability world-wide and novel therapeutic approaches are needed. Our laboratory has identified a novel pathway, active in cerebral blood vessels, the sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) pathway, which plays a critical role in the exacerbation of neurovascular injury in the acute phase of stroke. The proposed studies will test the hypothesis that manipulation of this pathway in the cerebral vasculature prevents neurovascular injury resulting in improved stroke outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE: ANALYTICAL VALIDATION OF FRATAXIN PROTEOFORMS IN BLOOD AS BIOMARKERS OF FRIEDREICH’S ATAXIA Friedreich’s ataxia (FA) is an autosomal recessive disease caused by an intronic GAA triplet expansion in the FXN gene, leading to reduced expression of the mitochondrial protein frataxin. We recently found that there is an extra-mitochondrial form of frataxin expressed in erythrocytes (isoform E) and that both proteoforms are reduced by > 70 % in blood from FA patients when compared with healthy control subjects. The present proposal will develop rigorously validated assays that address all of the pre-analytical and analytical issues that are relevant to the use of whole blood as a biological matrix for frataxin proteoform biomarker analysis in healthy controls, FA carriers and FA patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Mycophenolic acid, an approved drug used to prevent rejection in organ transplant patients, cause chronic diarrhea that could last for years, which significantly affect patients' quality of lives. The long-term goal of this application is to develop safe and effective drugs to reduce incidence and severity of diarrhea in these patients to improve therapeutic outcomes. We propose to use dietary components that are only present in the gut to boost gut detoxification without affecting drug in the plasma to maintain therapeutic efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy (ACM) is a significant cause of sudden cardiac death and end stage heart failure. Disease-causing genetic abnormalities for ACM tend to cluster near each other within each gene. This study will capitalize on this recent advancement to discover novel disease-causing gene interactions, and to design a new therapy for a variety of genetic abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis infection of the central nervous system is the most devastating form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. It is associated with a robust immune response that drives inflammation and accumulation of excess fluid (edema) in the brain. The recently re-discovered brain associated lymphatics regulate fluid drainage and immunity by controlling vessel volume and antigen trafficking to the lymph node. We have discovered that brain TB induced lymphangiogenesis and increased drainage from the brain. This proposal investigates how lymphatic regulation affects immunity and protection against TB and will test the effects of agents that increase or diminish the brain-draining lymphoid vessels on the outcome of brain tuberculosis in a murine model. This data will help broaden our understanding of the role of brain drainage in neuroinflammation using a CNS-infection model associated with different brain pathologies and may lead to new strategies in brain tuberculosis treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to develop novel and effective therapies utilizing a unique multipotent stem cell population to reverse age-related neuromuscular dysfunction common in the elderly, thereby improving overall health. Knowledge obtained will define the mechanism(s) by which young stem cells promote neuromuscular health and function, identify the anti-aging factors secreted by young stem cells that may be used therapeutically, and expedite effective clinical translation for rejuvenation therapies. Together these studies will significantly advance our efforts to enhance the functional abilities of older adults, leading to healthier aging and a better quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects 10% of the United States adult population, and with serious cardiac and ischemic complications for half of these patients. Anti-hyperlipidemic therapies do not fully address the burden of ASCVD in the population. The research and training proposed in this application are relevant to public health because they increase our understanding of the cellular mechanisms associated with atherosclerosis development, progression, and potential resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A subset of prostate cancers evolve in the face of therapy to look less like a typical prostate cancer and more like a small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma, as a means to bypass treatment. Here, we will integrate patient data and preclinical models to assess the molecular mechanisms driving drug resistance and determine how lineage specific transcription factors regulate cellular reprogramming and the tumor's epigenetic state to facilitate this change in identify. We will identify the context and cooperation of key drivers of disease progression and drug resistance that will lead to new strategies to improve the early detection, treatment, and mortality of patients with treatment resistant prostate cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal addresses immune-regulatory roles of the main T cell population of the body, the intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs), in colorectal cancer. The proposed studies will shed light on possible protective anti-tumor, as well as pro-tumorigenic roles of these mucosal immune cells against intestinal cancers, opening entirely new avenues for the design of novel immune-based therapeutic approaches against cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Transgender-specific Differentiated HIV Care Models:  An Implementation Science Study PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite a disproportionate burden of HIV, transgender people are less likely to achieve viral suppression than the general population and have low engagement in PrEP services. Transgender-specific differentiated service delivery models have the potential to overcome barriers to HIV service engagement. This study will advance the science on effective HIV care and prevention strategies for transgender people by assessing the implementation, effectiveness, and cost of transgender-specific differentiated service delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is designed to assist Dr. Balantekin in establishing an independent research career in the fields of obesity and disordered eating by providing training, experience, and mentorship in the areas of: 1) identifying novel treatment targets; 2) applying basic behavioral science principles towards understanding eating behavior; 3) translating lab-based studies into interventions; 4) learning novel statistical approaches for analyzing longitudinal and eating behavior data. Loss of control eating, or the feeling that one cannot control what or how much one is eating, is prevalent among children across with weight spectrum, and is associated with increased obesity risk and metabolic dysfunction. The proposed study aims to explore the relationships among LOC eating, parental restriction, and the reinforcing value of food with respect to obesity risk.

PHR: Overall Project Narrative Improving the public’s health is a significant initiative that involves a massive, complex mixture of professionals and organizations working together to achieve the mission of ensuring a healthier population. The mission can only be achieved when evidence-based information is made easily, openly, and freely available to healthcare professionals, the public health workforce, librarians, patients, researchers, educators, community-based organizations, and others dedicated to improving the health of local communities and the Nation. Region 7, through its network of partners, such as libraries, health-related institutions, and community-based organizations, provides the infrastructure, products, and services for the provision of equal access to authoritative biomedical information to those who need it, in the format they want, and at the desired time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Rewards motivate behavior, and the prospect of reward shapes how we perform our actions. However, the mechanisms by which reward influences the fine details of our movements are not known. Experiments in this proposal will dissect the influence of reward on motor cortex in a variety of reward contexts, with the goal of determining the subconscious difference between practice and game-time, why breakdown of behavior often occurs in the face of large stakes, and the implications these processes have for learning and motor rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Despite the success of antiretroviral therapy (ART), HIV-1 cannot be eradicated and worldwide incidence rates have been declining slowly. Efforts to identify novel strategies to prevent new infections and eradicate or induce HIV-1 remission are critical. Broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) have emerged as an attractive new strategy against HIV-1, however bNAbs are vulnerable to escape by viral variants which underscores the need for greater understanding of the underlying mechanisms of bNAb resistance to guide the successful clinical development of this approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: National Public Health Coordinating Office Project Narrative Public Health Departments and agencies are on the front line for delivery of basic public health services to most of the communities in this country. The majority of health departments and agencies provide a wide variety of services to very diverse communities with limited resources and staff. The services provided vary widely from state to state, from urban to rural areas, and are especially adapted to address local priorities and concerns. Despite considerable variation, however, health departments provide essential services: adult and childhood immunizations; communicable disease control; community outreach and education; epidemiology and surveillance; environmental health regulation such as food safety services and restaurant inspections; and tuberculosis testing. The NPHCO program seeks to promote the use evidence- based information and NLM resources, including the Public Health Digital Library, to strengthen the capacity for research, practice, and continuing education.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative The thymus atrophies precipitously beginning relatively early in life, resulting in declining production of new, naïve T cells, driving a shift toward an oligoclonal T cell memory, leaving the elderly less responsive to vaccines and new infections, especially viral infections. We recently showed that paracrine signaling between medullary and cortical thymic epithelial cells (TEC) involving the mammalian target of rapamycin pathway, is a key regulator of thymus growth. In this study we will generate new mTEC tissue-specific mouse models to test the hypothesis that paracrine fibroblast growth factor 21 (FGF21) signals are required for thymus growth and maintenance during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ambient levels of air pollution may be an important but underappreciated contributor to racial/ethnic disparities in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). Novel approaches can be applied to understand how vulnerability to air pollution in racially/ethnically diverse cohorts impact ADRD outcomes. The proposed research is critical for understanding root causes of health disparities and informing environmental policies with potential evidence-based impacts on health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tendon ruptures and tendinopathies are painful and debilitating conditions affecting a large portion of the adult population. From a regenerative standpoint, there is a pressing clinical need to identify the cell and molecular mechanisms regulating tendon induction and differentiation in order to develop novel therapies to improve repair outcomes. The objective of this proposal is to apply mESCs and hiPSCs to model tendon development, identify new transcriptional regulators, and induce regenerative capacity in established tendon injury models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE STATEMENT Aging increases bone loss, fractures, disability, and frailty. Aging process is linked with increasing inflammation which if not resolved, causes progressive decline of skeletal function. This project studies the underlying mechanism that causes loss of bone function by studying specialized cells that can produce inflammation due to progressive accumulation of fat within bone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Protein synthesis is important for cell viability and is subjected to multiple regulatory mechanisms. Our preliminary data show that the intracellular bacterium Legionella pneumophila induces global protein synthesis inhibition by phosphorylating a single residue in the chaperone HSC70 (pHSC70). Here we propose to understand the mechanisms by which this phosphorylation affects protein synthesis and the host stress response pathways that can lead to pHSC70 and protein synthesis inhibition.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Circadian timing of the preovulatory surge in GnRH and LH secretion is critical in regulating ovulation and reproductive success in rodents as well as, possibly, in women. This proposal will provide new knowledge of the neural circuits that govern the circadian activation of kisspeptin neurons – a cell population essential for the preovulatory surge under physiological conditions. This research, when completed, may provide the foundation for future opportunities in treating ovulatory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathy (ACM) is a familial disease characterized by early-onset ventricular arrhythmias arising in the absence of overt cardiac remodeling, with subsequent development and progression of heart failure. This application focuses on the critical interactions between external factors imposed by exercise and genetic factors caused by mutations in the intercalated disc protein desmoplakin. We will develop next generation therapies for ACM that target the abnormal signaling cascade that the interaction between exercise and DSP haploinsufficiency unleashes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aggressive behavior in pituitary tumors is defined by rapid growth following standard treatment (surgery and radiation); at present, there are no biomarkers that reliably predict future aggressive behavior. We aim to identify these biomarkers by performing genetic and epigenic profiling on a unique cohort that includes patients with malignant tumors. The ability to identify patients with life-limiting tumors at an earlier stage would improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults decide to have major elective surgery hoping for improved function or longer life, but some will experience a long-term decline in cognition after surgery. This study will use two large, diverse databases of older adults to create and test a mathematical model predicting whether an individual is likely to be at risk of memory decline, dementia, and/or loss of function (ability to manage medicines and money independently) two years after major surgery. Accurate, individualized predictions for patient-centered cognitive outcomes will help clinicians and older adults talk about what to expect after surgery and ensure that choosing to have elective surgery meets older adults’ goals for cognitive health in late life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: To enhance understanding the microbiome's dynamic role in disease progression, and explore its clinical potential, we will develop two sets of analytic methods designed to 1) detect genome-wide microbial variants, identify strains within species, and estimate strain relative abundance using longitudinal metagenomics samples and 2) develop, validate, and apply the microbial risk scores in disease prediction. Further, we will validate the proposed tools in multiple longitudinal microbiome studies; explore new insights; and develop, distribute, and support open-source software packages to apply the tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Neutrophils are the first line of defense against infection and exhibit a unique cell-killing mechanism called trogoptosis (“gnawing”), based on successive puncturing of cancer cell membranes. We investigate the efficacy of this mechanism in the context of different tumor cell surface markers as well as the extracellular matrix. We envision that neutrophil trogoptosis can be therapeutically enhanced for anti-tumor activity in combination with adjuvant drug therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Half of patients with heart failure have preserved heart pumping function, with limited tools to prevent, diagnose, and treat this condition. The body’s response to the stress of exercise may uncover abnormalities not apparent at rest that can help to diagnose heart failure with preserved ejection fraction before the onset of symptoms. Here, we measure a large number of proteins in the blood and compare them with patterns of a person’s response to exercise to better understand this disease, its earlier forms, and potential treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Osteochondral tissue injuries remain a significant challenge in the orthopedics community, as they affect millions of people each year throughout the world and there are few viable treatment options. We propose to engineer prevascularized osteochondral tissue constructs using direct assembly of individual human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) and human endothelial progenitor cells (hEPCs) via 3D bioprinting into a temporary photocurable microgel slurry supporting medium with spatiotemporally controlled delivery of tissue-specific growth factors. This new strategy to create functional osteochondral tissue through printing of a carrier-free cell-only bioink to form complex cellular condensations may represent a powerful clinical therapeutic advance to treat and improve the lives of patients suffering from osteochondral tissue damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no effective treatments for patients with advanced cholangiocarcinoma (CCA); less than 10% of patients survive a year after diagnosis. Our data support the hypothesis that combining gemcitabine, a current standard of care for CCA, with a BETi + a PARPi comprises effective therapy for CCA even in tumor models that are insensitive to gemcitabine. Since mechanistic data in this application show that BETi decrease expression of DNA repair proteins that contribute to gemcitabine resistance and that PARPi augment this effect, we will determine the extent to which sequential administration of a BETi + PARPi decreases levels of DNA repair proteins and subsequent administration of gemcitabine produces durable tumor regressions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will evaluate a new therapeutic strategy to control joint-level inflammation following acute joint trauma or within an osteoarthritic joint. In our approach, we seek to modify the local metabolism of an injured joint by delivering an immunomodulatory enzyme. With this enzyme, we aim to produce anti-inflammatory metabolites within the diseased joint, and thereby control joint pain and reduce pathologic remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rapid diagnosis of bacterial sepsis and timely initiation of antibiotics is crucial for reducing neonatal mortality and improving morbidity. However, subtle clinical signs and inaccurate laboratory tests make rapid diagnosis especially difficult in infants. We will develop a novel infant sepsis early recognition system to improve clinician recognition by improving situation awareness, with a goal of improving infant sepsis outcomes in a future clinical trial.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Male germ cell differentiation relies on expressing the correct suite of proteins at the correct time, which is achieved via regulated mRNA translation. This work aims to determine how a novel RNA binding protein regulates the timing and location of mRNA translation in meiotic germ cells. The outcome of this work may improve our ability to treat male infertility and develop male contraceptives along with informing on the fundamental process of mRNA translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infection with Shigella spp. resistant to first and second-line WHO recommended antibacterial treatments is rapidly increasing worldwide, and there is an urgent need for new therapeutic options. However, it still is not clear what pharmacokinetic parameters are associated with efficacy or emergence of resistance for any shigellosis treatment. Our proposed studies aim to determine antibacterial pharmacokinetic properties that contribute to their in vivo efficacy and emergence of resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it addresses a novel mechanism increasing progression of clonal hematopoiesis a common event in older individuals may lead to increased morbidity and risk of bone marrow failure and malignancy. If successful, it will provide a scientific basis for development of new strategies to prevent and/or treat these pathologies. It is also expected to advance the field of aging biology by elucidating how clonal hematopoiesis causes inflammation. This is highly relevant to the NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mobile app mental health interventions are accessible and effective when used at the recommended dose; but when implemented in routine care, patients do not stay engaged long enough to see clinical benefits. The proposed research evaluates what drives patient engagement and tests the impact of two strategies— automated motivational push messaging and coach support—to improve engagement with an evidence-based mobile app intervention for depression and/or anxiety. Findings will lay the foundation for a program of research focused on optimizing mobile app interventions for engagement and effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of deaths due to opioid overdose continue to increase each year and rates are rising faster for Black people than for any other racial/ethnic group. Interventions are critically needed that can effectively reduce overdose mortality and do so equitably for Black people. The results of this study will quantify the effectiveness of policy interventions for the opioid crisis and identify the sets of provisions that best reduce overdose mortality overall and specifically among Black people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Student Opportunities for AIDS/HIV Research (SOAR) is a multi-component theory-based two-year long research education mentoring program for University of Michigan undergraduate students from NIH-designated groups that are underrepresented in the biomedical, clinical, behavioral and social sciences (URM: NOT-OD- 20-031). Given the program's thematic focus on HIV-centered behavioral and social science research priorities within sexual and gender minority (SGM) communities, we will also encourage participation from URM students who identify as SGM (NOT-OD-19-139). SOAR is grounded in the expanded Social Cognitive Career Theory; patterned after the evidence-based U.S. Department of Education funded Ronald E. McNair Post- baccalaureate Achievement Program; incorporates elements of the evidence-based research mentoring program Entering Mentoring and the evidence-based research mentee program Entering Research; and allows for two years of intensive faculty-mentored research experiences for undergraduate students interested in pursuing doctoral education leading to a research career in the mental health of HIV/AIDS.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Research Fellowship has prepared many generations of physicians and Ph.D. scientists for a successful research career in geriatric mood disorders over 30 years. We have transformed our training in response to changes in science, the National Academy of Medicine mandates, the 2020 NIMH Strategic Plan Draft, the RDoC Project, and the evolution of our research team. We request to extend the fellowship for another 5 years, as we believe that our future ability to reduce the burden of mid- and late-life mood disorders rests on the development of tomorrow's science leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Cerebral glucose hypometabolism is now considered one of the hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), clinical AD symptoms almost never occur in the absence glucose hypometabolism, and the extent of the metabolic changes measured strongly correlate with the severity of clinical symptoms. The mechanism(s) that drive glucose hypometabolism remain a critical knowledge gap in AD research. This proposal aims to examine age- related changed in cerebral glucose metabolism in both healthy and AD mouse models to 1) improve our understanding in the metabolic aging process and 2) to identify divergent events that result in the onset of AD from the aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis, the leading infectious killer worldwide, is associated with lung injury which can persist despite successful therapy. This persistent lung injury is an important contributor to excess morbidity and mortality in treated tuberculosis. In this study, we will characterize the phenotype, progression and immune correlates of post-tuberculosis chronic lung disease to inform future preventive and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Numerous human diseases and syndromes are caused by disturbances in gene expression, and an important component in this process is the ability of cells to complete the production of mRNAs from the genome. The goal of the work described in this proposal is to understand how a multifunctional protein complexes balances gene expression during stress. The complex that is the focus of this proposal have been implicated in DNA damage resistance, cell proliferation and cardiovascular development; thus, the work described here is directly relevant to human health.!

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many rural hospitals are in financial distress and face challenges that contribute to poor access to care and poor health outcomes for cancer patients living in rural areas. This project will assess the impact of an innovative state program, which changes the way rural hospitals are paid and encourages new approaches to health care delivery, on surgery for rural cancer patients. Results will provide timely evidence about strategies to address the needs of surgical cancer patients in rural communities throughout the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to show that many adolescent schoolchildren with the early stage of new TB infection have a previously undetected case of active TB disease in their household, a finding that would fundamentally change the understanding of TB transmission to adolescents. Very importantly this finding would lead to an innovative new public health method to identify previously undetected cases of TB disease, a major goal of the global plan to eliminate tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Non-traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage, bleeding into the subarachnoid space around the brain from the rupture of an aneurysm, is a potentially devastating and often deadly subtype of stroke. There is a great need for ways to accurately identify and treat patients most at risk for neurologic deterioration from complications like cerebral vasospasm or delayed cerebral ischemia. Adequate blood pressure management tailored to individual patients, aiming to maintain optimal brain blood flow and function, may prevent additional brain injury and is an important first step towards personalized medicine for patients suffering from subarachnoid hemorrhage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term health of kidney transplant patients in the United States depends critically on the immunosuppressive drugs that are taken by such patients long-term during the duration of their transplant function. This project aims to improve the safety and efficacy of these immunosuppressive strategies by modeling new strategies in a closely related non-human primate (NHP) species, rhesus monkey, that share 97% genetic identity with humans. Lessons learned from our previous and ongoing work from our prior U19 NIH award is already being translated into human clinical trials, and we anticipate further advances to move into clinical trials to help further prolong kidney transplant function and patient survival, thus extending the lifespan and quality of life of patients with kidney failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this study, we develop and use state-of-the-art proteomics to characterize Tau, its modifications and the modification-causing enzymes in primary post mortem brain tissue samples from patients with varying stages of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Large datasets from primary human tissue provides target prioritization information for functional follow-up experiments to identify which Tau modifications and the modification-causing enzymes in AD that lead to disease progression. The aim of this work is to identify therapeutic strategies for AD in early stages of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 2 Building on knowledge gained during our previous NHPCSG U19 award, this project aims to test clinically- feasible agents targeting post-transplant humoral response and determine efficacy of antigen-specific tolerance strategies for kidney transplantation in sensitized nonhuman primate recipients. It further aims to evaluate the protective and vaccine immune response after theseapproaches. Lastly, this project will determine the functional profile of allo-, viral- ,and vaccine-specific T and B cell required to establish donor-specific tolerance in sensitized recipients at repertoire levels using the cutting-edge technology of single cell immune repertoire sequencing to precisely identify molecular mechanisms of transplantation tolerance and its interaction with viral pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen that causes cryptococcal meningitis, a severe HIV-associated infection of the central nervous system. In healthy individuals, C. neoformans establishes latent infections that reactivate and cause clinical symptoms upon HIV-associated immunosuppression, yet disease manifestation differs across patients. Using a mouse model, this research will determine the continuum of patient immune responses and fungal genetic factors that influence clinical outcome towards the goal of developing novel immune-modulatory treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Dysregulated intestinal inflammation results in mucosal injury and impaired healing responses. Efficient repair of intestinal mucosa is dependent on complex events involving crosstalk between receptors on the epithelium as well as immune cells that are recruited to sites of injury. A better understanding of complex interplay between inflammatory cells and epithelial cells in orchestrating mucosal repair may provide ideas for druggable targets to promote healing during mucosal inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 1 Strongly based on knowledge gained during ourpreviousNHPCSG U19 award, this project aims to test clinically- feasible tolerance strategies for both living and deceased donor kidney transplantation. It further aims to determine the host susceptibility and stability of tolerance in settings of unexpected post-transplant viral infections, abruptly brought into a sharp focus by the most recent SARS-CoV2 pandemic. Lastly, this project will employ the cutting-edge technology of single cell immune repertoire sequencing to precisely identify molecular mechanisms of transplantation tolerance and its interaction with viral pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension affects 75% of older adults in the United States and current treatment options, inclusive of exercise training, are ineffective given only 21% of adults with hypertension have their blood pressure under control. We propose exercise training combined with chronotherapy will improve the effectiveness of this treatment option and plan to demonstrate this through a series of studies examining morning versus late afternoon/evening exercise on blood pressure and vascular health outcomes in older adults with hypertension. We expect this research will optimize exercise prescriptions for adults with hypertension which in turn will enhance their health and reduce the prevalence of hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory hypersensitivity is a central issue in autism and autism-related disorders like Fragile X syndrome (FX), and relatively little is known about the underlying brain mechanisms. This proposal combines novel behavioral assays for assessing sound hypersensitivity in rodents with state-of-the-art electrophysiological, chemogenetic, and analytical techniques to determine the currently poorly understood nature of auditory perceptual and circuit abnormalities in FX. Results from this study will uncover fundamental neural disruptions at the core of FX and autism as well as provide a clinically translatable platform for screening potential therapies for auditory disturbances in these common and debilitating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will investigate if exposure to greater neighborhood greenspace in early, mid, and late- life is associated with healthy brain aging as measured via regional brain volumes and longitudinal decline on multiple cognitive domains. The study will assess whether there are critical periods in which greenspace exposure may be most beneficial, as well as potential effect modification by sex, race, apolipoprotein E (genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease), and geographic region. The ultimate goal is to provide evidence for community-level interventions that can increase cognitive resilience and healthy behaviors throughout the lifespan, promoting healthy brain aging and allowing older adults to age in place.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop and validate a novel sustainable, easy-to-use phenotypic drug susceptibility testing (DST) test for drug resistant tuberculosis (TB) using non-invasive specimens (i.e. sputum). We will focus on validating and confirming drugs recently approved by WHO to treat drug susceptible (RIPE and HPMZ drug regimens) and resistant (BPaL drug regimen) TB and confirm its efficacy against current phenotypic DST reference tests. This new DST test will be validated further in field settings (Democratic Republic of Congo and the US-Mexico border), where TB is a major health issue and is under-reported due to lack of widely available diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Based on a 35-year track record, reflected in our latest Medical Student Research Program followup, we anticipate cultivating a large number of diverse inquiring scientific physicians who understand and can contribute to the research enterprise (emphasizing cardiovascular, lung, and blood disorders, mechanisms, evaluation, and therapy), including a growing cadre of physician-scientist leaders to replenish the dwindling numbers of translational medical researchers. In this way, we will contribute to the concerted effort of NIH and NHLBI to build the diverse enlightened medical research teams of the future, to provide the latest in personalized care and precision medicine, and thereby to expedite the translation of scientific advances from “bench to bedside to diverse community”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute graft-versus-host disease (aGVHD) is a major complication of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, and improved therapies for aGVHD are needed. To develop potential new targets for improving aGVHD, our group recently identified a novel T cell-enriched long noncoding RNA, LINC00402, that uniquely promotes allogeneic T-cell proliferation. We now seek to determine LINC00402’s function and molecular mechanism in both mice and humans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Persons with epilepsy often suffer from memory problems that may improve with a 6-week exercise program. We will investigate (1) the degree of memory improvement with exercise, (2) if the exercise program positively affects the brain regions involved in memory, and (3) whether the effects of exercise on memory and the brain can outlast the exercise program. This study would greatly impact our ability to treat memory problems in persons with epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Chronic stress causes molecular adaptations and structural remodeling of neurons, which leads to behavioral and cognitive deficits. Our work shows that neuronal activity-induced DNA double strand breaks (DSBs), which regulate the expression of genes that mediate experience-driven synaptic changes, are also increased in stress-activated neurons. By mapping the sites that incur DSBs following chronic stress and deciphering the role of DSBs in stress-induced gene activity patterns and neuronal remodeling, this project will enhance fundamental knowledge of how stressful experiences cause lasting changes in behavior.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will investigate how school-age children who were born preterm learn new motor skills, if there are differences in motor learning between preterm and term born children, and if this contributes to atypical movement development. Information about motor learning differences in preterm children can lead toward timely and targeted physical and occupational therapy interventions that may help improve motor abilities, allowing children to fully participate in school and maximize their independence as they mature toward adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women in the US Census racial/ethnic categories of Hispanic/Latina and Asian American/Pacific Islander have relatively lower incidence of breast cancer but are more likely to be diagnosed with the more aggressive human epidermal growth factor receptor (HER2) positive tumors compared to non-Hispanic White and non-Hispanic Black women. The use of European-centric research to predict cancer risk and prognosis in non-Europeans remains a critical barrier for equity in the implementation of precision medicine. The current proposed project aims to fill in the gap of knowledge regarding the genetic underpinnings of HER2 positive breast cancer in women of Latin American and Asian heritage, to enable the benefit of precision medicine in non-European populations, ensuring that the advances in medicine may be more equitably applied for public health in diverse populations.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: CGRP inhibitors are now available for migraine prevention and treatment, so we will study the effects of chronic CGRP antagonism on bone healing. We aim to understand the cellular and molecular mechanism by which CGRP/CLR signaling can affect bone fracture healing. Understanding how CGRP/CLR sensory signaling influence fracture healing can pave the way for more targeted therapies for bone healing in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Our goal is to develop an online, flow-through, affinity assay that can continuously monitor the efflux of biochemical messengers from dynamically changing biological systems in real time. Our premise is that microfluidic integration of a perfusion chamber, online mixing of affinity reagents and continuous micro free flow electrophoresis (µFFE) separations will directly address limitations that have prevented the development of time responsive affinity-based assays to date. Continuous affinity µFFE assays will enable researchers to study how biochemical messenger systems (i.e. neurotransmission, energy regulation and immune response) change over time or respond to external stimuli.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eukaryotic circadian clocks impact nearly every aspect of physiology behavior. Their dysfunction contributes to cancer, as well as to mental illness (e.g., depression) and to metabolic diseases (e.g., diabetes). While we know a great deal about the details of molecular timekeeping within pacemaker cells, we know relatively little about how clock information is used. Circadian output generates a series of signals representing phase markers, according to which diverse downstream tissues and circuits bias their daily temporal activities. We will study the generation of circadian phase in Drosophila at the levels of behavior, neurophysiology, neuroendocrinology and intracellular signaling pathways. The detailed mechanisms thus revealed will help define how clock information underlies normal physiology and also pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysfunctions of the immune system of the pancreas are involved in major pancreatic diseases such as pancreatic cancers and diabetes. Here we propose novel mechanisms of disease due to the crosstalk of pancreas with intestinal and hepatic immunity, mediated by the anatomical co-drainage into lymph nodes. Lymph node sharing with gut and liver exposes the pancreatic immune system to a new, previously unsuspected range of infectious and toxic challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The nervous system has the remarkable ability to sustain its function over lifetime of an organism. The goals of this research program are to advance our knowledge of how axons and synapses are formed and maintained, and the proposed experiments will identify new mechanisms underlying dynamic cellular processes that ensure function of neural circuits. The findings will offer fundamental insights into how genetic mutations and environmental insults cause dys-regulation of neural circuits, leading to neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The indirect impacts of disasters—morbidity and mortality due to compromised conditions such as food security and clean water—are typically not included in estimates of disaster deaths. Child health is particularly sensitive to such compromised conditions and understanding the indirect burden of disasters on child health is central for designing mitigation and adaptation strategies. This project aims to estimate the indirect child mortality burden from floods and severe storms around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Members of the Black community are at higher risk for cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease. This project proposes to investigate several risk factors that contribute to cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease, including social, neuroimaging, and genetic factors. Findings from this study may contribute to our understanding of contributors to cognitive decline, which has the potential to inform risk of future impairment and prevention for Black individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women at high risk for breast cancer can decide to supplement breast cancer screening with MRI, but lack of awareness and access may prevent high-risk Black and Latina women from making an informed decision about breast MRI. The proposed study will develop and test a multilevel intervention to support informed decision- making about breast MRI among high-risk Black and Latina women. If demonstrated to increase informed deci- sions, this approach can be translated to any new preference-sensitive, risk-based cancer screening modality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescence is a vulnerable time period when insufficient and mistimed sleep may affect cardiometabolic risk factors including adiposity, high blood pressure, and insulin resistance. To understand which aspects of sleep to intervene on, there is an urgent need to disentangle the independent contributions of short sleep duration and delayed sleep timing (proxy for circadian rhythm misalignment) to cardiometabolic risk. Examining the epigenetic pathways that link sleep duration and timing with prospective cardiometabolic risk provides a novel way to distinguish these relationships and to gain mechanistic insights.
