IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE Americans experience between 200,000 and 700,000 new cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) each year, with estimates varying widely due to the likelihood of under-reporting. Thirty to fifty percent of all DVT patients develop the morbid post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS), which is a national health crisis. There is no effective treatment for DVT that is meant to avoid PTS, which limits the application of vein-clearing mechanical therapies that can provide immediate benefits. Development of therapies that specifically target the development of PTS are therefore critical in the overall treatment paradigm for DVT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compared to health/care interventions that require in-person attendance, the advantages that digital health interventions (DHIs) offer – for advancing research and end-user perspectives (e.g., participants, clients) – are ten-fold. Yet, extensive resources are required to develop DHIs and there are currently no viable solutions for the long-term sustainability and maintenance of DHIs. The proposed 1-year SBIR Phase 1 project has a solution to these challenges by developing a functional software prototype of the HERO (Health/care Environment for Research and Organization programs) platform that will be secure, HIPAA compliant, intuitive to use, and state- of-the-art by including a suite of menu options with both a user and admin portal interfaces to create and/or host DHIs over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The organ transplantation process has many inefficiencies and significant issues that result in less than optimal patient outcomes and impacts to valuable clinical resources. Our product, TransplantAI, aims to transform the organ matching process. By utilizing advanced AI algorithms, large proprietary datasets and access to world renowned medical experts at leading transplant centers and organ procurement organizations (OPOs), the InformAI team plans to address limitations of current transplant analytic models by enhancing data insights into organ discard, waitlist mortality and post transplant survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Modern human lifestyles powered by technological advances and demanding work schedules often impinge on robust daily rhythms of physiology and behavior, which are hallmarks of healthspan This project aims to understand the molecular mechanisms by which metabolic signals from feeding-fasting cycles interact with environmental time cues to orchestrate temporal changes in physiology. Our findings will shed light on the impact of disrupting metabolic regulation of daily rhythms and pave the way to new therapeutic targets for circadian and metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deterioration of the retina, the light-sensing portion of the eye, is caused by a number of incurable inherited diseases that result in progressive vision loss and blindness. This proposal focuses on determining how mutations in the metabolic enzyme IMPDH1 cause dominant forms of inherited photoreceptor degeneration. We aim to determine the normal physiological role of IMPDH1 in photoreceptors, and how this is perturbed in blind patients with degenerative disease due to IMPDH1 mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bariatric surgery could provide considerable health benefit to the 30 million Americans living with severe obesity, but the associated risk of bone loss and fracture is concerning to both patients and providers. This ancillary study to an ongoing clinical trial is designed to test whether a first-line antiresorptive medication for osteoporosis can preserve bone microarchitecture, density, and strength in the year after bariatric surgery. This will improve our understanding of antiresorptive treatment efficacy in bariatric surgery patients, and offer insight on the underlying biological mechanisms of action for preventing bone microstructure deterioration, which is increasingly recognized as an independent predictor of fracture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Typical indoor air pollutants include CO, VOCs, nitrogen oxides, benzene, and formaldehyde. As people spend ~90% of their time indoors, the EPA considers indoor air pollution to be one of the top five environmental risks to public health (EPA 2019). Particularly important are chlorinated VOCs, which are known to increase the risk of cancer from 1 in a million to 1 in 100,000 at 4 ppb, typical concentrations observed in indoor air (WHO Guidelines for Indoor Air Quality: Selected Pollutants 2010). Our technology will reduce the high risk VOCs and other common pollutants to less than 4 ppb to reduce health risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) with residual low-frequency hearing impairs patients’ ability to understand speech, afflicts more than 3.3 million Americans, and annually costs more than $100B between health care and lost productivity. Current treatments are inadequate and destructive, leading to loss of residual hearing, but extracochlear stimulation of the spiral ganglion promises a minimally invasive method to restore speech understanding in affected individuals. In the proposed project, Auricle will iterate the design of its stimulation electrode and conduct an animal study to confirm long-term effectiveness of the implant, delivering proof-of-concept for its innovative strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative No dual modality probe of the type that is required for super-resolution correlated light electron microscopy (CLEM) is readily available. To enable elucidation of cellular and detailed subcellular structures at the pseudoatomic level using super-resolution CLEM, Photon Biosciences proposes a novel genetically expressible probe that has high electron density and luminescence necessary to act as a dual-modality probe for both modes of imaging. This novel and innovative probe for super-resolution CLEM will enable biomedical innovations that require modeling regions of interest inside a cell to a pseudoatomic level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, eye surgeries are the most frequently performed surgical interventions aimed at mitigating the adverse effects of vision loss that can significantly impact the quality of life of individuals and their families, and pose serious safety risks, necessitating long-term care. Effective ophthalmic intraoperative visualization is crucial for achieving favorable surgical outcomes in the treatment of eye diseases. To enhance visualization and consequently improve surgical outcomes, we are developing a System on Chip to enable Swept-Source Optical Coherence Tomography to provide real-time 3- dimensional imaging with high-resolution, high-speed, low-latency, and the capacity to handle large volume scans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The proposed research focuses on the further advancement of a candidate vaccine that protects against chikungunya virus (CHIKV) which causes debilitating disease in humans. The vaccine is based on an established recombinant subunit platform for producing viral envelope proteins. Although CHIKV is not yet prevalent in the U.S., recent epidemics in the Americas provide the potential for the virus to become endemic in the U.S. and its territories. CHIKV is classified as a category C priority pathogen and has been identified as a prototype pathogen for the Togaviridae family of viruses in NIAID’s Pandemic Preparedness Plan. A successful CHIKV vaccine would also streamline the rapid development of vaccines for other Togaviruses with pandemic potential.

PHR: NARRATIVE The long-term vision of CryoCrate LLC related to this project is to commercialize a “First-in-Class” biocompatible cryopreservation medium product, OdinSol®, which eliminates the need for any toxic cell permeating cryoprotectant used in traditional cryopreservation methods. This novel technology will provide enabling and efficient options for biobanking urgently needed for the development and implementation of cell-based therapeutics and tissue engineering in personalized medicine and other emerging biomedical technologies. In this project, we will obtain qualifications associated with Good Manufacturing Practice production, biocompatibility, safety and efficacy testing, and secure 510(k) clearance, to pave the path to commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Fifty percent of alcoholic liver disease (ALD) patients have alcohol recidivism within the first five years of transplantation, and advanced fibrosis or graft loss occurs in approximately 20% of those patients. We have found that the ceramide synthesizing enzyme ceramide synthase 6 is upregulated early in ALD at the stage of steatosis and regulates the development of fatty liver. This project aims to understand how CerS6 specifically regulates proteins involved in liver fat development and how CerS6 and its ceramides can be used as early biomarkers of ALD in patients with both pre- and post-transplant ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Motor symptoms of Parkinson’s disease remain a major disability for a large number of patients over the chronic course of the disease because currently available treatments provide only partial improvement. This project investigates a novel therapeutic strategy to selectively target genes in affected brain areas. Results of these preclinical studies can lead to clinical tests of a new gene therapy to improve mobility in patients with Parkinson’s disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug overdose deaths, misuse and substance use disorders (SUDs) collectively constitute a major, high-impact health problem in the U.S. This competitive renewal of the training grant Translational Explorations in Substance Use Disorders (T32 DA007287) at the University of Texas Medical Branch addresses the large gap between the problem of SUDs and efficacious solutions by applying innovative mentoring and research approaches to fully equipping the next generation of SUD scientists to greatly enhance therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This project is focused on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on pain management for Veterans with chronic low back pain. Chronic low back pain is the most common form of chronic pain for Veterans, causing significant pain and disability. Current recommendations from experts are that Veterans receive several forms of pain management services, with an emphasis on approaches other than opioid medications. The COVID-19 pandemic may have led to substantial disruptions and changes in pain management services, including increases in telehealth. This mixed-methods project will explore changes in pain management services following the onset of COVID-19, including any persisting effects, and perceived impacts of these changes (negative and positive). Finally, the project includes a stakeholder panel comprised of operational partners, Veterans, clinicians, and other experts who will provide guidance throughout the research and ensure rapid dissemination of findings and recommendations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The microbiota protects the host from microorganisms that cause disease in unprotected or immunocompromised individuals. Enteric pathogens such as Salmonella enterica, however, are adept at circumventing and weakening these protections and in doing so render the host susceptible to infection. Here, we propose to elucidate the mechanisms by which Salmonella overcomes microbiota-mediated colonization resistance with the goal of uncovering new therapeutic strategies to restore this important protective barrier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black individuals are burdened by a constellation of socioeconomic and cardiovascular risk factors that put them at a greater risk for developing Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRDs). One potential explanation for the increased burden of these factors and overall risk for ADRDs is racially stratified educational environments and resulting experiences of discrimination, yet there is little evidence on the potential lifecourse effects of structural and interpersonal racism as a driver of racial inequalities in healthy brain aging. This study will use rigorous casual inference methods to provide new evidence on how school segregation and experiences of discrimination impact ADRDs risk and contribute to racial disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Microglia and macrophages assume diverse functional states after ischemic stroke and critically influence neuroinflammation, injury progression, and brain repair. This proposal will investigate the role of signal transducer and activator of transcription 1 (STAT1) in regulating microglial and macrophage functions and long- term stroke outcomes, and the underlying mechanisms involving inflammation resolution and neurorestoration. Positive results from this proposal may also pave the road for the potential clinical use of STAT1 inhibitor as a therapy to enhance rehabilitation and recovery, and improve the quality of life of stroke victims.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Cells lining the lower part of the oviduct retain sperm to form a reservoir before fertilization. The goal of this study is to define how complex sugars on the sperm surface and newly-discovered Siglec proteins in the reservoir surface contribute to sperm adhesion and regulation of the local immune system. The long-term outcome of our findings could result in the development of novel contraceptive targets and help us understand some of the causes of idiopathic infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) remains a deadly malignancy around the world and in the US HNSCC incidence is rising at an epidemic rate, fueled largely by the human papillomavirus (HPV). Our data indicate that generation of replication stress via RAD51 inhibition can directly target the E7 oncogene critical to HPV+HNSCC and may generate superior anti- tumor activity compared to standard of care cisplatin, when combined with radiation. We also demonstrated that targeting of RAD51 increased sensitivity to radiation in HPV-negative HNSCC, which is often refractory to conventional chemo-radiation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Familial Alzheimer’s disease (FAD) is caused by mutations in the substrate and enzyme that produce amyloid peptide, which deposits as plaques in the brain. Understanding the changes in structure and function induced by these mutations is essential to deciphering the etiology of FAD and developing strategies for the discovery of FAD therapeutics. The goal of this project is to use chemical probes along with structural and computational approaches to elucidate how FAD mutations in the enzyme, gamma-secretase, alter its structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a common cause of disability, suicide, and adverse life/health outcomes. We propose to identify the subset of people with MDD who are especially impacted by MDD. We will do this is a highly rigorous way via very similar analyses in large samples from the US, UK, Sweden, Denmark, and Norway. We will use all available data (treatment history, other medical and psychiatric problems, and genetic information). Our goal is to predict those who are likely to develop the worst forms of MDD early in their illness. Successful predictions will enable us to craft interventions in future studies to improve the health of MDD patients who are the most severely ill.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pregnant and postpartum women living with HIV (WLWH) experience high rates of hepatotoxicity with isoniazid preventive therapy (IPT), but there are limited data on underlying toxicity mechanisms in this population. Using a case-control design, the proposed research will characterize the pharmacology of isoniazid metabolites and toxicity biomarkers using metabolomics and inflammatory cytokines in pregnant and postpartum WLWH. This work will help address critical knowledge gaps in the use of IPT in this population, and also establish Dr. Kristina Brooks as an independent investigator in TB/HIV pharmacology and adverse drug reactions.

PHR: NARRATIVE Youth with type 1 diabetes (T1D), particularly those from ethnic minority and lower financial resource backgrounds, exhibit significant difficulty adhering to the complicated treatment regimen for T1D, placing them at risk for adverse acute and long-term health outcomes. Although evidence-based behavioral interventions are efficacious at improving health outcomes for youth with T1D, few families receive this care. Effective implementation strategies, or methods for increasing the integration of behavioral intervention into standard care for youth with T1D, and additional data supporting effectiveness of this intervention when delivered as part of standard care can contribute meaningfully to improving the overall health of youth with T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus is one of the most dangerous and costly bacterial pathogens in the United States. This proposal will uncover the mechanism by which the respiratory metabolism regulates virulence and advance our understanding on the adaptive mechanisms that enable this organism to be such a versatile pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Neurodegenerative Disorders, such as Alzheimer's Disease and other dementias, as well as the general aging process, are characterized the distinct loss of vital synaptic connections in the brain21; as of 2019, diseases such as this affect a devastating 57.4-million people worldwide22. The proposed research seeks to break the mold of conventional research on Neurodegeneration, exploring a unique phylum of invertebrates, the tardigrade, whose entire nervous system can survive extreme environmental stressors without observable impact on nervous system function. Our work will unveil and subsequently assess the utility of novel homologous targets for a therapeutic generation with the potential to revolutionize our understanding of the limits of fundamental animal physiology as well as neurodegenerative patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In humans, an age-related decline in neuromuscular function is associated with loss of muscle mass (sarcopenia), increased frailty and a degradation of both health and quality of life. Using three independent mouse lines, newly implicated in homeostatic plasticity, we will determine whether homeostatic plasticity functions to counteract the insidious effects of age-related neuromuscular decline over the normal lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Oligodendrocytes and microglia are two types of glial cells with critical functions in the brain. Despite their important roles in health and disease, many questions remain unanswered about the genetic mechanisms that control the development and function of these cells. The goal of this project is to use the powerful genetic and cellular approaches in the zebrafish model system to discover new genes with essential functions in oligodendrocytes and microglia. The mechanistic insight gained from these studies will advance our fundamental understanding of the central nervous system, illuminate the pathways that are disrupted in diseases of the brain, and suggest avenues toward therapies for neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease is considered the most costly and burdensome disease in the U.S, and its public health impact will only grow with the increase of 65-75 year olds in the next decade. Paralleling cardiovascular disease and cancer, it is now widely recognized that a key to slowing disease progression is early identification during pre-dementia phases. With cognitive and biomarker data beginning when participants were in their 50s, the longitudinal VETSA project stands to advance progress toward early identification, which may, in turn, improve quality of life and reduce societal burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Persons with mild cognitive impairment (PwMCI) are at higher than average risk for nonadherence to medications due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Hypertension is prevalent among PwMCI and nonadherence to medication increases the risk of accelerated cognitive decline through cerebrovascular disease. This project will adapt an existing hypertension medication self-management system to develop Medication Education, Decision Support, Reminding, and Monitoring-Memory (MEDSReM-M) to meet the needs and abilities of PwMCI and conduct an efficacy study to assess medication adherence benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to define how the ill-defined protein, FIT2, regulates: 1) the amount and types of lipids (i.e., fats) loaded onto particles (known as VLDL) that can cause heart disease; and, 2) how these resulting lipid-rich VLDL particles are captured in membrane containers that exit the part of the cell called the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER). These studies will capitalize on new mouse models having liver-specific deficiency FIT2, as well as cell culture systems that the investigators have used to decipher the molecular mechanisms that control upstream, early events during the biogenesis of VLDL in the ER. The relationship of FIT2 to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and steatohepatitis along with atherosclerosis (the basis of coronary heart disease and heart attacks) will be established, and these and all other hypothesis-driven studies will be made possible by close collaborations with other experts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overweight/obesity and loss of control eating (characterized by the sense that one cannot control what or how much one is eating) are prevalent among children and adolescents, and both are associated with serious medical and psychosocial health complications. Although our recently published data suggest that youth with these conditions may have relative deficits in neurocognitive functioning, particularly working memory, understanding of how these processes and their neural correlates are related to change and stability in eating- and weight-related outcomes over time is limited, thereby impeding development of targeted, optimally timed interventions. The proposed study aims to assess prospective associations between general and food-specific executive functioning and underlying neural substrates, and eating and weight outcomes among children at varying levels of risk overweight/obesity and eating disorders, which will help guide research efforts towards the development of effective prevention and intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of HIV among female sex workers (FSW) in South Africa is disproportionally high and addressing the treatment needs of FSW is critical to supporting optimal health and wellbeing, reducing onward transmission, and altering the HIV epidemic; how to feasibly and effectively implement strategies to support the unmet needs of those most marginalized remains often unclear. This study will leverage existing data collected over 18-months among a cohort of 777 non-virally suppressed FSW living with HIV to understanding longitudinal patterns of engagement with HIV treatment support strategies, the role engagement had on sustained retention and viral suppression, and the mechanisms through which implementation outcomes (i.e., fidelity, feasibility, and appropriateness) influenced sustained retention and viral suppression. Results will inform the measurement, optimization, and dissemination of HIV implementation strategies aimed to increase HIV treatment access, retention, and viral suppression among FSW living with HIV at greatest need.

PHR: U-RISE at Queens College, CUNY, Narrative This grant requests support for the training of students from diverse backgrounds and for their increased representation and success in the biomedical sciences within Queens College. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will establish a clinical research center to conduct network wide research to develop asthma treatments for children living in low-income urban settings. The site-specific research will investigate molecular mechanisms that could explain the heterogeneous clinical phenotypes and how allergy, pollution and stress affect these mechanisms. The knowledge gained from the network and site-specific studies will improve asthma outcome and has the potential to lead to novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aims of this proposal are to determine the safety and efficacy of Cannabidiol (CBD) to alleviate pain and opioid craving among people living with both opioid addiction and chronic pain. Results will provide evidence as to whether CBD might aid as a novel treatment for this especially vulnerable population. This proposal will accelerate the development of novel therapeutics targeting the endogenous cannabinoid system for opioid addiction and chronic pain, a strategy that is likely to reduce persistently high rates of relapse and save lives.

PHR: Narrative: Social stress in humans increases the risk for depression resulting in anhedonia—a loss of interest in pleasurable stimuli—which can manifest within social domains and lead to severe social impairments. Mouse models of social stress are useful to better understand the biological underpinnings of stress-impaired social behavior deficits. Our results show that activation of lateral septum in susceptible mice following social defeat occludes social reward and preference promoting social avoidance behavior.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will aim to establish the connection between antibiotic use, activity of gut bacteria, and depression, with the long-term goal of finding new therapeutic options to treat neuropsychiatric diseases. The training plan will allow the trainee to gain new skills to study if and how antibiotic use leads to depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal blood flow has been shown to play a role in the formation of congenital heart defects (CHDs). However, few tools exist to study how forces exerted by blood flow early in heart development result in altered molecular signaling. Our proposal centers on creating optical imaging to investigate mechanical stresses experienced by cells lining the beating, early-stage heart tube and how these cells and adjacent tissues respond in gene expression in each area of the heart during normal, diseased, and rescued conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Insight into transcription elongation mechanisms will be sought through studies of RNA polymerase pausing and transcription termination in Bacillus subtilis and Escherichia coli. Proper regulation of gene expression is of paramount importance for the function of cells in all organisms. As several human diseases arise in part through inappropriate gene expression, these studies will contribute to improving human health by providing a detailed mechanistic understanding of how transcription elongation is controlled.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Heart Failure Collaboratory (HFC) is a public-private partnership between the Inova Heart and Vascular Institute (IHVI), the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and the major stakeholders in the heart failure (HF) community whose mission is to advance scientific discussion and improve efficiency of clinical trials and evidence generation for HF by fostering a collaborative environment in which all stakeholders can interact to optimize innovation and advancement of new therapeutic products. HFC deliverables provide recommendations, structures, definitions, and mechanisms for all individuals, companies, or organizations to use for the development of new therapies for patients with HF.

PROJECT_TITLE: The Heart Failure Collaboratory Public-Private Partnership Between the United States Food and Drug Administration, the Inova Heart and Vascular Institute, and the Heart Failure Community

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: This study will improve access of Veterans with epilepsy living in rural areas to the most important diagnostic procedure for the care of patients with epilepsy: the routine electroencephalogram (EEG). We will test a new method for recording EEG which uses a novel dry electrode system headset that does not require an EEG technologist to operate. The headset integrates the EEG electrodes and amplifier into a compact system which is easily placed on the head. This approach could make it possible for a nurse or nurse assistant with minimal training to record an EEG in a rural community based outpatient clinic (CBOC) as part of an epilepsy telemedicine outreach program along with clinical interviews. We will compare performance of this dry electrode system to standard EEG when it is used by EEG technologists in three VA medical centers. This project has the potential to improve access of Veterans to the EEG procedure and decrease cost to the Veterans Health Care System.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disrupted social cognition is a risk factor, core symptom, and maintenance factor for most major mental illnesses, including autism, schizophrenia, and depression. At their core, these disruptions involve biases in if and how social information is perceived, a process that also varies across individuals in the normative population. The proposed research will determine the behavioral and neural mechanisms that underlie how different individuals can perceive the same social information in different ways, and identify novel intervention and treatment targets for biased social cognition in mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysm is a major vascular disease in the United States, but current treatment relies on detection, monitoring, lifestyle changes, and surgery. Very little is known about the molecular mechanisms contributing to aneurysm rupture, a highly lethal complication among aneurysm patients. The proposed research aims to investigate how thrombospondin-1 coordinates the vascular responses that drive or protect aneurysm growth and rupture, which will facility therapeutic development for aortic aneurysm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative X Implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) are commonly used in older patients with multiple co-morbidities. This project will use a multi-center cohort study to prospectively define patient-centered experiences of older patients following ICD implantation. We then apply these data to the shared decision-making process with individualized decision tools, evaluating the feasibility of a precision approach to ICD use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Macrophages have been implicated in several autoimmune diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis (RA), lupus kidney disease, and macrophage activation syndrome. The long term goals of this project are to understand how inflammatory macrophage activation (and de-activation) are regulated, and to use this knowledge to develop new therapies. This project will focus on understanding regulation of macrophage genes and pathways that play a key role in increasing inflammatory responses to gain knowledge that can be used to turn off macrophages to effectively and safely treat autoimmune and inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The question of resident stem cell specification, maintenance, and homeostasis is both broad and important: In addition to furthering our basic understanding of how adult stem cells interact with their host tissues for optimum performance throughout life, this research may suggest interventions that would lessen the age- related decline in stem cell efficiency and number that occurs in many critical tissues, including muscle. The impairment of aged skeletal muscle regeneration leads to structural (fibrosis), biochemical and physiological deficits in muscle function that culminate in reduced physical activity, frailty, and the progressive decline in the health of the aged. Importantly, the proposed research has the potential to identify extrinsic and intrinsic factors that stimulate muscle SC proliferation and/or fate decision, which is both consistent with current theories on age-related decline in muscle regeneration, and a feasible avenue for potential therapy development against muscle degenerative disease, and to restore muscle after sport and/or combat injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Harm resulting from drug-drug interactions is almost always preventable, yet many nursing home residents are at increased risk due to the number of medications they take, along with physiologic and clinical factors placing them at increased risk. I propose a series of interrelated aims to quantify the prevalence and consequences of drug-drug interactions involving direct-acting oral anticoagulants among nursing home residents. This work will not only generate valuable knowledge in its own right, but also allow for the implementation of policies to optimize drug use and improve outcomes among this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: The mortality rates associated with many invasive fungal infections remain disturbingly high, despite the appropriate use of three major classes of antifungal drug. Recently we found that many medications approved for human use can induce resistance to first-line antifungal drugs, suggesting their coadministration may undermine the clinical efficacy of antifungal therapy. Ultimately the findings of the proposed studies will be used to guide the selection of drug regimens and develop treatment protocols that maximize antifungal efficacy, to improve outcomes for patients with life-threatening fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical interactions between cells influence many important aspects of embryo development. This proposal uses the nematode embryo as a model system to determine how cellular interactions regulate the shape, organization, and function of cells, tissues, and organs. Our findings will provide insights into how cell interactions contribute to human embryo development, and how defective cellular interactions can contribute to birth defects and diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Transfer learning to improve the re-usability of computable biomedical knowledge Narrative Re-using computable biomedical knowledge in the form of a mathematical model in a new setting is challenging because the new setting may not have data needed as inputs to the model. This project will develop and evaluate transfer learning algorithms, which are computer programs that adapt a model to a new setting by removing and adding local variables to it. The developed methods for re-using models are expected to benefit the public’s health by: (1) improving case detection during epidemics by enabling re-use of automatic case detectors developed in the earliest affected regions with other regions, and, more generally, (2) increasing the impact of NIH’s investment in machine learning by enabling machine-learned models to be used in more institutions and locations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Mutation of genes involved in chromatin regulation frequently underlie cancer. We have identified and validated two genes that when deleted, cause cell death specifically in childhood cancers mutant for the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeler subunit SMARCB1. The proposed studies are designed to determine the normal function of these two genes and to define the mechanisms by which they kill these childhood cancers, with the ultimate goal of yielding new therapeutic approaches.

PHR: No changes The proposed project investigates fluorescence image-guided surgery to allow precise identification of necrotic tissue both preoperatively and intraoperatively in burn patients. Furthermore, it uses a multi-model approach to elucidate the localization of indocyanine green inflammation and necrosis to determine how this novel use of a well-known fluorescence marker can be optimized to aid in surgical decision making. This proposal will provide the necessary data to support the design of a larger clinical trial to study the feasibility and efficacy of this technology to improve the precision of necrosis detection and removal and improve wound healing outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are causally linked to 5% of all human cancers, including ~25% of HNSCCs, resulting in half a million deaths every year. An epidemic-level increase in HPV+ HNSCC requires urgent needs to develop new tools to treat HNSCC patients. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the mechanism by which the chemokine CXCL14 suppresses HNSCC growth, and test if CXCL14 serves as a useful immunomodulatory target for novel immunotherapies to treat HPV+ HNSCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed research is to interrogate the role of miR-181a in the emergence of immune tolerance and tumor development through the regulation of Stimulator of Interferon Genes (STING). Defective STING signaling is one of the primary means by which a high grade serous cancer (HGSC) create an immunosuppressive microenvironment thus its re-activation can potentially induce tumor interferon signaling, decrease tumor volume, as well as induce anti-tumor innate/adaptive immune response. We propose to test the co-operativity between miR-181a loss and STING agonists to restore innate immune signaling in HGSC and induce tumor cell death and ultimately have a significant impact on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Overall Center for Bio-behavioral Mechanisms of Eating Behavior NARRATIVE Eating disorders represent one of the most serious and lethal psychiatric disorders. Also, rates of obesity are increasing dramatically across the United States with highly significant medical, social, and economic implications. The purpose of the proposed COBRE is to establish a Center for Bio-behavioral Mechanisms of Eating Behavior (CBM-EB) at the Sanford Center for Bio-behavioral Research that will support comprehensive biomedical studies of eating disorders and eating behavior, while mentoring early career investigators in these areas. The five proposed projects focus on bio-behavioral factors which increase risk, or operate to maintain the disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Recent research has made dramatic strides by revealing how the brain organizes and ‘navigates’ continuous, non-spatial task dimensions as a cognitive map in typical and atypical individuals. A cognitive map of a task confers powerful advantages for flexible behavior and generalization, which are compromised in several psychiatric conditions. However, how cognitive maps of discrete and abstract tasks commonplace in the real world contribute to such flexibile behavior remains largely unknown. The present project aims to develop a new neural model of how discrete, abstract tasks are represented and used for flexible behavior during decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Crohn’s disease (CD) is a chronic, progressive disease that can cause irreversible bowel damage with complications including strictures, fistulae and bowel resections. As the armamentarium of therapeutic agents for CD continues to expand, there is an increasing need for precision medicine approaches in treatment selection. In this grant, we aim to expand and improve the performance of a set of blood proteins that can predict anti-tumor necrosis factor alpha (anti-TNF) treatment response and then to explore blood biomarkers of response to a newer drug class used to treat CD, anti-interleukin 12/23 (anti-IL12/23).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are at increased risk of age-related disease and complications such as frailty. The proposed research aims to determine 1) the associations of free testosterone and sex hormone binging globulin (SHBG) concentrations with incident frailty, 2) the association of diurnal variation in free testosterone with HIV serostatus and its association with systemic inflammation, 3) the association of novel SHBG glycans with frailty among men with HIV. This work will inform efforts to find new therapeutic targets for frailty via the improvement of alterations in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis in men with HIV.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug exposure in pregnancy is common although data available to pregnant patients and their providers on the risks and benefits of drug use in pregnancy are sparse. Reducing adverse pregnancy and infant outcomes requires new approaches to address the insufficient pace of new information on safe use of medicines in pregnancy. In this study we will combine a) innovative data-mining techniques that can evaluate multiple drugs and outcomes simultaneously with b) formal assessments of prioritized safety signals obtained from data mining in real world populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Leveraging the infrastructure of the parent BASIC project and its ancillary study, we propose the largest study of polysomnography among stroke patients. This population-based study will quantify the physiological underpinnings of sleep apnea in post-stroke patients and stroke-free participants for the first time. This study will provide opportunities for personalized medicine for post-stroke sleep apnea, as an understanding of the underlying pathophysiology has direct implications for treatment selection and success.

PHR: NARRATIVE One of the fundamental and highly regulated events in the generation of functional mRNAs is 3’-processing and transcription termination. Defects in this process are linked to human diseases, including cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Tau protein undergoes abnormal and pathological accumulation in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease and frontotemporal dementia. Tau is a multifunctional protein, expressed in multiple cell types within the central nervous system. In this study, we will use hiPSC-derived neural cells and cortical organoids to examine how loss of tau function affects key neurodegenerative phenotypes including neuroimmune pathways, cellular stress and DNA damage, and neuronal electrophysiological function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to develop biologically relevant, scalable systems for the functional analysis of neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorder (NPD) genes to advance from gene discovery to biological targets. We propose to establish an Assay and Data Generation Center as part of the SSPsyGene Consortium to screen 250 NPD genes in parallel and develop innovate assays for multi-omics screens. Our overarching goal is to gain new insights into the function of NPD genes and advance our understanding of the biology of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is a major global health concern that continues to rise at an alarming rate driven by the tide of the obesity pandemic. We propose that the BCKA regulatory network in liver is an important regulator of NASH pathogenesis. In this proposal we will explore the impact of modulating the components of the BCKA regulatory network on NASH development and further define the mechanism of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A national challenge in the biomedical sciences, and especially translational science/research, is recruiting, training, and retaining the most diverse scientific talent pool possible. At the UU CTSI, we are poised to tackle this challenge by leveraging recent successes at the UU in recruiting underrepresented students to our graduate programs and redoubling our efforts to develop targeted training and pipeline programs for underrepresented students to strengthen our applicant pool for translational science-related graduate programs. We will expand the Biomedical Research Inclusion & Diversity to Grow Excellence in Science – Undergraduate Program for Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), and solidify key relationships with our local community and HBCUs to foster an inclusive, research-intensive environment where underrepresented scientists can flourish and attain their goal of admission to top-notch graduate training programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite improved reperfusion strategies decreasing mortality in non-diabetic patients after acute MI, both prevalence and severity of ischemic heart failure continually escalate in type 2 diabetic patients, via incompletely understood mechanisms. The current application endeavors to define molecular mechanisms responsible for the pathologic communications between diabetic adipocytes and coronary microvascular endothelial cells. Successful completion of this proposal will identify novel therapeutic strategies capable of blocking/preventing exosome-mediated pathological communications between adipose tissue and heart (two organs critically involved in the development of type 2 diabetes and the death in this population, respectively), to ultimately ameliorate morbidity and mortality associated with diabetic cardiovascular complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  B cell populations infiltrating the central nervous system (CNS) are common hallmarks of neurotropic infections, the demyelinating disease multiple sclerosis (MS), as well as autoimmune encephalitis. However, their antibody-independent regulatory functions and crosstalk with resident meningeal stromal cells, which provide the platform for chronic B-cell aggregates associated with immune pathology in MS, require more extensive investigation. Using a viral CNS infection model to characterize cues associated with acute, resolving, and chronic activation of meningeal stromal cells and their effects on B-cell retention and function, results will unveil how meningeal immune responses can be manipulated to optimize parenchymal protective immunity and/or minimize pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: NARRATIVE Cigarette smoke is a complex mixture of toxicants that can damage DNA and promote many diseases. The goal of this project is to define how mice reprogram 37 different RNA modifications comprising their tRNA-specific epitranscriptome to regulate translation in response to environmental tobacco smoke (ETS). We have recently discovered a new mechanism of translational regulation in response to stress, in which toxicant exposures cause highly predictive changes in dozens of modified ribonucleosides in the RNA machinery that regulates protein levels, leading to selective translation of codon-biased mRNAs representing families of genes critical for surviving the stress. Using novel mouse genetic models, we will test our proposed mechanism of translational control, define the ETS-programmable epitranscriptome, and determine the importance of RNA modification reprogramming in response to ETS. The results will have major implications for our understanding of tissue and cellular responses to cigarette smoke and they will be broadly applicable to other toxicants and pharmaceuticals. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have provided proof-of-principle that HSE in childhood may result from single-gene inborn errors of cortical neuron-intrinsic immunity, with the discovery of TLR3, UNC-93B, TRIF, TRAF3, TBK1, IRF3 and snoRNA31 deficiencies in children with forebrain HSE, and DBR1 deficiency in children with brainstem HSE. We now aim to test the hypothesis that other single-gene inborn errors of neuron-intrinsic immunity to HSV-1 can underlie childhood HSE, and that forebrain and brainstem HSE result from mutations affecting different pathways. We will pursue a GW approach, making use of NGS techniques, including WES, WGS, and RNA-seq, to select candidate variants for validation by biochemical and immunological means.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little is known about how genomic variants affect human brain development, brain function, and neuropsychiatric disorders. We propose a large-scale study to identify DNA variants and their effects on gene expression in brain tissue and single cells from the brain across human brain development. This will provide functional insight into the neurobiological processes responsible for human brain development and function, and disrupted in neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain often clusters in families, where parents and their offspring both experience chronic pain conditions. Young children of parents with irritable bowel syndrome represent an at-risk group for the development of abdominal pain, disability, and excess health care visits in later childhood. Parental solicitous responses to children’s expressions of discomfort and maternal modeling of their own illness behavior contribute to a greater focus on somatic sensations, leading to illness behaviors in children. We hypothesize that an early preventive psychosocial intervention specifically for children at risk for an abdominal pain disorder can alter parental responses and lead to improved child health and decreased health care costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance to Public Health  Formation of toxic Aβ oligomers is a key pathological process in Alzheimer’s disease. This project aims to study the conversion of oligomers to fibrils, which are less toxic than oligomers. Success of this project may help develop strategies to modulate the oligomer-to-fibril conversion process as a therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Multiple myeloma (MM) is a neoplasm of bone marrow resident plasma cells that remains incurable, primarily due to the development of pro-MM survival responses. We have found that the PIM2 kinase plays an important role in MM survival, and inhibiting it leads to MM cell death even in the presence in major pro-MM survival signals. The work proposed will define the molecular mechanisms underlying PIM2’s pro-survival effects, which will point to novel therapeutic strategies for multiple myeloma. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Clinical care of metastatic breast cancer demands rigorous monitoring to ensure that a patient is on the right treatment at the right time. Our proposal seeks to validate and demonstrate the clinical utility of a CLIA- compliant low-cost, rapid response monitoring strategy for circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) using customized digital droplet PCR (ddPCR) and next generation sequencing (NGS). This hybrid approach to molecular surveillance will significantly improve the management of metastatic breast cancer by anticipating response or progression sooner than existing clinical standard of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute exacerbations of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) are associated with accelerated lung function decline, impaired health status, increased hospitalization, and increased mortality. Population heterogeneity of those at risk for these events makes it difficult to identify subgroups that are particularly susceptible. In carrying out the research outlined in the following proposal, we will perform extensive quantitative-CT image characterization of study subjects, and we will apply Bayesian trajectory analysis on these measures to better identify subpopulations with differing innate susceptibility to exacerbations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to understand a fundamental mechanism controlling feeding and obesity in humans, which is organized in part by the primary cilium, an ancient signaling organelle in the cell. Using human genetics, proteomics and quantitative cell biology, we have found that genes encoding proteins within the cilium are mutated in rare inherited syndromes, but more recently found 1000s of cilia-linked mutations in humans with obesity or high Body Mass Index (BMI) causing signaling molecular defects, which we will study here. By examining new genes and signaling mechanisms, we endeavor to explain and quantify the effects of cilia-related obesity lesions in patients, to identify new targets for treating obesity and metabolic disease, and to facilitate patient diagnosis and selection for molecularly rationale therapies and precise therapeutic choices.

The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance our understanding of brain tumor pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To meet the current and future challenges created by the leading infectious diseases in Kenya (e.g., malaria and COVID-19), we propose continuation of our research training program that has been continuously funded since being established in 2002. To maximize programmatic impact for training the next generation of Kenyan leaders, we have assembled a world-class team of multidisciplinary investigators from Kenya and Ghana who were former trainees in the program, along with long-standing partners at the University of New Mexico and Los Alamos National Laboratory. We propose advanced training in state-of-the art methodologies under the rubric of thematic target areas (Host-Pathogen Dynamics, Therapeutic Discovery, and Disease Modeling), strategically selected for maximizing long-term capacity building to combat high-burden infectious diseases in Kenya. ,

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The overall 5-year survival rate for head and neck cancer has not improved much over the last few decades with both conventional multimodal treatment and emerging immunotherapies known to have an adverse (and sometimes fatal) impact on quality of life. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the mechanisms driving the effectiveness of a novel immunotherapy for head and neck cancer we call “SynerGel” and determine how it can be used in combination with standard-of-care radiation therapy to reduce treatment toxicity. By doing so, we aim to enhance our understanding of how both tumor and immune cells in the tumor environment can be manipulated to produce a strong anti-tumor effect while reducing the side effects of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The rate of unintended pregnancy among women with substance use disorders (SUDs) is twice that of the general population and is perpetuated by low rates of contraceptive use, especially in the postpartum period. This research will determine the effect of a novel, patient-centered, reproductive planning decision support tool called MyPath on postpartum contraceptive utilization and reproductive health outcomes (i.e. unintended pregnancy, short interpregnancy interval) among women with SUDs. Findings from this research will provide high-quality evidence about how to improve postpartum contraceptive decision-making for women with SUDs and if successful, will identify a low-cost scalable solution that can be implemented in most clinical settings.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Our application is to determine how targeting the histone demethylase KDM4A inhibits HNSCC cell invasion and activates tumor cell-intrinsic immune responses by inducing DNA replication stress and determine whether targeting KDM4A can help to overcome HNSCC resistance to PD-1 blockade therapy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although opioid overdose deaths are persistently high, increasing availability of effective medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) are one reason for optimism. We propose to use the novel Massachusetts Public Health Data warehouse to compare the effect of different buprenorphine and naltrexone formulations on retention and fatal and nonfatal opioid overdose after opioid detoxification. We will utilize an emulated trials approach with advanced statistical techniques to improve causal inference and will compare results directly with the X:BOT randomized controlled trial of sublingual buprenorphine-naloxone and extended-release naltrexone. The findings of these comparative effectiveness analyses will inform policy and practice on the coverage and use of an expanding array of MOUD formulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative Arterial thrombosis, which describes the formation of abnormal blood clots in the artery, is a highly fatal disease that leads to stroke and myocardial infarction. Current therapeutic strategies for arterial thrombosis have relatively low effectiveness and a major risk of excessive bleeding. By identifying biomechanical platelet aggregation as a key player in arterial thrombosis, this proposal aims to establish a mechanism-driven approach to selectively inhibit biomechanical platelet aggregation without compromising hemostasis, which will lay the foundation for the development of therapeutics to better prevent and treat arterial thrombosis.

PHR: This proposal focuses on research and training in the fields of developmental and stem cell biology, as well as their potential applications in the up-and-coming field of regenerative medicine. A unique component of the training program is exposure of this next generation of scientists to the clinical correlates of the foundational research problems they are investigating. These young researchers will be at the forefront of translating emerging research into the control of developmental cell fate towards new stem-cell-based approaches for healing the human body.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a costly and pervasive disease that affects more than 10.5% of the US population and represented the 7th leading cause of death in 2019. This disease results from pancreatic β cell dysfunction and death preventing normal insulin levels required to maintain proper blood- glucose homeostasis. Here, I propose to better define the molecular mechanisms by which retinoic acid signaling synergizes with GATA transcription factors to regulate β cell development and function to improve therapeutic treatment of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) has the most diverse student body in the Wisconsin public uni- versity system and is located in the most racially and ethnically diverse city in Wisconsin. The UWM Promoting Equity, Diversity, and Academic Success Through Aging Research (UWM STAR) program is designed to lever- age this diversity in support of the NIA’s goals for this R25 program: to expand research opportunities for un- derrepresented undergraduate students and increase the diversity of researchers conducting health disparities research among older adults. The program will provide structured multi-year hands-on research experiences, plus curricular and socialization experiences designed to prepare underrepresented college students for careers in aging and health disparities research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Diabetes is common in older adults and associated with major adverse health outcomes. State-of-the art continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) technology provides a novel means to rigorously characterize glucose patterns, but this technology has rarely been used in older adults. The proposed project will provide evidence- based guidance regarding the use and interpretation of continuous glucose monitoring in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will reduce health disparities and disease burden that disproportionally affect individuals of Latino ancestry suffering from schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. We will develop novel statistical methods and generate gene expression data that specifically apply to the admixed genetic ancestries within individuals of Latino ancestries. The integrative approach will significantly advance our understanding of the biological factors leading to disease susceptibility and provide great opportunity for personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: This research will develop and validate machine learning methods for estimating brain micro-structural biomarkers from diffusion MRI measurements for neonates and pediatric patients. In addition to superior estimation accuracy, the new methods will compute prediction uncertainty, detect model failure, and enhance transparency and user trust. Hence, the new methods will enable assessment of normal and abnormal brain development in these critical stages with unprecedented accuracy and reliability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue resident macrophages are thought to play an important role in viral persistent because of their ability to survive HIV-1 infection, but have been understudied because of their paucity and inaccessibility. We propose addressing this shortfall through screening a small molecule library of epigenetic inhibitors to identify those pathways leading to selective cell death in a range of myeloid host cell lineages including HMDMs, alveolar macrophages, and microglial cells. Compounds identified as active will be assayed directly against HIV-1 positive patients’ cells, and characterized for the mode of action to identify novel therapeutic approaches towards HIV-1 reservoir eradication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An NIH-funded trial will assess whether active detection and treatment of low-density malaria infection in children results in clinical benefits on long-term health. In this study, we will determine whether this intervention also reduces gametocyte carriage, thereby having the potential to interrupt malaria transmission. This will help inform policy and practice regarding the role of ultrasensitive malaria diagnostics to reduce transmission and help achieve malaria elimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to develop a framework for the detection and evaluation of clinically relevant drug-drug interactions in older adults with diabetes using electronic healthcare data. The overarching goal is to produce actionable, high-quality, and clinically relevant evidence that will help older adults and their clinicians to more fully assess the benefits and risks of adding a new medication in the presence of other medications and co-morbidities. This research will improve the evidence-base for decision-making available to clinicians treating older adults with diabetes, ultimately enhancing patient care, which is aligned with the mission of the National Institute on Aging (NIA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Successful navigation requires the integration of our remembered environment with the scene in front of us, but little is known about how spatial memory and scene perception systems interact in the brain. Closing this knowledge gap is the overall objective of this proposal. This work is crucial to informing rehabilitation and support strategies for individuals with reduced vision (e.g. Macular Degeneration), neurodegenerative conditions (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease), developmental disorders (e.g. Williams syndrome), and typical aging, in which scene recognition and wayfinding abilities are key symptoms affecting day-to-day life and, in some neurodegenerative conditions, the first detected signs of decline.

PHR: Project Narrative: This career development proposal leverages an expert multinational mentorship team and rigorous didactics to acquire essential skills for an independent global health research career. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fear of the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) is widespread, and the emotional toll of this virus on our society is enormous. However, relatively little is known about the effects of this virus on children. Empiric estimates on the risks and long-term effects of this virus in children will enable clinicians and policymakers to make informed decisions about both the need for optimal use of preventative and therapeutic interventions as they become available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Close to 10% of the over 20,000 premature children every year develop airway disorders that often require laryngotracheal reconstruction using cartilage harvested from the rib cage, but this approach is invasive and cannot be applied to younger children, which motivates an urgent need for new, improved technology. We propose an innovative approach to produce functional cartilage for grafting using an instructive, degradable scaffold that direct the chondrogenic differentiation of a novel autologous cell sources obtained by a minimally invasive biopsy. The in vitro and in vivo proposed studies are aimed at defining new, less invasive and more effective therapeutic options for laryngotracheal reconstruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States (US), transgender and gender diverse (TGD) individuals, who have a gender identity that differs from their assigned birth sex, experience disparities in the burden of chronic conditions and healthcare use relative to their cisgender (non-TGD) peers. There is limited national data on whether and to what extent these disparities persist as TGD individuals age. This study will utilize a rigorous mixed-methods approach that combines quantitative data from a large cohort of older TGD and cisgender adults with qualitative interviews with patients and providers to provide clinically-important and policy-relevant evidence about the health and healthcare utilization of older TGD and cisgender adults; findings will be leveraged in future multilevel interventions to improve health outcomes for older TGD people in the US.

PHR: Project Narrative The current proposal seeks to understand why and how influenza virus lung infection induces ACE2 expression and activity, and in turn facilitates the compromised immune response to secondary bacterial lung infection. We will also try to test the potential preventive and therapeutic usage of ACE2 as a biomarker and clinical reagent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Transition age adults (ages 18-25) with opioid use disorders are poorly served by the current treatment system for substance use disorders. This study will examine the variation in quality of treatment for opioid use disorders for this age cohort and examine multilevel factors—individual, community, treatment program— associated with higher quality care. The findings from this study will inform clinical decision making by patients and providers as well as public health responses to the rising tide of young adults seeking treatment for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal will leverage high coverage long and short-read sequencing data to develop novel computational methods to improve the characterization of somatic and mosaic structural variation (SV) and transposition events together with their epigenetic consequences across three tissues and 34 individuals. The methods will be developed in coordination with the SMaHT network, and tools and results will be shared with all sequencing centers, in coordination with the DAC, enabling seamless incorporation of the software and our results into the network. The results will include a catalog of SV, transposition and methylation, in somatic tissues, that will enable new insights into the consequences of these variants, across the human population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent advances in induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) technology have made it possible to produce autologous patient-derived retinal cells for analysis of disease pathophysiology and testing of novel therapeutics. That said, even state-of-the-art retinal differentiation protocols, which give rise to three dimensional retinal organoids, do not accurately recapitulate the cell-cell interactions that are present in the outer retina. In this application we describe a program focused on the development and validation of a microphysiological system engineered to accurately recreate the complex architecture of the perfused outer retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA mechanics and supercoiling, binding and bridging by proteins, and liquid-liquid phase separation shape the topology of the genome. Macromolecular crowding influences each of these phenomena affecting all fundamental genomic functions, including transcription. Experiments employing single molecule manipulation and modeling, and comparison with in vivo measurements will enhance our understanding of crowding-mediated genomic regulation and our ability to apply crowding in synthetic biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Lewy body dementia (LBD) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) models, Hsp70, which assists in protein folding, can correct pathology caused by -synuclein, tau and Abeta proteins. While the mechanism of Hsp70 protection is unknown, our data suggest a very non-standard and specific mode of action, which we seek to determine in atomic detail and verify both in LBD cell models and in AD (tau and Abeta) biochemical assays. If verified, this mechanistic understanding will provide a specific pathway to exploit for treatment of LBD and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Organ transplantation is a proven intervention for end-stage organ failure; however, transplants are only currently meeting ~10% of the global demand. Yet, there are untapped resources of potentially transplantable organs that could be used to save these lives. This project aims to develop a quantitative, objective metric to definitively ascertain liver viability that will enable advances in experimental and clinical transplantation aimed at increasing the availability of organs for transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to understand how macrophages modulate tumor cell resistance to radiotherapy and uses that knowledge to develop improved radiotherapeutic strategies for brain cancer. Once such strategies have been developed, there is the potential for significant advances in treatment for patients with brain cancer. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke’s mission of seeking fundamental knowledge about neurological disorders and using that knowledge to reduce disease burden in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this program is to develop a high-throughput optical assay that enables non-destructive metabolic characterization of in vitro cell models and organoids for biomedical applications. We will demonstrate our assay for early prediction of breast cancer radiation sensitivity within the decision-making window via longitudinal metabolic characterization of patient-derived organoids under radiation stresses. The proposed work will impact the biomedical research by providing a novel tool for non-destructive metabolic measurement of cell and organoid models, and a novel paradigm for cancer patient’s radiotherapy sensitivity prediction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insomnia is common and highly comorbid among adolescents with migraine, impacting 65-71% of youth. The proposed project will determine efficacy of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) for insomnia, as well as the combined effect of CBT insomnia and pain interventions, on reducing insomnia symptoms and headache-related disability in adolescents with migraine. Our long-term goal is to offer effective, tailored self-management interventions that can address migraine and co-morbid sleep problems in adolescence and disrupt a cycle of persistent, disabling migraine from continuing into adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is an almost uniformly lethal disease and is characterized by an intense fibroinflammatory stromal reaction and a hypoxic microenvironment. Tumor-stroma crosstalk substantially contributes to disease progression and therapeutic resistance, and the goal of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanisms by which hypoxia regulates localization and function of fibroblasts and immune cells in pancreatic cancer by modulating the tumor-stroma crosstalk. Our studies will provide new insights into the role of hypoxia in shaping the tumor stroma in pancreatic cancer, which can be exploited to develop effective stroma-targeting strategies against pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative There is a growing need to improve next-generation sequencing (NGS) techniques for applications such as pathogen detection, strain identification, and drug susceptibility testing. Triangle Biotechnology is developing a novel lysis technology that drastically improves DNA extraction from lysis-resistant infectious pathogens, a current bottleneck in NGS workflows. The integration of this technology with in-vitro diagnostic platforms will assist in alleviating the public health burden of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Women are more susceptible to performance impairment in response to acute sleep loss during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle. This menstrual-phase-dependent susceptibility may be indirectly mediated by progesterone and estradiol via their effect on core body temperature, but it is unknown whether these effects persist under more realistic patterns of chronic sleep loss. This work will fill this important gap in knowledge and inform future interventions to mitigate the impact of sleep loss in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL COMPONENT The mechanisms and the biomarkers of developing food allergy are poorly understood, but it is known that traditional, agrarian lifestyle provides protection against atopic diseases starting in early life. In this proposal utilizing samples and clinical data from a longitudinal birth cohort study, we will evaluate the development of the microbiome, skin barrier function and skin and systemic immune system in urban infants at high risk for atopic diseases and in farming lifestyle infants. These studies will provide critical new knowledge about the biomarkers and mechanisms of early development of and protection against atopic diseases, and lay the groundwork for future studies of prevention of allergic diseases in childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Postoperative acute kidney injury (AKI) occurs in 20% of patients following cardiac and vascular surgery and increases the risk of developing chronic kidney disease and death. We have demonstrated that a higher preoperative high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol concentration is associated with a reduced risk of AKI after cardiac surgery, and now proposed studies to test the hypothesis that apolipoprotein A-I and specific miRNAs on HDL suppress endothelial intercellular adhesion molecule 1, renal tubule toll-like receptor (TLR) 2 and TLR4 expression, and reduce AKI. These studies will provide the candidate with experience in prospective clinical research, miRNA sequencing, and preclinical murine models of AKI, preparing her to establish an independent translational research career focused on developing novel methods of reducing postoperative AKI.
