IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes is a disorder that results from dysfunction and death of islet β cells. The identification and characterization of new pathways promoting stress in β cells would allow for the institution of defined therapies that protect β cells and their function. This application proposes to study the pathways that activate the integrated stress response in β cells and how this response leads to promotes the dialog with immune cells to propagate autoimmunity in type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current paradigm of laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR) largely ignores the interplay of psychological processes (e.g., hypervigilance, anxiety) on symptom burden, representing a tremendous missed opportunity to help patients with chronic laryngeal complaints and contributing to suboptimal treatment outcomes. This prospective study will utilize psychometric methods to develop a validated self-report instrument (the laryngeal hypervigilance and anxiety scale [LHAS]) and measure levels of hypervigilance and anxiety across distinct groups of LPR patients identified through our prior discriminant analysis of principal components model. These findings will introduce a novel tool to clinical practice, impact future anticipated clinical trial designs, and ultimately inform multi-pronged care paradigms for LPR inclusive of therapies targeting psychosocial processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The goals of the Health Education Research Opportunities for Teachers (HERO-T) program are to (1) cultivate in teachers the skills needed to conduct cutting edge biomedical research and translate their research experience into curricula for their students and (2) increase student awareness of and exposure to research in the biomedical sciences and foster in them scientific investigation skills. The anticipated outcomes are that teachers who participate in this summer research experience will have improved ability to communicate scientific concepts to their students, have a greater understanding of the applications of science to everyday life, and have improved research and laboratory skills. Students who participate in the program will enhance their awareness of and exposure to biomedicine/ biomedical research and increase their awareness of careers in biomedicine/ biomedical research and cultivate their scientific investigation skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Repair of large bone defects is a crucial medical challenge and tissue engineering (either using stem/progenitor cells transplantation and/or growth factors, e.g. BMPs) is a promising alternative to autologous bone graft while a number of crucial barriers must be overcome for full therapeutic translation. Through a combinatorial approach utilizing small molecule drugs and tunable and biomimetic scaffolds, this study will develop novel regenerating therapies for treatment of bone defects. This work will not only advance knowledge with regard to regenerative medicine, but accelerate novel strategies for bone repair/regeneration in a range of patients, most particularly the elderly.

The proposed program seeks to provide state-of-the art training for the next generation of clinical pharmacologists.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Guided by an innovative conceptual model incorporating perspectives from the migration and child development literatures, this project examines multiple child- and environment-level mechanisms through which the migration of family members is associated with left-behind children’s social competence and psychological adjustment problems. New knowledge about migration’s costs and benefits can assist families in settings with a high prevalence of labor migration as they adapt to the changes that migration brings to family members’ relationships, caregiving, and households’ resources. This research can also help policy makers anticipate the challenges that migration poses to children’s mental health and positive adjustment, and inform policies and interventions aimed at supporting left-behind family members and reducing problems such as depression, anxiety, aggression, rule-breaking, and substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) Time-of-flight positron emission tomography is the standard of care in nuclear imaging for a broad range of diseases, from numerous types of cancer to neurological and cardiovascular disorders. To achieve a good spatial resolution and image quality, an excellent time and energy resolution are required. In this project, we aim to demonstrate a novel way to improve both simultaneously by exploiting the information carried by the wavelength of the optical photons generated in scintillator materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although the devastating consequences of Zika virus infection in the fetal brain have been known since the 2016 outbreak in the Americas, we still do not fully understand how the virus causes microcephaly. We hypothesize that a branch of the immune system known as innate immunity-- which is important for controlling viral infection-- is not fully functional in the fetal brain. Our experiments will determine how innate immunity develops and functions in the fetal brain, allowing us to design treatments that protect the growing infant and brain from Zika infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) We seek funding to complete the Trial to Assess Chelation Therapy 2 (TACT2), an ongoing multicenter US- Canada randomized controlled factorial trial in 1000 post-MI patients with diabetes, testing whether 40 intravenous edetate disodium-based infusions or placebo infusions and high-dose oral multivitamins or oral placebo reduce recurrent ischemic cardiac events. There is a biorepository for urine and blood. The study has completed enrollment and seeks funding for 2.5 additional years to complete infusions, follow-up, and closeout.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: This study uses a Type 1 effectiveness-implementation hybrid approach to swiftly examine program effectiveness while simultaneously determining implementation uptake of a multi-level intervention that builds the resilience of community-based child care centers during and post- public health crises such as COVID-19. This project has the potential to provide valuable information on how to rapidly support the immediate psychosocial and safety needs of teachers and children, and strengthen the readiness for childcare centers to adapt to future crises. If we can equip childcare centers serving low-income, ethnic minority communities with strategies to maintain quality in the face of adversity, we can in turn support teachers, parents, and young children and help keep society functioning during global challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Different areas of the brain are composed of unique cell types and connectivity patterns that subserve their unique functional roles, and disruption of areal patterning during development can lead to neurologic and neuropsychiatric disorders such as autism and schizophrenia. Recent studies have implicated a role for retinoic acid, derived from Vitamin A, in patterning of the cerebral cortex, and this proposal will explore the mechanism by which this areal specification occurs. These experiments will generate foundational knowledge about the mechanisms of areal specification in the brain, and may help explain genetic susceptibility to neurodevelopmental disorders associated with abnormal arealization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lumbar spine imaging has become ubiquitous in the standard course of care for low back pain (LBP); however, offers only a qualitative assessment of spinal anatomy often not predictive of painful conditions. Magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) is a non-invasive technique that allows the in-vivo measurement of tissue's mechanical properties and has been described as a way to visually palpate internal tissues. The long-term objective of this work is to integrate MRE with other advanced MR imaging parameters into a “patient specific” clinical tool that can identify damage and quantify the functional consequences of disease and treatments for LBP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Title: Commensal bacteria resilience mechanisms in the inflamed intestine PROJECT NARRATIVE  Marked decreases in essential micronutrients such as iron perturb the gut microbial community during intestinal inflammation, depleting beneficial commensals. Commensal resilience is central to maintaining the overall microbiota structure and functions in the face of perturbations such as nutritional depletion; however, there is a crucial knowledge gap in the underlying mechanisms of resiliency. The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand how the prevalent bacterium Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron survives iron starvation during inflammation, thereby elucidating fundamental mechanisms governing microbiota resilience and commensal-pathogen iron competition in the gut.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Core Project Narrative/ Relevance We designed projects to protect people from catching hard-to-treat germs in all types of healthcare facilities: nursing homes, long-term ventilator facilities, and hospitals. Diverse interventions are needed in all settings, so we will evaluate how a patient’s own microbes can protect them or may make them vulnerable, learn how bugs spread between people using advanced genetic analyses, facilitate data exchange among facilities, and develop measures of antibiotic use across facilities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Washington University/ BJC Prevention Epicenter performs research to prevent healthcare associated infections and antibiotic resistance in healthcare settings and the community. We develop and test Interventions to improve antibiotic use, & disinfection methods, & identify new biomarkers to reduce antibiotic resistance, infections and improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) control most aspects of post-transcriptional gene regulation and cause several types of human cancers when mutated, which disrupts their interactions with many different RNAs. Currently, it is not well understood how RBPs are organized to regulate the expression of the RNAs they bind, and which specific domains within them have regulatory potential that is sensitive to mutation. In this work, I will develop and use a high-throughput recruitment assay to identify functional ‘effector’ domains within RBPs, link them to their molecular and cellular mechanisms of regulating RNA, and determine how mutations within them lead to cancer developmen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This work will define new requirements for classical dendritic cell type-2 (cDC2) positioning, homeostasis and function in spleen and lung. The work will establish the role of the CD97 adhesion-G-protein coupled receptor pathway in splenic cDC2s using flow cytometric, cell signaling and imaging approaches. Studies in EBI2 conditional knockout mice and mice unable to make oxysterols that function as EBI2 ligands will determine how this chemoattractant system determines lung cDC2 distribution and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental cues can reinforce actions and evoke strong, dynamic motivational states during drug seeking and craving to prompt relapse, which poses a significant public health problem in humans with substance use disorders. This proposal will use cutting-edge in vivo and ex vivo techniques to record neural signals and manipulate neuronal activity within the basolateral amygdala, a brain region critical for encoding environmental context information. Understanding how the dopaminergic signaling within and the glutamatergic projections from the basolateral amygdala are engaged during addiction-like behaviors will provide novel insight into mechanisms underlying affective diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Helicobacter pylori is a gastric pathogen that colonizes the gastric mucosa of more than half of the global population and is a major risk factor for several gastric pathologies including peptic-ulcer disease and gastric adenocarcinoma. The goal of this project is to determine how reactive oxygen species, a hallmark of H. pylori infection, oxidize host ribosomal proteins and impact their functions. The results of this study will further our knowledge of how H. pylori infection modulates host cellular events and identify signaling axes that could be leveraged for the prevention and treatment of H. pylori-induced gastric pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: CD4+ T helper 2 (TH2) cells normally function against parasitic diseases but can largely contribute to the development of asthma, a hyperinflammatory airway disease with increasing prevalence worldwide. Gaps in knowledge exist regarding the mechanisms governing TH2 differentiation and effector function. The work described in this proposal seeks to provide novel mechanistic insight into the molecular regulation of TH2 cells, with an overarching goal to identify molecular targets that can be leveraged for therapeutic benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In its most severe form, sepsis causes hypotension that can lead to organ failure and death, a process that is often treated with vasopressor medications that raise blood pressure and increase blood flow to vital organs. This proposal will assess current practices for delivering vasopressors in sepsis and the association of these practices with patient outcomes and complications, and will identify factors that influence provider decisions about how to administer vasopressors. The ultimate goal of this proposal is to inform future clinical trials to optimize vasopressor delivery and improve sepsis outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative Since 1994, the biennial Biology of Spirochetes Gordon Research Conference has served as the foremost forum for researchers who study this diverse group of bacteria that include several successful pathogens. Since the spirochete phylum includes the bacteria that cause Lyme disease, syphilis, leptospirosis, relapsing fever, and intestinal spirochetosis, as well as bacteria that contribute to periodontal disease, the 2024 Biology of Spirochetes Gordon Research Conference will allow presentation and discussion of the frontiers of research relevant to both human and animal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a highly lethal disease for which new therapeutic interventions are needed. The proposed project aims to develop a novel mouse model to determine whether increased production and activation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor delta (PPARD) in pancreatic cancer cells propels pancreatic cancer progression. New knowledge from this project is expected to help show whether drugs that are being developed to target PPAR-d function can be used to prevent pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Memory CD8 T cells are generated in response to infection or vaccination and form a critical component of antiviral immunity, rapidly responding to subsequent infections by killing virus-infected cells. These memory CD8 T cells are functionally diverse, with some better-suited than others to respond during infection, but little is known about how and why T cells develop to be more or less functional. This research will use cutting-edge techniques to track the development of CD8 T cells that recognize SARS-CoV-2, providing blueprints to design vaccines that provoke more effective responses and shedding light on multiple possible underlying causes of Long COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The critical importance of myelin for proper nervous system function is underscored by the devastating symptoms in diseases in which it is disrupted, including multiple sclerosis, leukodystrophies, and peripheral neuropathies that affect millions of Americans. It is also now becoming clear that myelin is a dynamic rather than a static structure that modulates neural plasticity in the healthy as well as diseased and injured central and peripheral nervous systems. The 2024 Myelin Gordon Research Conference and Seminar will bring together experts and trainees in the field of myelinating glial cell biology and repair to provide a forum to highlight recent advances in the field with a focus on themes of dynamism and plasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Induction of plasticity is a potential therapeutic avenue for ameliorating neural deficits due to early perturbation, such as amblyopia, but the mechanisms underlying plasticity in the adult brain are not fully understood. This proposal will examine a novel form of adult plasticity in the visual cortex and identify how interneurons that express somatostatin (SST-INs) contribute to experience-dependent plasticity in mouse visual cortex. We expect our findings to provide important insights into the cellular underpinnings of plasticity in the adult brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type one diabetes (T1D) is a chronic autoimmune condition resulting from the progressive destruction of insulin- producing β cells, leading to irreversible dysglycemia. It is well accepted that both immune system and β-cell dysfunction contribute to T1D pathogenesis, however many investigations of interventions focus on either the β cell or the immune system. Manipulation of the PGE2 signaling pathway, through its functionally opposing receptors EP3 and EP4, may provide an intervention which can simultaneously alter the autoimmune attack and provide cell-autonomous protection to the β cells, allowing delay, prevention, or reversal of disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney infection caused by Escherichia coli can lead to systemic infection, impaired renal function, or renal scarring. Recent work in mouse models shows that androgen exposure worsens pyelonephritis, often leading to abscess formation in the kidney. This project will define how an E. coli toxin called alpha-hemolysin (HlyA) promotes renal damage and how its toxic activity in the kidney is amplified by testosterone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary target of ∆9-Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) is cannabinoid type-1 receptors (CB1Rs), which have been shown to be downregulated, desensitized, and internalized following chronic THC exposure, and can ultimately play a key role in synaptic plasticity and cannabinoid function. While there are numerous studies on the effects of chronic THC immediately following exposure, long-term effects and chronic prenatal THC exposure are poorly understood. This proposal will investigate the gap between previous literature that shows a decrease in CB1R expression and function and plasticity following chronic THC exposure, and our preliminary data, which shows that CB1R expression and cortical plasticity is increased two weeks after chronic THC exposure, and will ultimately inform novel therapeutic strategies for prenatal THC exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astrocytes play important roles in health and disease but their role in the pathogenesis of Parkinson’s Disease (PD), as well as targets for their therapeutic modulation, are still largely unknown. I found that the sigma-1 receptor (SigmaR1) drives astrocyte disease-promoting responses in PD. In this project, I propose to define the role of SigmaR1 signaling in the control of astrocyte pathogenic responses in PD and evaluate its potential as a therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: A minority of alcohol users develop problem drinking patterns, or even worse a chronic alcohol use disorder, which exacts a huge toll on society. This proposal addresses the need for better detection of ethanol use/abuse using a direct biomarker for alcohol consumption. The rapid point-of-care lateral flow immunoassay developed in this project will provide a quick & reliable tool to monitor problem alcohol use, and help caregivers provide better treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The glycine receptor type alpha 2 (GlyRα2) plays a role in neurogenesis, and mutations have been linked to neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder and epilepsy. By investigating the structure-function relationship and lipidic profile of GlyRα2, this study aims to provide a better understanding of the role of this receptor in neurogenesis, adult physiology, and pathology. The knowledge gained from this study may lead to the development of pharmacologic therapies targeting GlyRα2 to help alleviate the symptoms of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it investigates the novel use of live engineered bacteria for the oral delivery of peptide drugs, specifically for treating autoimmune disease. These investigations will enable new microbe-based drug delivery strategies, enhancing access to care with the potential to significantly advance our understanding of gut microbe behavior. Therefore, the proposed research contributes to the NIH’s mission of seeking knowledge on the behavior of living systems and applying it to reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative TDP-43 pathology, due to loss of TDP-43 nuclear function, is a hallmark of several neurodegenerative diseases including mixed etiology dementias (MEDs) such as Alzheimer’s Disease with TDP-43 pathology (AD-TDP) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Proposed studies will elucidate the role of TDP-43 in the pathological conversion and “prion-like” spreading of tau protein in the presence or absence of ß-amyloidosis. These mechanistic insights can guide the development of novel therapeutic approaches for MEDs currently without effective treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is a microvascular retinal complication of diabetes mellitus that leads to breakdown of the blood retinal barrier (BRB). Building on prior work in the lab suggesting that hyperinsulinemia induces BRB breakdown under hyperglycemic conditions, we will investigate the effects of insulin on tight junction proteins of the RPE. This proposal will broaden our understanding of the pathogenesis of DR and could potentially identify therapeutic targets for macular edema

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Anti-tumor immune responses and response to immunotherapy rely on direct recognition by cytotoxic CD8 T cells of antigens presented on the surface of tumor cells. Tumors like melanoma suppress native immune response through induction of T cell dysfunction and exhaustion, but the direct interactions between tumor- specific CD8 T cells and cells in the tumor leading to dysfunction are incompletely understood. Investigation of the anti-tumor T cell specificities required for tumor control, and the intratumoral interactions of tumor-specific CD8 T cells in melanoma, will contribute to a better understanding of the mechanisms driving anti-tumor T cell responses and pave the way for future TCR-based therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Musculoskeletal tissues like tendon undergo a variety of mechanical changes at the microscale that lead to inferior tissue-level mechanics and increased rupture rates. The purpose of this study is to elucidate the role of glycosaminoglycans in fatigue-induced rupture in aging and healing Achilles tendons using a multiscale experimental and computational approach. This research will innovate current biomechanical evaluations of tendon rupture due to fatigue, enhance our understanding of how tendon ruptures occur in vulnerable populations, and inform future treatments to improve tendon function and prevent injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnant people, fetuses, and infants are at increased risk of influenza-associated morbidity and mortality, which can be prevented by administering seasonal influenza vaccine during pregnancy. Leveraging data from a previously conducted maternal influenza vaccine RCT in Nepal, this project seeks to close gaps in knowledge in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) pertaining to maternal influenza disease severity, the impact of maternal influenza vaccination on infant growth, the optimal timing of vaccination during pregnancy, and the cost-effectiveness of this intervention. These data could inform vaccine policy changes, facilitate implementation of maternal influenza vaccines in LMICs, and provide opportunities for the F31 candidate to gain expertise in new methods and advance as an independent investigator studying maternal immunization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Belay Diagnostics has developed and validated a highly sensitive and specific multi-omic technology, CSF-TumorDx, that can detect tumor derived DNA in cerebrospinal fluid to aid in the diagnosis of brain cancers. In this Fast-Track application we will: i) establish pre-analytic quality control procedures, ii) determine the analytical sensitivity and specificity of CSF-TumorDx and iii) determine the clinical validity of CSF-TumorDx. Belay Diagnostics will work closely with investigators at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine to validate the performance of CSF-TumorDx and at the completion of this proposal will have a CLIA certified test ready for clinical implementation and commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Whether obesity is unhealthy depends in large part upon the balance between maladaptive fat expansion via adipocyte hypertrophy (growth in pre-existing fat cells) and metabolically protective fat expansion via adipocyte hyperplasia (increasing numbers of new fat cells). In this proposal, we will investigate the potential of insulin-like growth factor 2 (IGF2) to promote adipocyte progenitor proliferation and differentiation, the dynamic processes that drive hyperplastic fat expansion. The results of this proposal will provide a better understanding of whether enhanced IGF2 action in adipocyte progenitors is a viable strategy for promoting hyperplastic fat expansion and uncoupling obesity from metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) affects approximately 1% of the population and can lead to significant morbidity, in- creased mortality, and substantial health-care and societal costs. This project will study two immune cell sub- sets from the lung to understand whether they are involved in the production of RA-related antibodies in the lung during the early phases of RA development. Ultimately, these findings can lead to novel approaches for RA prevention that target these cells or proteins produced by these cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This research is clinically relevant as it aims to improve the accuracy of assessing HER2 expression in breast cancer patients, particularly those with HER2-low/negative tumors, and to develop personalized treatment strategies for these patients. Subclassifying breast cancer by quantitatively measuring spatial HER2 expression patterns using our proposed high-sensitivity HER2 assay and morphologic, deep learning-based approaches could lead to better patient selection for trastuzumab deruxtecan therapy, ultimately improving treatment outcomes and reducing healthcare costs. The research also has the potential to advance our understanding of the pathologic and spatial biomarker expression parameters that influence antibody-drug conjugate therapy response, contributing to the advancement of cancer medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative An unacceptably high risk for second ACL injuries exists for young and physically active individuals who suffer a first-time anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury and opt for surgical reconstruction to restore stability in preparation to return to pre-injury levels of activity. The current ancillary study aims to develop a predictive model for underlying kinematic mechanisms for this increased risk of re-injury by using easily accessible, open-source, markerless video capture technology combined with innovative data processing techniques to derive movement coordination features during single-leg jump maneuvers. The findings of this study will provide an evidence-based approach for personalized & precision care for patients recovering from ACL reconstruction surgeries that leverages current data analytics and technology to better inform healthcare decisions and to promote health and well-being through safe engagement in physical activity despite prior injury and surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients supported by extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and their families likely have numerous palliative care needs due to high mortality and complication rates for patients, increased psychological distress for families, and the unique ability of ECMO to support life nearly indefinitely even when prognosis is very poor. Despite the exponentially increasing use of ECMO for cardiac and pulmonary failure, research into the palliative care needs of these patients and their families is lacking. This project aims to better understand which patients on ECMO are receiving specialty palliative care support, what type of support palliative care services are providing, and what types of support patients and their family members need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The recently developed charge-altering releasable transporter (CART) gene delivery vectors exhibit remarkable efficiency for mRNA transfection and expression with site specific selectivity and low cytotoxicity. We propose to study the structure-property-function relationship of mRNA/CARTs complexes with advanced microscopy and scattering techniques to elucidate how physicochemical properties affect nanostructure. Distinct formulations will be further screened to relate biological function to structure allowing for the establishment of a set of design rules to aid the development of CARTs for efficient and selective immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROGRAM OVERALL – Project Narrative - CCHI Enteric bacterial infections include different types of diarrheal illnesses caused by pathogenic Salmonella and Shigella which afflict major populations around the world, particularly in developing nations, disproportionally affecting children. The development of new and improved vaccines is hampered because we do not fully understand how the human immune system operates to protect children and adults from these infections. To address these problems, the central theme of our “Mechanisms of Mucosal and Systemic Immunity to Vaccination and Infection with Enteric Pathogens in Children and Adults” CCHI application is to further our understanding of the immune mechanisms that operate in both systemically and in the gut mucosal environment, by using unique human infection and vaccination models of Salmonella and Shigella.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Due to its significant involvement in biological processes, cell migration contributes to disease progression in cancer and arthritis, while its impairment leads to anomalous tissue development or regeneration. Our approach of combining genetic resources with live-cell imaging and optogenetic operations will uniquely dissect the molecular mechanisms of cell migration, and may offer novel mechanistic insights into the cell migration-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Covalent protein modifications are critical regulatory signals that enable cells to adapt to changing conditions, but they are often dysregulated in diseases, such as cancer. In the interest of improving public health, we must understand–at the molecular level–how such modifications affect protein function and dysfunction. To this end, the proposed work will establish a causative link between protein modification, structure, and function, which may ultimately translate to new treatment strategies for human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent work has uncovered incredible transcriptional diversity within the somatostatin cortical interneuron class. Although much work has shown that interneuron circuit integration drives the proper maturation of cortex, the precise efferent connectivity of cortical interneurons subtypes, and how this precision is achieved in development, is unknown. This project seeks to link transcriptional diversity of somatostatin subtype specific functional connectivity in cortical microcircuits, to examine how this specify arises in development and to explore the role of developmental activity in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Liver fibrosis is the consequence of chronic liver diseases, such as hepatitis B and C infection and alcoholic and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, and to date, there is no effective anti-fibrotic agent for treating liver cirrhosis, thus, effective treatments for liver fibrosis and cirrhosis are desperately needed. The invasion of hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) to liver parenchyma is crucial for fibrosis development and we found that Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) is upregulated in migrated and invaded HSCs. Because the role of WT1 in the HSC invasive phenotype of HSCs is not fully understood, we will investigate the role of WT1 and its downstream effector pathways in HSC migration, invasion and extracellular matrix production, developing bridging fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project narrative In the United States, 1.84 million people have type 1 diabetes with 21% increase in diagnosis between 2001 and 2009, and 5 million people expected to be diagnosed by 2050. Islet transplantation can cure type 1 diabetes, but it requires chronic systemic immunosuppression which limits the applicability of this procedure only to the most severe cases of type 1 diabetes. Our innovative platform for islet microencapsulation through conformal coating combined with our localized immunomodulatory approaches may eliminate the need for lifelong systemic immunosuppression and extend the applicability of islet transplantation to a larger number of patients with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative New antibiotics are urgently needed as pathogens become increasingly drug-resistant, and an attractive set of targets are the bacterial machines involved in cell wall growth. In Escherichia coli, there are two major cell wall synthesizing complexes: the Rod system involved in cell elongation, and the divisome responsible for cell division. My project will investigate the function of the RodZ protein that is important for the activity of the rod system, and the insights gained have the potential to identify new vulnerabilities in bacterial surface growth to target for antibiotic development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although evidence indicates that half of all surgical site infections may be preventable, they are on the rise in the United States and are a substantial cause of morbidity, prolonged hospitalization, mortality, and healthcare costs. There is a lack of evidence-based guidelines for pediatric surgical infection risk factors and prevention protocols leading to high variability and low reliability across pediatric surgical care settings. This study aims to apply machine learning to generate prediction models using electronic health data that will inform the design of a clinical decision support tool prototype that provides clinicians with precision pediatric infection risk estimations and prevention recommendations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose investigating whether defective miRNA buffering underlies the phenotypic variability observed in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome. The results of these experiments will provide a new mechanistic understanding of the interaction of genes and environment, which can be directly translated to the prevention of congenital disabilities in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic diseases, such as obesity, type II diabetes, and atherosclerosis are often the result of multi-system changes at the organ, cell, and intracellular level. While one of the key drivers of metabolic disease is elevated plasma lipid levels, less is known on the molecular underpinnings that occur during lipid accumulation. This proposal will investigate how specific changes in the peroxisome drive lipid homeostasis and inter-organelle responses, allowing for an advanced understanding of intracellular communication in both healthy and diseased states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The regulation of protein homeostasis is a crucial for all life, especially in nervous systems. Among mollusks, octopuses seem to have coevolved in these systems through a unique modification to the species’ ribosomes which improves translation accuracy, with broad implications for also improving proteostasis. This project aims to characterize this evolved novelty on a molecular level and the adaptive impact it has for broader phenotypes we see in these vastly intelligent and complex animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Barrett's esophagus (BE) is the only known precursor lesion for esophageal adenocarcinoma and little is known about the progression from intestinal metaplasia to dysplasia. Here, we probe the molecular drivers of this transition to dysplasia with unprecedented resolution using a combined approach of single-cell RNA sequencing, mitochondrial mutational clone tracking and 3D epithelial culture systems. Results of this work will provide new diagnostic and therapeutic targets for dysplastic BE to prevent development of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The overarching goal of the Research and Education towards Solutions for Late effects to Innovate, Excel, and Nurture after chronic Graft-versus-Host Disease (RESILIENT after cGVHD) consensus conference is to address the state of the science, recommendations for clinical care, and research priorities for pediatric survivors of Hematopoetic cell transplantation (HCT) diagnosed with cGVHD. The conference will be divided into four sections, each led by a working group: Phases of Chronic GVHD, Organ Dysfunction and Immunity, Metabolism, Growth and Development, and Patient Important Outcomes. Preliminary reports of the working groups will be open for discussion over a one day conference for stakeholders on the HCT community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Across the globe, 537 million individuals are diagnosed with diabetes and in the United States, the prevalence has steadily increased from 2001 to 2020. This project aims to study the gene regulatory mechanisms of β-cell identity, function, and senescence mediated by the epigenetic regulator, Rnf20, with the overall goal of identifying factors involved in the maintenance of healthy insulin-producing β-cells. Our findings will provide a better understanding of the factors and pathways that maintain β-cell function, which is crucial for the development of novel diabetes therapies that can mitigate comorbidities associated with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary care physicians are at the front lines of care for the growing population of patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), but they must often make treatment decisions without convincing empirical evidence. This study will use electronic health record data to rigorously evaluate three treatment decisions made in primary care for patients with cognitive decline: referral to specialty care, prescription for the antidementia drug memantine, and treatment of urinary tract infections. The project will prepare the student for a research career focused on improving clinical care for individuals with ADRD by leveraging real-world data to inform clinical guidelines for dementia care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease is characterized by cognitive impairment and memory loss, however, the precise constellation of symptoms, the age at which they start, and the rate of decline can vary widely between patients. This study will address one potential contributor to clinical heterogeneity in Alzheimer's by studying factors which affect amyloid neuropathology thought to be an early hallmark of disease, and how differences in amyloid formation may impact cells in the brain and their ability to support learning and memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ─ OVERALL The goal of this proposed COBRE in Convergent Engineering and Biomolecular Science (CEBS) is to support the growth of multidisciplinary collaborative research at Boise State University and build research infrastructure through the creation and consolidation of research core facilities. The Center will also provide expertise, training, and mentoring in convergent research to help Research Project Leaders to become independent investigators. Together, these efforts will contribute to creation of a nationally recognized biomedical research center supporting the growing critical need in human healthcare for the development of medical devices and sensors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative There is no patient-centric tool for recording, reviewing, and searching the medical conversations patients have with their healthcare providers, in spite of the fact that patients, on average, forget over 90% of the information communicated with them during office visits only after a few days. This project will provide patients with such a tool that will also support Q&A and further patient education to increase patient compliance and adherence to treatment plans, leverage the patients’ engagement in “shared decision making”, and provide “data mobility” for sharing with any “care partners”. Moreover, the novel representation of patients’ medical journey and other deep learning outcomes of the project will lay the groundwork for advancements in medical ontologies and future research on a variety of treatment plans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital heart defects (CHDs) are the most common class of birth defect worldwide, affecting 1% of all pregnancies and 4-5% of pregnancies affected by pregestational maternal diabetes mellitus (DM). Placental dysfunction is at the core of many adverse obstetric outcomes seen in pregnancies affected by either, and is thought to have a pivotal role in the development of fetal CHDs, particularly in the vasculopathic context of the DM state. The scientific aims of this proposed training plan could inform future biomarker-based diagnosis, in- utero therapy, and clinical risk management of pregnancies with maternal DM and/or fetal CHDs by comparing clinical risk associated with these pregnancies and determining the molecular correlates of placental dysfunction in each disease state.
